[[File:Busan New Year Festival.jpg|thumb|Busan Sunrise Festival]] The '''Busan Sunrise Festival''' ({{Korean|hangul=부산해맞이축제|rr=Busan Haemaji Chukje}}) is an annual event held in [[Busan]], South Korea.
==History== The Busan Sunrise Festival was conceived in 1999 to promote Busan as a "metropolis of cosmopolitan culture and tourism".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shim|first1=Su-hwa|script-title=ko:부산시, 새천년맞이 문화사업 계획 확정|url=https://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=102&oid=001&aid=0004525348|website=[[Yonhap]]|accessdate=August 14, 2018|language=Korean|date=March 12, 1999}}</ref> In order to spread awareness of the inaugural event, the Busan Metropolitan City Government and Busan Cultural Festival Promotion Association invited public participation throughout April to select an official promotional poster.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=ko:<지방단신>새천년 해맞이 축제 포스터 공모|url=https://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=102&oid=001&aid=0004528539|website=Yonhap|accessdate=August 14, 2018|language=Korean|date=March 31, 1999}}</ref>
A bell toll ritual occurs in [[Yongdusan Park]] on December 31 followed by the observance of the [[sunrise]] on [[Haeundae Beach]] on January 1.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bfo.or.kr/festival_Eng/info/01.asp?MENUDIV=1&Fcode=SUNFESTIVAL Official Website]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox play | name = Chariots of Fire | image = Chariots of Fire 2012 play generic poster.jpg | image_alt = | caption = | writer = [[Mike Bartlett (playwright)|Mike Bartlett]]
(stage adaptation)
[[Colin Welland]]
(screenplay) | chorus = | music = [[Vangelis]] | characters = {{plainlist| * [[Eric Liddell]] * [[Harold Abrahams]] * Lord Andrew Lindsay * [[Aubrey Montague]] * [[Sam Mussabini]] }} | mute = | setting = {{plainlist| * [[1924 Paris Olympics]] * [[Cambridge University]] * [[Scotland]]}} | premiere = {{Start date|2012|5|9|df=y}} | place = [[Hampstead Theatre]], London | orig_lang = | series = | subject = | genre = drama, sports, inspirational | web = https://web.archive.org/web/20120528073952/http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/whats-on/2012/chariots-of-fire }} '''''Chariots of Fire''''' is a 2012 stage adaptation of the 1981 [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-winning [[Chariots of Fire|film of the same name]]. Production of the Olympic-themed play, which opened at London's [[Hampstead Theatre]] 9 May 2012 and transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] on 23 June 2012, was partially inspired by the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 London Summer Olympics]]. ==Overview== The ''Chariots of Fire'' adaptation for the stage was written by playwright [[Mike Bartlett (playwright)|Mike Bartlett]], and [[Edward Hall (director)|Edward Hall]] directed the play. It starred [[Jack Lowden]] as Scottish missionary [[Eric Liddell]], and [[James McArdle]] as Jewish Cambridge student [[Harold Abrahams]]. For the production, stage designer [[Miriam Buether]] transformed the entire theatre into an Olympic stadium, so that audiences had the experience of being in the Olympic stands.[http://westend.broadwayworld.com/article/Cast-Announced-for-Hampstead-Theatres-CHARIOTS-OF-FIRE-Opens-May-9-20120402# "Cast Announced for Hampstead Theatre's ''Chariots of Fire''; Opens May 9"]. ''Broadway World''. 2 April 2012.Girvan, Andrew. [http://www.whatsonstage.com/news/theatre/london/E8831331287794/Black+Watch's+Lowden+plays+Eric+Liddell+in+Chariots+of+Fire.html "''Black Watch'''s Lowden plays Eric Liddell in ''Chariots of Fire''"]. ''What's On Stage''. 9 March 2012.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120528073952/http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/whats-on/2012/chariots-of-fire ''Chariots of Fire'' – Hampstead Theatre] The play includes the film's iconic [[Vangelis]] score, and Vangelis also created several new pieces of music for the production.[http://elsew.com/data/latest.htm#25-5-2012 "''Chariots of Fire'' Stage Play Music: A Possible Release?"] ''Elsewhere: The Independent Vangelis Website''. 25 May 2012.Twitter: ''Chariots Tweeter'', [https://twitter.com/ChariotsHT/status/191903872313344000 16 April 2012], [https://twitter.com/ChariotsHT/status/192645441958055936 18 April 2012] [https://twitter.com/ChariotsHT/status/203210428313108480 17 May 2012].Rees, Jasper. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/9241633/Chariots-of-Fire-The-British-are-coming...-again.html "''Chariots of Fire'': The British Are Coming... Again"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''. 3 May 2012. As in the film, [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] songs are also used, and additional music was provided by Tony Award-winning composer Jason Carr. The stage version for the London Olympic year was the idea of the film's director, [[Hugh Hudson]], who co-produced the play; Hudson stated, "Issues of faith, of refusal to compromise, standing up for one's beliefs, achieving something for the sake of it, with passion, and not just for fame or financial gain, are even more vital today."Jury, Louise. [https://archive.is/20120917112247/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-24032072-theatre-to-run-chariots-of-fire-with-vangelis-tracks.do "Theatre to Run ''Chariots of Fire'' with Vangelis Tracks"]. ''[[London Evening Standard]]''. 30 January 2012. ''Chariots of Fire'' opened in previews 9 May at London's [[Hampstead Theatre]], and officially opened there on 22 May.[http://www.viewlondon.co.uk/whatson/chariots-of-fire-article-969816-20410.html ''Chariots of Fire'']. ''View London''. (Accessed 12 May 2012) It transferred to the [[Gielgud Theatre]] in the [[West End theatre|West End]] on 23 June, where it ran until 5 January 2013.Rees, Jasper. [http://www.theartsdesk.com/film/chariots-fire-coming "''Chariots of Fire'' Is Coming!"] ''The Arts Desk''. 18 April 2012. ==Original cast== * [[Jack Lowden]] – [[Eric Liddell]], the devout son of Scottish missionaries to China * [[James McArdle]] – [[Harold Abrahams]], a Jewish student at [[Cambridge University]] * Tam Williams – Lord Andrew Lindsay, a Cambridge student runner, partially based on [[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter|Lord Burghley]] and [[Douglas Lowe (athlete)|Douglas Lowe]] * Mark Edel-Hunt – [[Aubrey Montague]], a runner and friend of Harold Abrahams * [[Nickolas Grace]] – Master of [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]] at Cambridge University * [[Simon Williams (actor)|Simon Williams]] – Master of [[Caius College, Cambridge|Caius College]] at Cambridge University * [[Nicholas Woodeson]] – [[Sam Mussabini]], Britain's greatest running coach * Natasha Broomfield – Jennie Liddell, Eric's devout sister * Savannah Stevenson – [[Sybil Evers]], Harold Abrahams' fiancée * [[Antonia Bernath]] – Florence Mackenzie, Eric Liddell's Canadian fiancée * Matthew Pearson – Sandy McGrath, Liddell's friend and running coach * David Newman – the [[Edward VIII|Prince of Wales]], who tries to get Liddell to change his mind about running on Sunday ==Synopsis== {{main article|Chariots of Fire}} ''Chariots of Fire'' is the inspirational true story of two great British athletes, outsiders who overcome prejudice and personal strife to compete in the [[1924 Paris Olympics]]. [[Eric Liddell]] is a devout Scottish Christian who runs for the glory of God. [[Harold Abrahams]] is the son of an immigrant Lithuanian Jew who runs to overcome prejudice. The two young track athletes live for the purity and honour of running, and prevail in the face of enormous odds. The story begins in 1919, and climaxes in the heartbreaks and triumphs of the [[1924 Paris Olympics]]. ==Production== [[File:VangelisElGrecopremiereDE2.jpg|thumb|230px|In addition to his iconic original score, [[Vangelis]] created several new pieces of music for the 2012 play.]] The stage revival of the film was the inspiration of Hugh Hudson, who directed the 1981 film.Nikkhah, Roya. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/9291892/Director-Hugh-Hudson-and-his-wife-Maryam-dAbo-speak-of-their-new-film-inspired-by-the-illness-that-nearly-killed-her.html "Director Hugh Hudson and His Wife Maryam d'Abo Speak of Their New Film Inspired by the Illness That Nearly Killed Her"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''. 27 May 2012. He and fellow co-producer [[Barbara Broccoli]], a film-industry magnate best known for the [[James Bond in film|James Bond]] franchise, set about looking for the perfect director for the piece. Broccoli's involvement with ''Chariots of Fire'' extended back to 1980, when she introduced her friend [[Dodi Fayed]] to the screenplay, and he ended up co-financing the film and becoming its executive producer.Jury, Louise. [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/london/chariots-of-fire-will-run-in-west-end-to-honour-dodi-fayed-7660581.html "''Chariots of Fire'' Will Run in West End... to Honour Dodi Fayed"]. ''[[London Evening Standard]]''. 19 April 2012. Hudson and Broccoli chose Edward Hall to helm the stage adaptation, based upon his clear and incisive view of all the challenges involved in adapting the athletics-heavy story to the stage. Hall recruited the award-winning playwright Mike Bartlett, based on his many successes including ''[[Earthquakes in London]]'', to write the script for the play. Set designer Miriam Buether transformed Hampstead Theatre into its very own stadium, giving the audience an immersive experience that evoked the 1924 Paris Olympics, including seating in the round around an Olympic track, and a double [[revolving stage]].[[Matthew Syed|Syed, Matthew]]. [http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/news/2012/april/when-sport-was-fun-chariots-of-fire-is-back "When Sport Was Fun: ''Chariots of Fire'' Is Back"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512070123/http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/news/2012/april/when-sport-was-fun-chariots-of-fire-is-back |date=12 May 2012 }}. ''[[The Times]]''. 28 April 2012.[[Mark Lawson|Lawson, Mark]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/may/29/history-theatre-revolve-stage-studies "A 360-Degree History of the Theatre Revolve"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 29 May 2012. Buether also later transformed the Gielgud Theatre into an immersive stadium with a track running through the audience.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01j5nw0 ''Midweek'': Libby Purves interview with Jack Lowden]. [[BBC Radio 4]]. 30 May 2012. And choreographer Scott Ambler reinvented and choreographed the various running scenes for maximum theatrical effect. Scottish up-and-comer [[Jack Lowden]] was cast as Eric Liddell, on the strength of his glowingly reviewed, charismatic, and athletic performance as the main character Cammy in an international tour of the Olivier Award-winning play ''[[Black Watch (play)|Black Watch]]''. And [[RADA]]-trained [[James McArdle]], with several classics under his belt, had most recently portrayed [[Robin Hood]] at the [[Royal Shakespeare Company|RSC]], and was chosen to play Harold Abrahams. Rehearsals for the actors portraying athletes incorporated grueling training, including lengthy runs, with a [[British Military Fitness]] instructor.Kay, Richard. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2150847/RICHARD-KAY-Troubled-Sophie-Anderton-single-again.html "Troubled Sophie Anderton Single Again"]. ''[[Daily Mail]]''. 27 May 2012. And when stars Jack Lowden and James McArdle discovered they live on the same London street, they began running to rehearsals in addition to the required group training.Gardner, Lyn. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/may/06/chariots-of-fire-athletic-plays "''Chariots of Fire'': This One Will Run and Run"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 6 May 2012. ==Differences from the film== [[File:The Great Court at Trinity College - geograph.org.uk - 1291695.jpg|thumb|230px|The [[Trinity Great Court|Great Court]] at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], site of the Great Court Run]] In the 1981 film, screenwriter [[Colin Welland]] anchored the period story to the present by opening with Harold Abrahams' 1978 memorial service. In Mike Bartlett's 2012 play, the story is anchored to the present by beginning the piece with 15 modern athletes doing a warm-up, "which turns into a training session, which suddenly evolves into Lord Lindsay and Harold Abrahams." Bartlett also used theatrical techniques to allow the play to "tell two stories at the same time, and show links between them and metaphors and parallels", using the Eric Liddell story to talk about Harold Abrahams and using Harold to talk about Eric. The play contains more meetings between Liddell and Abrahams than there were in the film, and also more humour.[http://www.thesouthernreporter.co.uk/news/local-headlines/jack-fired-up-as-he-follows-in-flying-footsteps-of-olympics-legend-liddell-1-2308057 "Jack Fired Up as he Follows in Flying Footsteps of Olympics Legend Liddell"]. ''Southern Reporter''. 21 May 2012. In contrast to the film, the play has Abrahams struggling with, in addition to anti-Semitism, thoughts of his estranged and never-present father. Director Edward Hall stated that, in addition, "In theatre you can take components of the story and analyse them narratively in different ways. So you can stretch or freeze a moment in a race.... it gives you more freedom." Astute staging, he noted, can convey all of the various emotions that take place while running, and then finishing, a race.Hemming, Sarah. [http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/2708eb7a-92ea-11e1-aa60-00144feab49a.html "''Chariots of Fire'' Comes to the Stage"]. ''[[The Financial Times]]''. 5 May 2012. And in contrast to the film, the play also introduces a female admirer for Eric Liddell: his real-life fiancée Florence Mackenzie, the daughter of Canadian missionaries to China. Also in the play, the very fit ensemble cast and extras are not only utilized for running and racing, but also are frequently employed in singing as well.Geiser, Lauren. [https://archive.is/20120722055818/http://www.camdennewjournal.com/reviews/books/2012/may/theatre-pre-olympics-blaze-glory-chariots-fire-hampstead "A Pre-Olympics Blaze of Glory in ''Chariots of Fire'' at Hampstead"]. ''[[Camden New Journal]]''. 24 May 2012. ==Critical reception== [[File:London26July2012d.jpg|320px|thumb|right|[[Jack Lowden]], [[Vangelis]], and [[James McArdle]] watch the [[Olympic Torch Relay]] from the [[Gielgud Theatre]], July 2012.]] ''Chariots of Fire'' opened officially on 22 May 2012, and received positive reviews from major critics in major UK publications.[http://www.whatsonstage.com/roundup/theatre/london/E8831337871078/Review+Round-up%3A+Chariots+of+Fire+takes+the+silver+.html "Review Round-Up: ''Chariots of Fire'' Takes the Silver"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527184631/http://www.whatsonstage.com/roundup/theatre/london/E8831337871078/Review%2BRound-up%3A%2BChariots%2Bof%2BFire%2Btakes%2Bthe%2Bsilver%2B.html |date=27 May 2012 }}. ''What's On Stage''. 24 May 2012.Masters, Tim. [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-18165964 "''Chariots of Fire'' Play Limbers Up for West End Run"]. ''[[BBC News]]''. 23 May 2012.[http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/news/ "News"]. ''HampsteadTheatre.com''. (accessed 25 May 2012) By 29 May, the Hampstead Theatre run had sold out.Twitter: ''Hampstead Theatre''. [https://twitter.com/Hamps_Theatre/status/207497861477310465 29 May 2012]. [[Libby Purves]] of ''[[The Times]]'' wrote that "even this grumpy Olymposceptic was brought to actual tears, moved to empathy and understanding by the fabulous theatricality of it." She called Edward Hall's staging "thrilling" and the play "irresistible", adding that "above all, it's the sincerity: a full-blooded willingness to take the hearty morality, amateur spirit and patriotism at its own valuation without modish irony." Praising the main cast, Purves singled out Jack Lowden as "outstanding", and Nicholas Woodeson as "superb".[[Libby Purves|Purves, Libby]]. [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/stage/theatre/article3423772.ece "''Chariots of Fire'' at the Hampstead Theatre"]. ''[[The Times]]''. 24 May 2012. (paywall)[http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/news/2012/05/4-stars-from-the-times-for-chariots-of-fire "4 Stars from ''The Times'' for ''Chariots of Fire''"]. HampsteadTheatre.com. 24 May 2012. (Excerpt of ''The Times'' review by Libby Purves, 24 May 2012) [[Quentin Letts]] in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' deemed the play a "stirring production" and "thrilling", and gave it five stars, adding of the two leads that, "Both actors are splendid."[[Quentin Letts|Letts, Quentin]]. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/reviews/article-2148513/Chariots-Fire-Gold-medals-round-adaptation-celebrated-film.html "''Chariots of Fire'': Gold Medals All Round for this Adaptation of the Celebrated Film"]. ''[[Daily Mail]]''. 22 May 2012. Revised and reprinted 24 May 2012 as [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2149611/Chariots-Of-Fire-flaming-fantastic-adaptation-hit-film.html "''Chariots of Fire'' Is a Flaming Fantastic Adaptation of Hit Film"]. [[Christopher Hart (novelist)|Christopher Hart]] of the ''[[Sunday Times]]'' also gave the play five stars, declaring it "a bravura version of the 1981 movie". "It's Edward Hall's staging that's the real winner" he wrote, describing the running sequences as "pure exhilaration". He summed up the play as "a joyful antidote to the modern Olympics", "a real summer high", and "surely one of the great treats of the summer".[[Christopher Hart (novelist)|Hart, Christopher]]. [http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/arts/theatre/article1044680.ece "''Chariots of Fire'', Hampstead Theatre"] ''[[The Sunday Times]]''. 27 May 2012. (paywall)[http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/news/2012/05/5-stars-from-the-sunday-times-for-chariots-of-fire/ "5 Stars from ''The Sunday Times'' for ''Chariots of Fire''"] HampsteadTheatre.com. 27 May 2012. (Excerpt of ''The Sunday Times'' review by Christopher Hart, 27 May 2012). [[Ian Shuttleworth]] in the ''[[Financial Times]]'' praised Edward Hall's "considerable adroitness" in directing what he deemed "a fine Olympic-season project". He also admired Bartlett's script in that "[h]e utilises the stage's greater ability to open up to the protagonists’ inner voices, showing Abrahams’ preoccupation with his never-present father and in particular Liddell's devout brand of muscular Christianity ...."[[Ian Shuttleworth|Shuttleworth, Ian]]. [http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/30b684f6-a4c0-11e1-9a94-00144feabdc0.html "''Chariots of Fire'', Hampstead Theatre, London"]. ''[[Financial Times]]''. 23 May 2012. [[Michael Billington (critic)|Michael Billington]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' praised "Edward Hall's bravura production" and Miriam Buether's "brilliant" set. He also noted approvingly that Hall's "kaleidoscopic pageant" of a play is bound together by music, including Gilbert and Sullivan numbers, Scottish bagpipes, a medley of British folk tunes, and the iconic Vangelis theme.[[Michael Billington (critic)|Billington, Michael]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/may/22/chariots-of-fire-review "''Chariots of Fire'' – Review: Hampstead Theatre, London"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 22 May 2012. Andrzej Lukowski of ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' wrote, "This lavish stage adaptation ... is about as close to a West End musical as it's possible to get without in fact being one", citing the frequent Gilbert and Sullivan hits, the impressive stadium set, the 21-strong ensemble cast, and the stylized running choreography. Lukowski praised Bartlett for his "funny, pithy and creative" script, and summarized the production by asserting it is "a spectacle".Lukowski, Andrzej. [http://www.timeout.com/london/theatre/event/253672/chariots-of-fire "''Chariots of Fire''"]. ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]''. 23 May 2012. ''[[The Independent]]'' noted that, in a play about competition, "what eventually emerges as the really engaging battle of wills is that of Abrahams and Liddell versus the British Establishment – ironic, as they each strive to shine for king and country."Bassett, Kate. [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/reviews/chariots-of-fire-hampstead-theatre-londonchildrens-children-almeida-londonin-the-next-room-the-vibrator-play-ustinov-studio-bath-7791217.html "''Chariots of Fire'', Hampstead Theatre, London; ''Children's Children'', Almeida, London; ''In the Next Room'' (''The Vibrator Play''), Ustinov Studio, Bath"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. 27 May 2012. And ''[[The Observer]]'' opined that "[Hall's] fantastically enjoyable production of ''Chariots of Fire'' is a triumph of will that is in keeping with the spirit of the story it tells.... This is an unmissable theatrical offering in the year of the London Olympics."Kellaway, Kate. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/may/27/chariots-fire-posh-childrens-review "''Chariots of Fire''; ''Posh''; ''Children's Children'' – Review"]. ''[[The Observer]]''. 26 May 2012. Many reviewers commented on the intense, often breathless, physicality of the production. The high-speed running around the perimeter of the auditorium and through the audience reminded some of ''[[Starlight Express]]'',[[Michael Coveney|Coveny, Michael]]. [http://www.whatsonstage.com/reviews/theatre/london/E8831337769576/Chariots+of+Fire.html "''Chariots of Fire''"]. ''What's On Stage''. 23 May 2012. and [[Mark Lawson]] on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Front Row (radio)|Front Row]]'' evoked the recent hit play ''[[War Horse (play)|War Horse]]'' as a comparison to the ''Chariots'' play, adding that "It's such an unusual theatre show!"[[Mark Lawson|Lawson, Mark]]. [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio/player/b01hxmwz ''Front Row'']. [[BBC Radio 4]]. 23 May 2012. [[Henry Hitchings]] in ''[[The Evening Standard]]'' deemed the play a "stirring crowd-pleaser" and "a potently realised spectacle", concluding that while "undeniably bombastic fare", "energy and conviction make ''Chariots of Fire'' a satisfying experience."[[Henry Hitchings|Hitchings, Henry]]. [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/arts/theatre/chariots-of-fire-hampstead-theatre--review-7781391.html "''Chariots of Fire'', Hampstead Theatre – Review"]. ''[[Evening Standard]]''. 23 May 2012. In ''[[The Stage]]'', [[Mark Shenton]] echoed other reviews regarding the high-energy, intriguingly staged production. He emphasized in addition that "the meat of the drama" is the "gripping human confrontation being played out at its centre, in which two young men from very different backgrounds ... are drawn into competition with each other but also a bigger one with themselves and what truly matters to each." Shenton concluded that the play "succeeds on its own terms to provide what is sure to be a huge popular theatrical success."[[Mark Shenton|Shenton, Mark]]. [http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/36255/chariots-of-fire "''Chariots of Fire''"]. ''[[The Stage]]''. 23 May 2012. ==Production credits== * Producers: [[Hugh Hudson]], [[Barbara Broccoli]] * Director: [[Edward Hall (director)|Edward Hall]] * Playwright: [[Mike Bartlett (playwright)|Mike Bartlett]] * Set Designer: Miriam Buether * Original Music: [[Vangelis]] * Choreography: Scott Ambler * Additional Music: Jason Carr ==Soundtrack== The play's incidental music was released on CD in 2012, titled ''Chariots of Fire – The Play: Music from the Stage Show''.{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/Vangelis-Chariots-Of-Fire-The-Play-Music-From-The-Stage-Show/release/3855692 |title=Vangelis – ''Chariots of Fire'' (The Play) (Music From The Stage Show) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |accessdate=20 August 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/chariots-of-fire-music-from-the-stage-show-mw0002400437 |title=''Chariots of Fire: Music from the Stage Show'' |author=Al Campbell |work=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=20 August 2016}} Except for the hymn "[[And did those feet in ancient time|Jerusalem]]", the music was composed, arranged and produced by [[Vangelis]]. The CD length is 58:22 minutes, and includes three tracks previously released on the [[Chariots of Fire (album)|movie soundtrack]], two of which are slightly updated. All other 11 Vangelis tracks are newly composed specifically for the stage play. {{Track listing | headline = ''Chariots Of Fire – The Play'' | all_music = | collapsed = yes | title1 = [[Chariots of {{Infobox holiday | |holiday_name=Courir de Mardi Gras
(Mardi Gras Run) |image=Courir de Mardi Gras, Mamou masked riders.jpg |caption=Masked riders in Mamou |date=Mardi Gras, Tuesday before Ash Wednesday |date2012= February 21 |date2013= February 12 |date2014= March 4 |date2015 = February 17 |date2016 = February 9 |date2017 = February 28 |date2018 = February 13 |date2019 = March 5 |frequency=annual |celebrations=Rural tradition, parties |longtype=Local, cultural, [[Catholic]], [[Cajun]] |type=christian |significance=Celebration prior to fasting season of [[Lent]] |relatedto=[[Mardi Gras]] }} The '''Courir de Mardi Gras''' ({{IPA-all|kuɾiɾ d maɾdi ɡɾa|Louisiana French pronunciation:}} {{IPA-fr|kuʁiʁ də maʁdi ɡʁa}}) is a traditional [[Mardi Gras]] event held in many [[Cajun]] communities of south [[Louisiana]] on the Tuesday before [[Ash Wednesday]]. Courir de Mardi Gras is [[Cajun French]] for "Fat Tuesday Run". The rural Mardi Gras celebration is based on early begging rituals, similar to those still celebrated by [[mummer]]s, [[Wassailing|wassailer]]s and celebrants of [[Halloween]].{{cite book|title=Capitaine, voyage ton flag : The Traditional Cajun Country Mardi Gras| author = [[Barry Jean Ancelet]] |publisher=Center for Louisiana Studies, University of Southwestern Louisiana| date=1989 |isbn=0-940984-46-6 }} As Mardi Gras is the celebration of the final day before [[Lent]], celebrants drink and eat heavily, and also dress in specialized costumes, ostensibly to protect their identities. Popular practices include wearing masks, [[capuchon]]s, and costumes, overturning social conventions, dancing, drinking alcohol, begging, feasting, whipping. Because of violent activities associated with the [[Ku Klux Klan]], Louisiana has a state law prohibiting the wearing of hoods and masks in public. Mardi Gras is one of the few occasions when exceptions are allowed, as are Halloween celebrations and religious observances.{{Cite web|url=http://www.legis.la.gov/legis/law.aspx?d=78402|title=RS 14:313|accessdate =2015-03-22}} Two [[HBO]] series (the crime drama [[True Detective (TV series)|''True Detective'']] and the post [[Hurricane Katrina]] themed [[Treme (TV series)|''Treme'']]) make reference to the tradition.{{cite web| url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20793232,00.html | title= Courir de Mardi Gras: The Strangest Tradition You've Never Heard Of| author= Heigl, Alex |publisher = [[People (magazine)|People]] | date= 2014-03-04 | accessdate= 2014-03-17}} ==Origins== [[File:Medieval peasant meal.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Medieval French peasants enjoying a meal]] [[Barry Jean Ancelet]], Cajun historian and head of the [[University of Louisiana at Lafayette]] Folklore Department, has explained the origin of the ''Courir'' as being in rural medieval France: {{quote|In a nutshell, the country Mardi Gras comes from the way Mardi Gras was celebrated in France in the rural section as opposed to the urban carnival. It’s an early springtime renewal and is essentially a way for communities to celebrate and find themselves|''Barry Ancelet''}} These origins are in the customs of [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[medieval Europe]], specifically the ''fête de la quémande'' ("feast of begging") of [[France in the Middle Ages|medieval France]]. During the ''fête'', which was a time when begging from house to house was a socially acceptable behavior, disguised revelers would go through the countryside visiting households and performing for offerings. This is similar to other contemporary traditional European customs such as [[Mummers Play|mumming]] and [[wassailing]] which usually occur around [[Christmas]], New Year's, and [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]]. These traditions originated in a time when most of the land and money was held by the upper classes. The poor, at the end of long winters and short on food, would gather in groups and make their way from castle to manor house to beg for food from the wealthy, dancing and singing in return for the generosity of the nobles.{{cite book|title=Mardi Gras: a Cajun country celebration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SQjbSNHQFwQC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=f%C3%AAte+de+la+qu%C3%A9mande&source=bl&ots=m93nDyYzPX&sig=WAcqq1WSH1BCR0ku6WeFtzS_EVQ&hl=en&ei=X114TbP7IPGD0QGs0-znAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false|first1=Diane|last1=Hoyt-Goldsmith|first2=Lawrence|last2=Migdale|publisher=Holiday House|date=September 1995|page=11|isbn=978-0-8234-1184-9}} French medieval [[carnival]] celebrations also featured contests and races, which may be the origins of the chicken chase associated with the ''courir''.{{cite web|title=Courir du Mardi Gras|url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Festiva1/en/lsm/page4.html|publisher=Canadian Heritage Information Network|accessdate=2010-03-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129192534/http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Festiva1/en/lsm/page4.html|archive-date=2010-11-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} A few of the traditional runs have whipping and [[Penance|penitinece]] as part of their traditions. These traditions are traced to the Medieval [[Flagellant]]s, who would hold processions through the streets whipping themselves and sometimes onlookers to beat the sin out of them. Other of the traditions associated with the ''courir'' are derived from the folk traditions of Pre-Christian [[Celts|Celtic Europe]] and are associated with fertility and renewal. Examples include the use of the [[burlap]] whip and the tune on which the ''Chanson de Mardi Gras'' are based, both of which are traced back to [[Brittany]], a Celtic enclave on the Northwestern French coast near where the original settlers of [[Acadia]] were from.{{cite book|title=Mardi Gras, Gumbo, and Zydeco: Readings in Louisiana Culture|first1=Marcia G.|last1=Gaudet|first2=James C.|last2=McDonald|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HqEY6o7KDqEC&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44&dq=f%C3%AAte+de+la+qu%C3%A9mande&source=bl&ots=Yy2FBZ8XqZ&sig=csGub5Xqa9snqMKaA9g0B2suOnE&hl=en&ei=uu54TbrAIqOI0QGhq7nRAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|date=2003-04-15|isbn=978-1-57806-530-1|page=44}} These traditions were carried to North America by European immigrants during the 17th and 18th centuries. In the mid to late 18th century when the [[Acadian]] settlers of the [[Canadian Maritimes]] were [[Expulsion of the Acadians|forcibly deported by the English]], many made their way to South Louisiana, settling what would become known as the [[Acadiana]] region. The [[Cajun]]s, as they would become known to the rest of the world, have held on to many of their traditional customs, including their language ([[Acadian French]] became [[Cajun French]]), [[Cajun music|music]], [[Cajun dance|dances]] and religious festivals such as the ''courir''.{{cite web|url=http://pages.cs.wisc.edu/~jmeaux/cajun.html|title=Cajun Country|accessdate=2011-03-10}} This determination to hold on to their religious customs and faith has been a major factor in creating the atmosphere that has allowed for the celebration of life, or "la joie de vivre," that is so characteristic of Cajun life and culture in South Louisiana.{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/North-America/Cajuns-Religion-and-Expressive-Culture.html|title=Cajuns - Religion and Expressive Culture|publisher=Advameg, Inc|accessdate=2011-03-10}} ===Modern revival=== Although the tradition never died out, during the 1930s and 1940s it had begun to fade away, especially during the [[World War II]] era as many of the young men who participated were away serving in the armed forces. During the late 1940s and early 1950s the tradition began to be revived and in the 1960s got a major boost with the "Cajun renaissance", a grass roots effort to promote the unique local food, culture, music and language of the area. In 1993, documentary filmmaker Pat Mire chronicled the tradition with his film ''Dance for a Chicken: The Cajun Mardi Gras''.{{ cite web | title = Dance for a Chicken: The Cajun Mardi Gras|author=Mire, Pat|url=http://www.louisianafolklife.org/lt/articles_essays/creole_art_dance_chicken.html | publisher = Louisianafolklife.org }} The imagery of the event is represented in work by local artists such as [[Chuck Broussard]],{{ cite news |url= http://www.myneworleans.com/Louisiana-Life/May-June-2009/Chuck-Broussard/ |title = Chuck Broussard : Art on the Acadian Prairie | newspaper=Louisiana Life Magazine |date =May 2009 | author= Kemp, John R. }} [[Francis Pavy]],{{cite web|url=http://arthurrogergallery.com/exhibition/2005-francis-x-pavy/|title=Arthur Roger Gallery : Francis X. Pavy| publisher=Arthur Roger Gallery}} and [[Herb Roe]]{{ cite news| newspaper= [[The Independent (Acadiana)|The Independent Weekly]] | url= http://www.theind.com/living-ind/9630-brush-strokes| author= Purdy, Anna |title= Brush Strokes|date=2011-12-28 }}{{cite news | newspaper= Country Roads Magazine | url= http://www.countryroadsmagazine.com/on-the-cover/february-2014 | author= Fox-Smith, James | title= On the cover : February 2014 | date= February 2014 | location= Baton Rouge, La | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140318223850/http://www.countryroadsmagazine.com/on-the-cover/february-2014 | archivedate= 2014-03-18 | df= }}{{ cite news|newspaper=[[The Independent (Acadiana)|The Independent Monthly]] |url=http://www.signatureflip.com/theind/ind/2014-02-03eEdition.pub/index.html#15 |title=Roe on 'the run' |page=14 |date=February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319000418/http://www.signatureflip.com/theind/ind/2014-02-03eEdition.pub/index.html |archivedate=2014-03-19 |df= }} and in the name and packaging of a locally brewed seasonal beer.{{ cite news|url=http://www.katc.com/news/local-bayou-teche-brewery-releases-beer-to-honor-traditional-mardi-gras/ |title=Local Bayou Teche brewery releases beer to honor traditional Mardi Gras |author=Wilson, Lauren |publisher=[[KATC (TV)|KATC]] |date=2012-01-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319000003/http://www.katc.com/news/local-bayou-teche-brewery-releases-beer-to-honor-traditional-mardi-gras/ |archivedate=2014-03-19 |df= }} The increased popularity of Cajun music and culture has also led to more nonlocal attention for the event. In 2011 the [[NPR]] show Snap Judgement did a series of interviews at one event{{cite news|url=http://snapjudgment.org/courir-de-mardi-gras|title=Courir de Mardi Gras|author=Daniels, Rita|publisher=Snap Judgment Studios|year=2010}} and the courir was used in a story line by [[David Simon]] for his [[HBO]] series ''[[Treme (TV series)|Treme]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/treme-hbo/index.ssf/2011/06/hbos_treme_explained_carnival.html#incart_mce|title=HBO's 'Treme' explained: 'Carnival Time|author= Dave Walker|newspaper=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2011-06-05}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/treme-hbo/index.ssf/2011/06/cajun_mardi_gras_explained_wil.html|title=Cajun Mardi Gras explained: Wilson Savoy on the costumes, music, masks| author= Dave Walker|newspaper=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2011-06-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/carnival-time,56913/ |title=Carnival Time|publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]| author= Phipps, Keith |date= 2011-06-05}}{{cite news| url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/karen-daltonbeninato/carnival-time-for-itremei_b_871560.html |title= Carnival Time for Treme: I Know Your Heart | newspaper= [[The Huffington Post]]| author= Dalton-Beninato, Karen | date=2011-06-05}}{{cite web| url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/ablogsupreme/2011/06/06/137006263/treme-ep-17-mardi-gras-mayhem | title= 'Treme,' Ep. 17: Mardi Gras Mayhem |publisher =[[NPR]] | author1= Jarenwattananon, Patrick |author2= Jackson, Josh |date=2011-06-06}} In 2014 the [[HBO]] crime drama [[True Detective (TV series)|''True Detective'']] included images of courir participants and created a cult group whose roots lay partially in the rural Mardi Gras traditions.{{cite news| url= http://www.vulture.com/2014/03/true-detective-creepy-photos-mardi-gras.html |title= Let’s Talk About Those Creepy Rural Mardi Gras Pictures on ''True Detective'' | newspaper= [[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]| author= Silman, Anna | date=2014-03-03 }}{{cite news| url= https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/03/-em-true-detective-em-reinvents-itself-again/284141/ | title= True Detective Reinvents Itself, Again | newspaper= [[The Atlantic]]| date=2014-03-02 }} ==Traditions== [[File:Courir run 2010 05.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Chasing a chicken through a muddy field]] People escape from ordinary life through the alcohol and the roles they portray in costume. In the early morning the riders or runners or ''Mardi Gras'' (as the troop and its individual members are known){{cite book|title=Cajun Mardi Gras masks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vAaRvSJaVcEC&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20&dq=basile+courir+de+mardi+gras&source=bl&ots=FQKE_TnBKY&sig=xW1vsYjwk_zGDUBuB9P2_Oy9Unc&hl=en&ei=ITd4Tdr7G6Hi0gGI7vnuBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=basile%20courir%20de%20mardi%20gras&f=false|first1=Carl|last1=Lindahl|first2=Carolyn|last2=Ware|publisher=Univ Press of Mississippi|date=June 1997|isbn=978-0-87805-969-0|page=18}} gather in a central meeting place. As they gather, ''Le Capitaine'' (the leader of the Mardi Gras) and his co-capitaines explain the rules and traditions that must be followed. The Capitaine usually rides on horseback, wears a cape and carries a small flag. After he organizes the troop, the bands begin to play and he leads them on the route. Traditions vary in each town with the way it is carried out. Some towns have people on horse back, some on trailers and some on foot, and others use a variation of all three methods.{{Cite web | url=http://www.almostcajun.com/almostcajun/WhatIs.cfm | title=What is Courir de Mardi Gras? | accessdate=2010-02-18 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225200228/http://www.almostcajun.com/almostcajun/WhatIs.cfm | archivedate=2009-02-25 | df= }} The Capitaine is the first to approach the houses along the route, to ask permission to enter onto their property. At this point, in the spirit of frivolity, individual ''Mardi Gras'' will attempt to sneak onto the property. They are held in check by the Capitaines, who sometimes brandish a plaited [[burlap]] whip.{{Cite web|url=http://www.louisianafolklife.org/FOLKLIFEimagebase/FLImagesListing.asp?Page=142|title=Tee Mamou Mardi Gras Whip|publisher=Louisiana Division of the Arts,|author=Carolyn Ware|accessdate=2011-06-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927071906/http://www.louisianafolklife.org/FOLKLIFEimagebase/FLImagesListing.asp?Page=142|archivedate=2011-09-27|df=}} {{quote|These whips are used to maintain discipline during the courir de Mardi Gras (Mardi Gras run.) They are used by the captain and his subordinates [co-captains] only|Claude Durio, Co-capitaine for the Tee Mamou courir}} The whips are designed to be flexible and not to inflict any serious damage onto their victims, but do produce a loud noise for the edification of onlookers. Participants claim one has not fully participated until one has been whipped. Once they are on the property, the revelers play a variety of pranks on the farmers and beg for food{{Cite web|url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/mardmain.htm |title=Mardi Gras in Rural Acadiana |accessdate=2010-02-18 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} for the communal [[gumbo]] that lies at the end of the route. A prize ingredient is a live [[chicken]], which is usually thrown into the air for the drunken ''Mardi Gras'' to chase through the muddy yards and fields. ===La Chanson de Mardi Gras=== The Mardi Gras song, known in the local [[Cajun French]] as "La Danse de Mardi Gras" and "La Vieille Chanson de Mardi Gras",{{cite web|title=Cajun Mardi Gras Celebrations|url=http://worldmusic.about.com/od/northamerican/p/CajunMardiGras.htm|access-date=2012-01-06|author=Megan Romer}} is a traditional tune sung by the participants, although the exact lyrics vary greatly from town to town. The melody of the traditional folk song is similar to melodies of the [[Breton people|Bretons]] from the northern coast of France.{{cite web|url=http://worldmusic.about.com/od/northamerican/a/CajunMardiGrasSong.htm|title=The Cajun Mardi Gras Song|last=Romer|first=Megan|access-date=2011-03-10}} The tune is played in a minor mode not generally found in other [[Cajun music]].{{cite book|title=Blues for New Orleans: Mardi Gras and America's Creole soul|author1=[[Roger D. Abrahams]]|author2= [[Nick Spitzer]]|author3= [[John Szwed]] |author4= [[Robert Farris Thompson]] |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|date=2006-02-09|isbn=978-0-8122-3959-1|page=77}} This version is sung at the Church Point ''Courir de Mardi Gras'': {{quote|Les Mardi Gras vient de tout partout, tout le tour du moyeu. Vient une fois par an pour demander la charité. Une vieille patate, une patate et des gratons. Les Mardi Gras vient de tout partout, tout le tour du moyeu. Vient une par an pour demander la charité. Une vieille patate, une patate et des gratons. Capitaine, capitaine voyage ton flag, tout le tour du moyeu. Une fois par an pour demander la charité. Et des patates, des patates et des gratons. Les Mardi Gras vient de l’Angleterre, tout le tour du moyeu. Vient une fois par an pour demander la charité. Une vieille patate, une patate et des gratons.|''Le Chanson de Mardi Gras, in [[French language|French]]''{{cite web|url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/cpmardisong.htm|title=Le Chanson de Mardi Gras|access-date=2010-02-18}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}}} And the same song in English: {{quote|The Mardi Gras come from everywhere around the hub. Once each year to ask for charity. An old potato, a potato and some cracklins. The Mardi Gras come from everywhere around the hub. Once each year to ask for charity. An old potato, a potato and some cracklins. Captain, captain wave your flag, all around the hub. Once each year to ask for charity. And for potatoes, for potatoes and some cracklins. The Mardi Gras come from England, all around the hub. Once each year to ask for charity. And potatoes, potatoes and cracklins.|''The Song of Mardi Gras, in [[English language|English]]''|source=}} A version of the song by the [[Balfa Brothers]] was included in the 1992 film ''[[Passion Fish]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105107/soundtrack|title=Passion Fish (1992) - Soundtrack|access-date =2010-02-19}} Many other musicians have recorded versions of the song, with notable artists being [[Zachary Richard]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.zacharyrichard.com/english/mardigras.html|title=Zachary Richard - Mardi Gras|access-date =2010-03-17}} [[Steve Riley and the Mamou Playboys]],{{cite web|url=http://lcmardigras.com/steve-riley-live%E2%80%93danse-de-mardi-gras-mardi-gras-song/|title=Steve Riley Live–Danse de Mardi Gras (Mardi Gras Song)|first=Eric|last=Scott|date=2010-02-02|publisher=|access-date=2011-03-10}} [[BeauSoleil]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gumbopages.com/music/beau-notes.html|title=BAYOU DELUXE: The Best of BeauSoleil|author=Chuck Taggart|access-date=2012-01-06}} and [[Cedric Watson]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Vieille-Chanson-Mardi-Gras/dp/B0017IZO6O|title= La Vieille Chanson De Mardi Gras|access-date =2010-02-18}} ===Costumes=== Many of the traditional costumes are derivatives of the costumes worn in early rural [[France]] during the same celebration. The costumes not only conceal the identities of the participants, but also allow them to parody authority figures and society. Role reversals can be employed such men dressing up like women or the rich to pose as the poor.{{cite journal|journal=Deep South|url=http://www.deepsouthmag.com/?page_id=3023|title=Courir de Mardi Gras|first=Erin Z.|last=Bass|publisher=|date=2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-03-10}} The costumes also directly mock the [[nobility]], the [[clergy]] and the educated; celebrants wear [[mitre|miter]] hats, [[mortarboard]]s and [[capuchon]]s, which were initially designed to mock the [[hennin|tall pointy hats]] worn by noble women. These hats are still worn, primarily by men. The name "capuchon" comes from the same root word, "cappa" in Latin, meaning a cape or hood, that gives us "cap" in English and "chapeau" in French. [[Chaperon (headgear)]] describes the development of the word. The hats are vibrantly decorated to match (or intentionally mis-match) the colorful Mardi Gras costumes that they accompany. The capuchons worn by Mardi Gras celebrants are completely unrelated to the pointy hats worn by the [[Ku Klux Klan]] (KKK), founded after the [[American Civil War]], and, in fact, predate the KKK costumes by several hundred years. Originally the costumes were made from old work clothes decorated with cloth remnants and pieces of feed sack material, as many of the participants could not afford to buy material strictly for the event. This led to a patchwork style that has become associated with the costuming of the event.{{cite encyclopedia| url= http://www.knowla.org/entry.php?rec=1306 |title = Georgie and Allen Manuel |encyclopedia= Encyclopedia of Louisiana| author= Farris, Teresa Parker| publisher= Louisiana Endowment for the Humanities}} The shirts and pants of the costume are made by sewing together various pieces of cloth in a patchwork style. The strips of cloth are cut into fringing, and are sewn onto the sleeves, up and down the legs, and on the capuchon. The end effect is a riot of color and pattern. These costumes are also believed to have originated in [[Middle Ages|Medieval times]]. The masks are made by taking ordinary wire mesh [[window screen]] and attaching large protruding noses and painting on features such as eyes and mouths. The masks are almost see through, but usually not enough to discern the wearer's identity. Many costumes and masks include animal features like beaks, feathers, hair, fur or tails. File:Courir de Mardi Gras Savoy Rougaroo and Capitane 2011.jpg|Capitane and a ''courir'' disguised as a ''[[rougarou]]'' File:Courir de Mardi Gras Horse rider with capuchon Savoy, La 2011.jpg|A capuchon wearing ''Mardi Gras'' on horseback File:Courir de Mardi Gras Savoy mortarboard 2011.jpg|Mortarboard and wire mesh mask File:Courir de Mardi Gras Miter hat Savoy, La 2011.jpg|A "Miter" wearing ''Mardi Gras'' dancing in a yard ==Notable Courir celebrations== Each community in the [[Acadiana]] area celebrates their take on the traditional ''Courir de Mardi Gras''. Although there are many variations, most still practice the time honored tradition with ''Le Capitaine'' leading masked revelers on horseback to gather ingredients for making the communal gumbo. A few notable examples have gained attention as vital parts of the local Cajun culture. ===Basile=== In [[Basile, Louisiana|Basile]] the Courir was suspended during [[World War II]], but was re-established during the 1960s.{{Cite web|url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/basimard.htm|title=Basile Courir|accessdate=2010-02-18}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} A provision allowing women to be a part of the Courir has been in place since the 1980s, and they are also permitted to serve as capitaines.{{Cite web| url=http://www.louisianafolklife.org/LT/Articles_Essays/cjn_wom_mg.html |title=Cajun Women and the Country Mardi Gras tradition|accessdate =2010-02-18}} The Basile ''Courir de Mardi Gras'' have a tradition of begging for nickels (called ''cinq sous''). The participants come up to bystanders with an open palm in the traditional begging gesture, and if that does not work, they will try to dig into the pockets or clothes of the bystanders as a prank in an attempt to find the nickels. ===Choupic=== The rural Mardi Gras in [[Choupic, Louisiana|Choupic]] involves a ritual chasing and [[flogging]] with [[willow tree]] [[branches]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.louisianafolklife.org/lt/articles_essays/main_misc_mardi_in_choupic.html|chapter=Neither Spared nor Spoiled: The Mardi Gras Chase in Choupic, Louisiana|title=Louisiana Folklore Miscellany|publisher=Louisiana Folklore Society|year=1996|pages=17–28|volume=6|first=Madeleine Domangue|last=Cagle|accessdate=2011-02-28}} Young, unmarried men from sixteen or seventeen years old up into their twenties secretly organize the run each year, and they do not disclose their participation in the run to anyone. Once a man is married, he voluntarily stops his participation in the Mardi Gras run. Traditionally, the Mardis Gras were on foot, but today some adaptations have been made, such as the use of pickup trucks and the use of [[all-terrain vehicle|three-wheelers]] by some participants. The Mardis Gras meet early Mardi Gras morning at Possum Square and then climb into the back of a few pickup trucks to hide. The pickup trucks carry the Mardis Gras from one residential section to another where they chase the children of the town, and make them recite [[Catholic]] prayers before giving them their pre-Lenten flogging with willow tree branches or sometimes with the flexible end of a [[fishing pole]]. The Choupic courir de Mardi Gras differs from other courirs in that it does not involve the chasing of chickens nor ritual begging nor the use of horses as a means of transportation. ===Church Point=== [[File:Winners of Children's Courir de Mardi Gras in Church Point, Louisiana - 2017.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|2017 Children's Courir de Mardi Gras in Church Point]] In [[Church Point, Louisiana|Church Point]] the rural Mardi Gras is basically the same as it was in the old days of the early settlers. In 1961 Elton Richard formally organized the event, which until then had been individual, independent groups of riders. Only men are permitted to participate in the run, and all ''Mardi Gras'' must be fully masked and costumed. The Capitaine holds his position as leader for year after year, until he decides to relinquish it. He appoints his co-capitaines who, like himself, must not be masked. The ''Chanson de Mardi Gras'' in Church Point has its own unique lyrics.{{Cite web|url=http://www.churchpointmardigras.com/history.html|title=Church Point Courir de Mardi Gras|accessdate =2010-02-18}} The Church Point Courir is held on the Sunday before Mardi Gras, a consequence of the formal organization in 1961. Elton Richard and Senator Paul Tate of Mamou flipped a coin to see who would have their official courir on Mardi Gras Day. Mamou won and as a result the Church Point Mardi Gras is on Sunday.{{cite web|url=http://www.churchpoint-la.com/mardigras.html|title=COURIR DE MARDI GRAS|publisher=Town of Church Point|accessdate=2011-03-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianarambles.com/news/archives/235/|first=Ian|last=McNulty|title=When Sunday is Tuesday: a Cajun Mardi Gras Alternative|publisher=Louisiana Rambles|accessdate=2011-03-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyworld.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Avis=DG&Dato=20110307&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=103070802&Ref=PH|author=Dwayne Fatherree|title=Church Point Courir du Mardi Gras|accessdate=2011-03-10|publisher=[[Gannett Company]], www.dailyworld.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729194720/http://www.dailyworld.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Avis=DG&Dato=20110307&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=103070802&Ref=PH|archivedate=2012-07-29|df=}} ===Duralde=== In [[Duralde, Louisiana|Duralde]], an unincorporated village between the towns of Mamou and Basile on the southwestern prairies of Louisiana, is one of the Creole Mardi Gras'. Participants at times wear "white face", a way that the Mardi Gras runners dress as "the other" and overturn social conventions and the world for a day.{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianafolklife.org/FOLKLIFEimagebase/FLImagesListing.asp?Page=665|title=Duralde Creole Mardi Gras, 1985|publisher=Louisiana Division of the Arts|accessdate=2011-03-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727042052/http://www.louisianafolklife.org/FOLKLIFEimagebase/FLImagesListing.asp?Page=665|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}} ===Elton=== [[Elton, Louisiana]] is a small town in [[Jefferson Davis Parish, Louisiana]] 15 miles west of Eunice on [[U.S. Route 190]]. Although it was defunct for a long time, the Elton courir was revived in the mid-1990s. It follows the same route and its participants sing the same local variation of the Chanson as the courir in 1925. The ride starts at sunrise just to the north of town and goes through the [[Coushatta Indian Reservation]] and then heads south back toward Elton. Like many of the traditional Courirs the ride is an all-male affair.{{Cite web |url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/elton.htm |title=Elton Courir de Mardi Gras |accessdate=2010-02-19 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Eunice=== In [[Eunice, Louisiana|Eunice]] the celebration dates from when the town was first established in the late 19th century. It was abandoned for a short time during [[World War II]] when many of the local young men were in the army, but was restarted in 1946. The roughly 2000 participants, both male and female, assemble at the National Guard Armory at the corner of South 9th Street and Maple Avenue at 6 a.m., and start the run 8 a.m.{{Cite web|url=http://www.eunice-la.com/festivals.html|title=City of Eunice, La - Area Festivals:Eunice Courir De Mardi Gras|publisher=City of Eunice, La.|accessdate=2010-02-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323144356/http://www.eunice-la.com/festivals.html|archivedate=2010-03-23|df=}} The route is {{convert|13|mi|km}} long. They stop at farms along the route and beg for gumbo ingredients and call out "Cinq-sous pour les Mardi Gras!" or "Nickels for the Mardi Gras'!" If ingredients or money are given, they thank the givers of charity with a dance.{{cite web|title=Where to Be in 30 Days: Experience an Authentic Cajun Mardi Gras|publisher=Fodors|first=Molly|last=Moker|date=2010-01-20|accessdate=2011-03-10|url=http://www.fodors.com/news/story_3834.html}} By 3:00 p.m. the revelers return to town for a parade along Second Street. In 1997 a new addition was added to the festivities, the baking of the world's largest [[king cake]]. ===Gheens=== [[Gheens, Louisiana|Gheens]] is located between [[Raceland, Louisiana|Raceland]] and [[Lockport, Louisiana]], about {{convert|30|mi|km}} from New Orleans. Every year during their Cajun Mardi Gras Chase 20,000 people flock to the town of less than 1000 people for the event. Unlike other Cajun Mardi Gras' celebrations, the Gheens event features teen-aged boys and men dressed as [[ghoul]]s riding in pickup trucks.{{cite web|url=http://www.cvmc.net/movie.jsp?movie_id=2290|title=CVMC: Pardon! Pardon! The Cajun Mardi Gras Chase|accessdate=2011-03-10}} After the morning parades the group meets behind the local church, where costumes are donned and the ground rules are laid out by the veteran runners to the newly initiated. Each of the newcomers must line up and be given a swat by each of the veterans with the yard long willow branches so they know how bad the switches can hurt if over used. The runners are given bells to pin on their clothing. They then load up into their trucks and attack the town with their willow switches, searching for children. They chase the children to "beat the sinful stuff out of them so they can be clean for the [[lent]]". Their young victims have the choice to either fall to their knees in a penitent position and say "Pardon! Pardon!" or make the ''Mardi Gras'' chase them, often taunting and daring them to catch and beat them more.{{cite web|url=http://www.tabasco.com/arts_pavilion/louisiana_artist/syndey_byrd.cfm|title=PepperFest:Courir de Mardi Gras|publisher=McIlhenny Company|accessdate=2011-03-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716182722/http://www.tabasco.com/arts_pavilion/louisiana_artist/syndey_byrd.cfm|archive-date=2011-07-16|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Mamou=== [[File:Courir de Mardi Gras, Mamou.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Mamou courir in the late 1990s]] In [[Evangeline Parish, Louisiana|Evangeline Parish]], the [[Mamou, Louisiana|Mamou]] celebration starts with a street dance held the Monday evening before Mardi Gras, with bands such as [[Steve Riley and the Mamou Playboys]] performing. A crowd favorite is the Mamou variation of the ''Chanson de Mardi Gras''. The next day a street party begins, in anticipation of the Courir, who have been riding through the countryside collecting ingredients for the evening gumbo. The Mamou Courir abides by the older traditions, with the Capitaines unmasked and all other revelers masked in the all-male troupe.{{cite news |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/travel/chi-mardijan13,0,3555985.story | title= Cajun Mardi Gras : And they're off... on the run for the chickens| newspaper=Chicago Tribune | author= Rozas, Angela |date=January 13, 2008}} They are accompanied by a wagon for the musicians and trailers for participants who do not have horses.{{Cite web|url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/mammardi.htm|title=Mardi Gras in Mamou|accessdate=2010-02-18}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The event was suspended twice in its history, during the American Civil War and during World War Two. By the mid-1940s the ''courir'' tradition in Mamou had declined but was revived by Alfred "Fred" Tate, Revon Reed, and Paul Tate, proprietors of the then newly opened "[[Fred's Lounge]]".{{cite news|newspaper=[[Austin Chronicle]]|author= Gerald E. McLeod |title=Day Trips : At Fred's Lounge in Mamou, Louisiana, the good times roll pretty early |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/columns/2001-12-28/84146/|date=2001-12-28|publisher=Austin Chronicle Corp}} ===Soileau=== The run in [[Soileau, Louisiana]] is one of the few [[Louisiana Creole people|Creole]] ''Courir de Mardi Gras'' in southwest Louisiana, and is thought to be just as old as the Cajun versions. The rural community of Soileau is located to the west of [[Duralde, Louisiana|Duralde]] in [[Allen Parish, Louisiana]] not far from the [[Evangeline Parish, Louisiana]] line. They hold their run on the Monday before Mardi Gras, with its starting point at Andrew Cezar's sulky racing track. From there they head down [[Louisiana Highway 104]].{{Cite web|url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/soileaumardi.htm|title=Mardi Gras in Soileau|accessdate=2010-02-19}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===South Cameron=== [[File:South Cameron Mardi Gras 2015.jpg|thumbnail|right|Two Mardi Gras "stealing" a child's bicycle at the South Cameron Courir]] In [[Creole, Louisiana|Creole]], a small town in southern [[Cameron Parish, Louisiana|Cameron Parish]], Mardi Gras celebrations had been defunct for over three decades. This region of [[Southwest Louisiana]] has been plagued by multiple [[Tropical cyclone|hurricanes]] throughout the years, including total destruction by Hurricanes [[Hurricane Audrey|Audrey]], [[Hurricane Rita|Rita]], and [[Hurricane Ike|Ike]]. As a result, the area has a very small, close-knit, and self-reliant population. The courir was revived in 2014 by a group of Cameron Parish natives. The group mainly consisted of young men who were [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] war veterans. Some were displaced by the hurricanes, living in different parts of the state, and looking to bring comradery and tradition back to their community.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kplctv.com/story/24795855/cameron-community-host-first-ever-mardi-gras-chicken-run|title=Cameron community hosts first ever Mardi Gras chicken run|accessdate =2015-04-28}} The Mardi Gras ride throughout the countryside in cattle trailers pulled by pickup trucks. Men and women ride together. The Mardi Gras stop at multiple houses and business in and around the town of Creole to dance, drink, play tricks, chase chickens, and gather ingredients for their communal gumbo that night. They wear traditional Cajun Mardi Gras costumes as well as modern variations. The two to three unmasked Capitaines regulate with burlap whips. A [[Fais do-do]] follows the gumbo. This courir is held two weekends before Mardi Gras day, however, dates are subject to change from year to year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/creolechickenrun|title=South Cameron Courir de Mardi Gras|accessdate =2015-04-28}} ===Tee Mamou-Iota=== The longstanding tradition of the ''courir'' in the small community of [[Tee Mamou, Louisiana|Tee Mamou]] had waned by the late 1960s when new capitane was instrumental in preserving the tradition. An all women's group was established a few years later. The women's group does their run on Saturday before Mardi Gras and the men's run is on Mardi Gras day.{{cite web|title=Gerald Frugé : Cajun Mardi Gras Capitaine|url=http://louisianafolklife.nsula.edu/artist-biographies/profiles/84|accessdate=2011-06-09|publisher=[[Northwestern State University|Northwestern State University of Louisiana]]}} The capitane and co-capitanes of Tee Mamou use a special variation of the burlap whip associated with the courir. The route of the courir ends in the nearby community of [[Iota, Louisiana]]. Iota has an organized event, with [[Cajun music|Cajun]] and [[Zydeco]] bands playing on the main stage throughout Mardi Gras day. The highlight of the day is the arrival of the Tee Mamou ''courirs'' riding into the town in a wagon after the route through the country. The courir then gathers on the main stage with the capitaine to sing their version of the ''Chanson de Mardi Gras''. Once this task is completed, the Mardi Gras descend on the downtown area dancing and begging for loose change.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iotamardigras.com/main.html|title=Tee Mamou-Iota Mardi Gras}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Courir de Mardi Gras}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHbaqtGUj5c&feature=related Balfa Brothers - La Dance Des Mardi Gras] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qhLalqmKkgM&feature=player_embedded Courir de Mardi Gras in Mamou, La 2010] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a6hE9fYpNtc&NR=1 Rural Mardi Gras - Tee-Mamou] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I9hcA6YE3-M&feature=related Rural Mardi Gras : Iota, Louisiana] * [http://snapjudgment.org/courir-de-mardi-gras NPR's Snap Judgement:Courir de Mardi Gras] * [https://curtguillory.wordpress.com/2015/02/15/the-real-maerdi-gras-lejeune-cove-2015/ Lejeune Cove] {{Louisiana}} {{US Holidays}} {{Louisianarootsmusic}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Courir De Mardi Gras}} [[Category:Cajun culture]] [[Category:Acadiana]] [[Category:Mardi Gras]] [[Category:February events]] [[Category:March events]] [[Category:Music festivals in Louisiana]] [[Category:American folklore]]
