[[File:National Defense Service Medal ribbon.svg|border|23px]] [[National Defense Service Medal]]
[[File:Prisoner of War Medal ribbon.svg|23px|border]] [[Prisoner of War Medal]] |website= }} '''Francis Gary Powers''' (August 17, 1929 – August 1, 1977)—often referred to as simply '''Gary Powers'''—was an American pilot whose [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA){{cite web |url=http://www.foia.cia.gov/powers.asp |title=CIA FOIA – Francis Gary Powers: U-2 Spy Pilot Shot Down by the Soviets |publisher=Foia.cia.gov |accessdate=August 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831191815/http://www.foia.cia.gov/powers.asp |archivedate=August 31, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} [[Lockheed U-2|U-2 spy plane]] was shot down while flying a reconnaissance mission in Soviet Union airspace, causing the [[1960 U-2 incident]]. He later worked as a helicopter pilot for [[KNBC]] and died in a [[1977 Gary Powers helicopter crash|1977 helicopter crash]]. ==Early life and education== Powers was born August 17, 1929, in [[Jenkins, Kentucky]], the son of Oliver Winfield Powers (1904–1970), a [[coal miner]], and his wife Ida Melinda Powers ({{nee|Ford}}; 1905–1991).{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/2118|title=Francis Gary Powers (1929 - 1977) - Find A Grave Memorial|work=findagrave.com}} His family eventually moved to [[Pound, Virginia]], just across the state border. He was the second born and only male of six children. His family lived in a mining town, and because of the hardships associated with the life in such a town, his father wanted Powers to become a doctor. He hoped his son would achieve the higher earnings of such a profession and felt the life of a doctor would involve less hardship than any job in his hometown.{{Cite book |last=Powers |first=Francis |title=Operation Overflight: A Memoir of the U-2 Incident |publisher=Potomac Books, Inc. |year=2004 |ISBN=9781574884227 |page=3}} ==Education and service== Graduating with a [[bachelor's degree]] from [[Milligan College]] in [[Tennessee]] in June 1950, he enlisted in the [[United States Air Force]] in October. He was commissioned as a [[Second Lieutenant]] in December 1952 after completing his advanced training with USAF Pilot Training Class 52-H[http://www.52g-52hpilots.org/rosters/52-h.htm] at [[Williams Air Force Base]], [[Arizona]]. Powers was then assigned to the [[468th Strategic Fighter Squadron]] at [[Turner Air Force Base]], [[Albany, Georgia|Georgia]], as an [[Republic F-84 Thunderjet|F-84 Thunderjet]] pilot. He married Barbara Gay Moore in Newnan, Georgia, on April 2, 1955.Newnan-Coweta Magazine, Sep/Oct, 2011, p. 78, https://issuu.com/debwilli/docs/ncom_0910_11_all_lo/78 In January 1956 he was recruited by the CIA. In May 1956 he began U-2 training at [[Area 51|Watertown Strip]], Nevada. His training was complete by August 1956 and his unit, the Second Weather Observational Squadron (Provisional) or Detachment 10-10, was deployed to [[Incirlik Air Base]], [[Turkey]]. By 1960, Powers was already a veteran of many covert aerial reconnaissance missions.{{rp|6–9,14–15,24,50–51,55–56,95}} [[File:RIAN archive 35174 American Spy Pilot Francis Gary Powers.jpg|thumb|left|187px|A Soviet photograph of Powers while he was in Soviet custody]] [[File:U2 Powers Senate model.jpg|thumb|left|187px|Wooden U-2 model – one of two used by Powers when he testified to the Senate Committee. The wings and tail are detached to demonstrate the aircraft's breakup upon impact.]] ==The U-2 incident== {{Main|1960 U-2 incident}} Powers was discharged from the Air Force in 1956 with the rank of [[Captain (U.S. Air Force)|captain]]. He then joined the CIA's [[Lockheed U-2|U-2]] program at the [[General Schedule (US civil service pay scale)|civilian grade]] of GS-12. U-2 pilots flew [[espionage]] missions at altitudes of {{convert|70,000|ft|km}},{{cite web|url=http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/products/u2/u-2-specifications.html |title=U-2 Specifications |publisher=Lockheed Martin |accessdate=November 16, 2015}}{{Cite web|title = Lockheed Martin U-2 Dragon Lady - Development and Operational History, Performance Specifications and Picture Gallery|url = http://www.militaryfactory.com/aircraft/detail.asp?aircraft_id=51|website = www.militaryfactory.com|accessdate = November 16, 2015}}{{Cite web|title = U-2 Dragon Lady|url = http://www.military.com/equipment/u-2-dragon-lady|website = Military.com|accessdate = November 16, 2015|first = John|last = Harper}} supposedly above the reach of Soviet air defenses.{{Cite web|title = American U-2 spy plane shot down - May 01, 1960 - HISTORY.com|url = http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/american-u-2-spy-plane-shot-down|website = HISTORY.com|accessdate = November 16, 2015}} The U-2 was equipped with a state-of-the-art camera designed to take high-resolution photos from the [[stratosphere]] over hostile countries, including the [[Soviet Union]]. U-2 missions systematically photographed military installations and other important sites.{{rp|41}} ===Reconnaissance mission=== The primary mission of the U-2s was overflying the Soviet Union. Soviet intelligence had been aware of encroaching U-2 flights at least since 1958 if not sooner{{rp|47,59}} but lacked effective countermeasures until 1960.{{Cite news|title = Fifty Years Later, Gary Powers and U-2 Spy Plane Incident Remembered|url = http://www.rferl.org/content/Fifty_Years_Later_Gary_Powers_and_U2_Spy_Plane_Incident_Remembered/2029269.html|newspaper = RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|date = April 30, 2010|access-date = November 16, 2015|first = Vladimir|last = Abarinov}} On May 1, 1960, Powers's U-2A, ''56-6693'', departed from a military airbase in [[Peshawar]], [[Pakistan]],{{rp|53}} with support from the U.S. Air Station at [[Badaber]] ([[Peshawar Air Station]]). This was to be the first attempt "to fly all the way across the Soviet Union...but it was considered worth the gamble. The planned route would take us deeper into Russia than we had ever gone, while traversing important targets never before photographed."{{rp|53–54}} ===Shoot-down=== Powers was shot down by an [[S-75 Dvina]] (SA-2 Guideline) surface-to-air missile{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/s75.htm |title=S-75 |publisher=Astronautix.com |accessdate=August 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005194237/http://astronautix.com/lvs/s75.htm |archivedate=October 5, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} over [[Yekaterinburg|Sverdlovsk]]. A total of 14 Dvinas were launched,Polmar, Norman (2001). ''Spyplane: The U-2 History Declassified.'' Zenith Press. p. 137 {{ISBN|0760309574}} one of which hit a [[MiG-19]] jet fighter which was sent to intercept the U-2 but could not reach a high enough altitude. Its pilot, [[Sergei Safronov (fighter pilot)|Sergei Safronov]], ejected but died of his injuries. Another Soviet aircraft, a newly manufactured [[Su-9]] on a transit flight, also attempted to intercept Powers's U-2. The unarmed Su-9 was directed to ram the U-2, but missed because of the large differences in speed (the Su-9 flew above Mach 1.1, while the U-2 flew at approximately Mach 0.6). As Powers flew near Kosulino in the Ural Region, three S-75 Dvinas were launched at his U-2, with the first one hitting the aircraft. "What was left of the plane began spinning, only upside down, the nose pointing upward toward the sky, the tail down toward the ground." Powers was unable to activate the plane's self-destruct mechanism before he was thrown out of the plane after releasing the canopy and his seat belt. While descending under his parachute, Powers had time to scatter his escape map, and rid himself of part of his suicide device, a silver dollar coin suspended around his neck containing a poison-laced injection pin, though he kept the poison pin.http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smithsonian-institution/gary-powers-secret-diary-soviet-capture-180956939/#yilEojcaVQvIj9qc.99 "Yet I was still hopeful of escape." He hit the ground hard, was immediately captured, and taken to [[Lubyanka Building|Lubyanka Prison]] in [[Moscow]].{{rp|61–63,67–71,76}} Powers did note a second chute after landing on the ground, "some distance away and very high, a lone red and white parachute".{{rp|69,148–149,274,278}}{{Cite book |last=Rich |first=Ben |title=Skunk Works |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |year=1994 |ISBN=0316743305 |pages=162–163}}{{rp|159–160}} ===Cover story=== When the U.S. government learned of Powers's disappearance over the Soviet Union, they issued a cover statement claiming a "weather plane" had strayed off course after its pilot had "difficulties with his oxygen equipment". What CIA officials did not realize was that the plane crashed almost fully intact, and the Soviets recovered its equipment. Powers was interrogated extensively by the [[KGB]] for months before he made a confession and a public apology for his part in [[espionage]].{{cite web |url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history.do?action=tdihVideoCategory&id=52645&HPF_rid=9121459&HPF_mid=1180_T1_Url3 |title=This Day in History – History.com – What Happened Today in History |publisher=History.com |accessdate=August 31, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Compromised by newspaper reports=== Powers tried to limit the information he shared with the KGB to that which could be determined from the remains of his plane's wreckage. He was hampered by information appearing in the western press. A KGB major stated "there's no reason for you to withhold information. We'll find it out anyway. Your press will give it to us." However, he limited his divulging of CIA contacts to one individual, with a [[pseudonym]] of "Collins". At the same time, he repeatedly stated the maximum altitude for the U-2 was {{convert|68,000|ft|km}}, significantly lower than its actual flight ceiling.{{rp|xii,78,91,128,135,137,139,145,165–166,256}} ===Political impact=== The incident set back talks between Khrushchev and Eisenhower. Powers's interrogations ended on June 30, and his solitary confinement ended on July 9. On August 17, 1960, his trial began for espionage before the military division of the Supreme Court of the USSR. Lieutenant General Borisoglebsky, Major General Vorobyev, and Major General Zakharov presided. Roman Rudenko acted as prosecutor in his capacity of [[Procurator General of the Soviet Union]]. [[Mikhail I. Grinev]] served as Powers's defense counsel. In attendance were his parents and sister, and his wife Barbara and her mother. His father brought along his attorney Carl McAfee, while the CIA provided two additional attorneys.{{rp|110,114,119,120,142–143,148,157–158,162,188,220}} ===Conviction=== On August 19, 1960, Powers was convicted of espionage, "a grave crime covered by Article 2 of the Soviet Union's law 'On Criminality Responsibility for State Crimes'". His sentence consisted of 10 years' confinement, three of which were to be in a prison, with the remainder in a [[labor camp]]. The US Embassy "News Bulletin" stated, according to Powers, "as far as the government was concerned, I had acted in accordance with the instructions given me and would receive my full salary while imprisoned".{{rp|157–161}} He was held in [[Vladimir Central Prison]], about {{convert|150|mi|km}} east of Moscow, in building number 2 from September 9, 1960 until February 8, 1962. His cellmate was Zigurd Kruminsh (Zigurds Krūmiņš), a Latvian political prisoner. Powers kept a diary and a journal while confined. Additionally he took up carpet weaving from his cellmate to pass the time. He could send and receive a limited number of letters from his family. The prison now contains a small museum with an exhibit on Powers, who allegedly developed a good rapport with Russian prisoners there. Some pieces of the plane and Powers's uniform are on display at the [[Central Air Force Museum|Monino Airbase museum]] near [[Moscow]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.moninoaviation.com/33a.html|title=Air Force Museum - Monino, Russia|website=www.moninoaviation.com|access-date=2018-03-29}} ===Prisoner exchange=== On February 10, 1962, Powers was exchanged, along with U.S. student [[Frederic Pryor]], in a well-publicized spy swap at the [[Glienicke Bridge]] in [[Berlin]]. The exchange was for Soviet KGB [[Colonel]] [[Rudolf Abel|Vilyam Fisher]], known as "Rudolf Abel", who had been caught by the [[FBI]] and tried and jailed for espionage.[https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/history/famous-cases/hollow-nickel/rudolph-ivanovich-abel-hollow-nickel-case/ Famous Cases: Rudolph Ivanovich Abel (Hollow Nickel Case)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160121132429/https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/history/famous-cases/hollow-nickel/rudolph-ivanovich-abel-hollow-nickel-case/ |date=January 21, 2016 }}. [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]. Powers credited his father with the swap idea. When released, Powers's total time in captivity was 1 year, 9 months, and 10 days.{{rp|237–240}} In 2010, CIA documents were released indicating that U.S. officials did not believe Powers's account of the incident at the time, because it was contradicted by a [[classified information|classified]] [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) report which alleged that the U-2 had descended from {{convert|65,000|to|34,000|ft|km}} before changing course and disappearing from radar. However, newly released declassified CIA documents confirm the accuracy of Powers's report.{{clarify|date=December 2015}} The NSA report remains classified.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article7113512.ece |title=CIA documents show US never believed Gary Powers was shot down |publisher=Timesonline.co.uk |accessdate=August 31, 2012}} ==Aftermath== Powers initially received a cold reception on his return home. He was criticized for not activating his aircraft's self-destruct charge to destroy the camera, photographic film, and related classified parts. He was also criticized for not using a CIA-issued "suicide pill" to kill himself (a coin with [[saxitoxin|shellfish toxin]] embedded in its grooves, revealed during CIA testimony to the [[Church Committee]] in 1975).{{cite web|url=http://garypowers.org/1962-spy-exchange-of-powers-for-abel/|title=The 1962 Spy Exchange of Powers for Abel|publisher=Francis Gary Powers, Jr.|accessdate=March 27, 2014}} He was debriefed extensively by the CIA,{{cite web | title = Report of the board of inquiry into the case of francis gary powers (sanitized copy)|publisher = Central Intelligence Agency |url = http://www.foia.cia.gov/sites/default/files/document_conversions/89801/DOC_0000009451.pdf |format = PDF |date = February 27, 1962 |accessdate = July 12, 2010 |page = 1}} [[Lockheed Corporation]], and the Air Force, after which a statement was issued by CIA director [[John McCone]] that "Mr. Powers lived up to the terms of his employment and instructions in connection with his mission and in his obligations as an American."{{cite news |issue=page 2 |publisher=New York Daily News |date=March 7, 1962}} On March 6, 1962, he appeared before a Senate Armed Services Select Committee hearing chaired by Senator [[Richard Russell, Jr.]] which included Senators [[Prescott Bush]], [[Leverett Saltonstall]], [[Robert Byrd]], [[Margaret Chase Smith]], [[John Stennis]], [[Strom Thurmond]], and [[Barry Goldwater]]. During the hearing, Senator Saltonstall stated, "I commend you as a courageous, fine young American citizen who lived up to your instructions and who did the best you could under very difficult circumstances." Senator Bush declared, "I am satisfied he has conducted himself in exemplary fashion and in accordance with the highest traditions of service to one's country, and I congratulate him upon his conduct in captivity." Senator Goldwater sent him a handwritten note: "You did a good job for your country."{{rp|264,270–280}} [[File:KellyJohnsonandGaryPowers.jpg|thumb|325px|[[Clarence Johnson]] and Francis Gary Powers in front of a U-2 (Photo Gary Powers, Jr. / Cold War Museum via AP)]] ===Divorce and Remarriage=== Powers and his wife Barbara separated in 1962 and divorced in January 1963. Powers stated that the reasons for the divorce included her infidelity and alcoholism, adding that she constantly threw tantrums and overdosed on pills shortly after his return.{{Cite news|url=http://www.suwanneedemocrat.com/community/remembering-the-people-and-events-that-shaped-suwannee-county-history/article_7e83104e-7f25-11e5-9a26-570f0db36611.html|title=Remembering the people and events that shaped Suwannee County history: Barbara Moore - part 2|last=Musgrove|first=Eric|work=Suwannee Democrat|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} He started a relationship with Claudia Edwards "Sue" Downey, whom he had met while working briefly at CIA Headquarters. Downey had a child, Dee Rogers, from her previous marriage. They were married on October 26, 1963.VA Marriage Records 1936-2014, Certificate #32518 Their son Francis Gary Powers II was born on June 5, 1965.{{rp|287,292–293,323}} The marriage proved to be a very happy one, and Sue worked hard to preserve her husband's legacy after his death.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jun/25/local/me-powers25|title=Claudia 'Sue' Powers, 68; Wife of Spy Plane Pilot Downed During Cold War|last=Writer|first=From a Times Staff|date=2004-06-25|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} ===Praise=== During a speech in March 1964, former [[CIA Director]] [[Allen Dulles]] said of Powers, "He performed his duty in a very dangerous mission and he performed it well, and I think I know more about that than some of his detractors and critics know, and I am glad to say that to him tonight."{{rp|295–296}} ===Later career=== Powers worked for Lockheed as a test pilot from 1962 to 1970, though the CIA paid his salary. In 1970, he wrote the book ''Operation Overflight'' with co-author [[Curt Gentry]]. {{cite web|last=Powers|first=Francis Gary|title=Operation Overflight: The U-2 pilot tells his story for the first time|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/OPERATION-OVERFLIGHT-PILOT-TELLS-STORY/dp/0030830451 |date=July 27, 2018|accessdate=July 27, 2018}} Lockheed fired him, because "the book's publication had ruffled some feathers at Langley." Powers became a helicopter traffic pilot reporter for [[KNBC|KNBC News Channel 4]]. ==Death== {{Main|1977 Gary Powers helicopter crash}} Powers was piloting a helicopter for KNBC Channel 4 over West Los Angeles on August 1, 1977 when the aircraft crashed, killing him and his cameraman George Spears.{{rp|251,289–290,324}} They had been recording video tape following brush fires in [[Santa Barbara County]] in the KNBC helicopter and were heading back from them. His [[Bell 206]] JetRanger helicopter ran out of fuel and crashed at the [[Sepulveda Dam]] recreational area in [[Encino, California]], several miles short of its intended landing site at [[Burbank Airport]]. The [[National Transportation Safety Board]] report attributed the probable cause of the crash to pilot error.{{cite web|url=http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/Powers-N4TV.htm |title=The Francis Gary Powers Helicopter Crash |publisher=Check-six.com |accessdate=August 31, 2012}} According to Powers's son, an aviation mechanic had repaired a faulty fuel gauge without informing Powers, who subsequently misread it.{{cite web |url=http://phs1.org/U2%20Program/Powers_Helicopter_Crash.htm |title=Powers Helicopter Crash |publisher=Phs1.org |accessdate=August 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613182148/http://phs1.org/U2%20Program/Powers_Helicopter_Crash.htm |archivedate=June 13, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} At the last moment, he noticed children playing in the area and directed the helicopter elsewhere to avoid landing on them. He might have landed safely if not for the last-second deviation, which compromised his [[Autorotation|autorotative]] descent. Powers was survived by his wife, children Claudia Dee and Francis Gary Powers Jr., and five sisters. He is buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]] as an Air Force veteran.{{cite web|author=Michael Robert Patterson |url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/francisg.htm |title=Francis Gary Powers, Captain, United States Air Force |publisher=Arlingtoncemetery.net |accessdate=August 31, 2012}} ==Honors== Powers received the CIA's [[Intelligence Star]] in 1965 after his return from the Soviet Union. Powers was originally scheduled to receive it in 1963 along with other pilots involved in the CIA's U-2 program, but the award was postponed for political reasons. In 1970, Powers published his first—and only—book review, on a work about aerial reconnaissance, ''Unarmed and Unafraid'' by Glenn Infield, in the monthly magazine ''Business & Commercial Aviation''. "The subject has great interest to me," he said, in submitting his review.Letter to G. Haber, Managing Editor, ''Business & Commercial Aviation'' In 1998, newly declassified information revealed that Powers's mission had been a joint USAF/CIA operation. In 2000, on the 40th anniversary of the U-2 Incident, his family was presented with his posthumously awarded [[Prisoner of War Medal]], [[Distinguished Flying Cross (USA)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], and [[National Defense Service Medal]]. In addition, CIA Director [[George Tenet]] authorized Powers to posthumously receive the CIA's coveted [[Awards and decorations of the United States government#Central Intelligence Agency.5B7.5D|Director's Medal]] for extreme fidelity and extraordinary courage in the line of duty.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090226191939/http://www.spymuseum.org/programs/educate/pdfs/AIRSHO2007_Powers.pdf Traitor or Patriot?] Boghardt, Thomas. International Spy Museum. Retrieved May 1, 2015. On June 15, 2012, Powers was posthumously awarded the [[Silver Star]] medal for "demonstrating 'exceptional loyalty' while enduring harsh interrogation in the Lubyanka Prison in Moscow for almost two years."{{cite web |url=http://www.defense.gov/Advisories/Advisory.aspx?AdvisoryID=3450 |title=Press Advisory: Silver Star to be Posthumously Presented to Capt. Francis Gary Powers |publisher=Defense.gov |accessdate=August 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012185541/http://www.defense.gov//advisories/advisory.aspx?advisoryid=3450 |archivedate=October 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Air Force Chief of Staff General [[Norton Schwartz]] presented the decoration to Powers's grandchildren, Trey Powers, 9, and Lindsey Berry, 29, in a [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] ceremony.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2012/06/u-2-pilot-gary-powers-receives-silver-star/ |title=U-2 Pilot Gary Powers Receives Silver Star – ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=June 15, 2012 |accessdate=August 31, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/09/us/silver-star-award/index.html?hpt=hp_t1 |title=Cold War pilot Francis Gary Powers to get Silver Star |publisher=CNN.com |accessdate=August 31, 2012}} ==Legacy== {{Portal|Biography|United States Air Force}} Powers's son, Francis Gary Powers Jr., founded the [[Cold War Museum]] in 1996. Affiliated with the [[Smithsonian Institution]], it was essentially a traveling exhibit until it found a permanent home in 2011 on a former Army communications base outside [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, D.C]].{{cite web|url=http://www.coldwar.org |title=Cold War Museum |publisher=Coldwar.org |date= |accessdate=July 13, 2014}} ==In popular culture== *In the 1976 telemovie ''Francis Gary Powers: The True Story of the U-2 Spy Incident'', Powers was played by [[Lee Majors]]. *In 1999, the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] aired ''Mystery of the U2'', hosted by Arthur Kent as part of their History Undercover series. The program was produced by Indigo Films. *In the 2015 movie ''[[Bridge of Spies (film)|Bridge of Spies]]'', dramatizing the negotiations to repatriate Powers, he is portrayed by [[Austin Stowell]], with [[Tom Hanks]] starring as negotiator [[James Britt Donovan|James Donovan]].[https://variety.com/2014/film/news/tom-hanks-steven-spielberg-cold-war-thriller-set-for-oct-16-2015-1201221269/ "Tom Hanks-Steven Spielberg Cold War Thriller Set for Oct. 16, 2015"], ''Variety'', accessed June 5, 2014 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Notes== *Khrushchev, Sergei N. ''Nikita Khrushchev and the Creation of a Superpower''. State College, PA: Penn State Press, 2000. {{ISBN|978-0-271-01927-7}}. *Powers, Francis Gary with Gentry, Curt. ''Operation Overflight''. Hodder & Stoughton Ltd, 1971 (hard cover) {{ISBN|978-0-340-14823-5}}. Potomac Book, 2002 (paperback) {{ISBN|978-1-57488-422-7}}. *West, Nigel. ''Seven Spies Who Changed the World''. London: Secker & Warburg, 1992 (hard cover). London: Mandarin, 1992 (paperback). *''The Trial of the U2: Exclusive Authorized Account of the Court Proceedings of the Case of Francis Gary Powers, Heard before the Military Division of the Supreme Court of the U.S.S.R., Moscow, 17 August 18, 19, 1960''. Translation World Publishers, Chicago: 1960. * {{cite book|last1=Powers|first1=F.G.|last2=Gentry|first2=C.|title=Operation Overflight: A Memoir of the U-2 Incident|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DVktBAbEn_UC|year=2004|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|isbn=978-1-57488-422-7}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Pickett |first=William B. |authorlink=William B. Pickett |editor1-last= Clifford |editor1-first= J. Garry |editor2-last= Wilson |editor2-first= Theodore A. |title= Presidents, Diplomats, and Other Mortals: Essays Honoring Robert H. Ferrell |location=Columbia, Missouri |publisher=University of Missouri Press |date= 2007 |pages=137–153 |chapter=Eisenhower, Khrushchev, and the U-2 Affair: A Forty-six Year Retrospective |isbn=978-0-8262-1747-9}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Wikisourcelang|ru|Приговор по делу Гэри Пауэрса Военной коллегией Верховного суда СССР|Francis Gary Powers}} *[https://archive.is/20131215005438/http://www.foia.cia.gov/search-results?search_api_views_fulltext=Gary+Powers&field_collection= CIA FOIA documents on Gary Powers] *[http://vault.fbi.gov/Francis%20Gary%20Powers FBI Records: The Vault - Francis Gary Powers] *[http://eisenhower.archives.gov/research/online_documents/u2_incident.html Documents and Photographs regarding the U-2 Spy Plane Incident of 1960, Dwight D. Eisenhower Presidential Library] *[http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/Powers-N4TV.htm Check-Six.com ''The Francis Gary Powers Helo Crash''] *[http://www.oldgazette.ru/lib/pauers/index.html Transcripts of the Soviet court trial] {{ru icon}} (dead link—saved at the Internet Archive) *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/10/newsid_2731000/2731827.stm 1962 Russia frees US spy plane pilot] *[http://voicesunderberlin.com/Stamps3.html View images of the ''Francis Gary Powers U-2 Pilot'' Cinderella stamps on the artist's webSite.] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0074545/ IMDB page for the 1976 TV movie.] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Powers, Francis Gary}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:American people convicted of spying for the United States]] [[Category:American people imprisoned abroad]] [[Category:American people imprisoned in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:American prisoners of war]] [[Category:American spies against the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:Films about shot-down aviators]] [[Category:Milligan College alumni]] [[Category:People from Jenkins, Kentucky]] [[Category:People from Pound, Virginia]] [[Category:People of the Central Intelligence Agency]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Intelligence Star]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:United States Air Force officers]] [[Category:Victims of helicopter accidents or incidents in the United States]] [[Category:Inmates of Vladimir Central Prison]] [[Category:Lockheed Martin people]] [[Category:Military personnel from Virginia]] [[Category:Military personnel from Kentucky]]

The '''Global Conference on Cyberspace (GCCS)''' are conferences held biennially since 2011 where governments, private sector and civil society gather to discuss and promote practical cooperation in cyberspace, to enhance cyber capacity building, and to discuss norms for responsible behavior in cyberspace.<ref name="2015Location"/>
== History ==
=== First conference ===
The first conference held in November 2011 in [[London]]. There, a set of principles “for governing behavior in cyberspace” have been established after a discussion from 700 participants.
=== Second conference ===
The second conference held on October 4-5th, 2012 in [[Budapest]]. The main subject and focus that has been discussed was the relationship between internet rights and internet security. Even though very few civil society organisations were invited to speak, the networking was valuable, and had more longer term impact than the Chair’s statement which represents the outcome of the event.
=== Third conference ===
The third event held on 17–18 October 2013 in [[Seoul]]. The conference had grown to approximately 1,600 attendees with greater representation from countries in the global South. Arguably the most significant outcome of the London Process is the Seoul Framework for and Commitment to Open and Secure Cyberspace, which highlights the importance of universal internet access, emphasizes that the same rights that people have offline must also be protected online, and echoes a [[UN]] report that established that international law is applicable online and is essential to maintaining peace and stability and promoting an open, secure, peaceful and accessible ICT environment. <ref name="history" />
=== Fourth conference ===
The fourth GCCS conference held at the [[World Forum (The Hague)|World Forum]] from 16 to 17 April 2015 in [[The Hague]].<ref name="2015Location" />
=== Fifth conference ===
The fifth GCCS conference held from 23 to 24 November 2017 in New Delhi, India.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.internetsociety.org/events/gccs-2017/ |title=Cyber4All: A Secure and Inclusive Cyberspace for Sustainable Development|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref> Theme of GCCS 2017 is “Cyber4All: A Secure and Inclusive Cyberspace for Sustainable Development”. However it could further be divided into following four sections: Cyber4Growth – share ideas and insights to foster growth and development with growing importance of the cyber space to individuals, small businesses, large companies etc. Cyber4DigitalInclusion –draw road map for inclusive . society by sharing best practices for digital identity, idea of open and free Internet for all, digital technologies for enabling differently abled etc. Cyber4Security –framework for comprehensive cyber. security protocols for organisations and nations.
Cyber4Diplomacy –explore various facets of cyber security . such as interstate cooperation for preventing Cyber Warfare and Cyber Diplomacy for Global Order.
== References == <references> <ref name="2015Location">{{cite web|url=https://www.gccs2015.com/gccs/all-about-gccs2015|title=About the Global Conference on CyberSpace 2015|accessdate={{date|2015-06-28|mdy}}}}</ref> <ref name="history">{{cite web|url=https://www.apc.org/en/news/what-global-conference-cyberspace-faqs-gccs-hague|title="What is the Global Conference on Cyberspace?" FAQs on the GCCS, The Hague, 16-17 April 2015|accessdate={{date|2015-06-28|mdy}}}}</ref> <ref name="2015Location">{{cite web|url=https://www.gccs2015.com/gccs/all-about-gccs2015|title=About the Global Conference on CyberSpace 2015|accessdate={{date|2015-06-28|mdy}}}}</ref> </references>
