{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Multiple issues| {{expert-subject|date=August 2010}} {{cleanup-rewrite|date=January 2009}} {{update|date=May 2009}} }} The '''[[Great Recession]] in Russia''' was a crisis during 2008–2009 in the [[Russia]]n financial markets as well as an economic recession that was compounded by political fears after the [[2008 South Ossetian war|war with Georgia]] and by the plummeting price of Urals heavy [[Price of petroleum|crude oil]], which lost more than 70% of its value since its record peak of US$147 on 4 July 2008 before rebounding moderately in 2009. According to the [[World Bank]], Russia’s strong short-term [[macroeconomic]] fundamentals made it better prepared than many [[emerging economies]] to deal with the crisis, but its underlying structural weaknesses and high dependence on the price of a single commodity made its impact more pronounced than would otherwise be the case.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTRUSSIANFEDERATION/Resources/rer17_eng.pdf | title = Russian economic report | number = 171 | publisher = [[World Bank]] | accessdate = 12 August 2008}}.</ref>
In late 2008 during the onset of the crisis, Russian markets plummeted and more than $1 trillion had been wiped off the value of Russia's shares,<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-CreditCrisis/idUSTRE4AC5M020081113 |agency = Reuters | title= Russian stocks shed over trillion in crisis | date= 13 November 2008| accessdate = 28 November 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090109212019/https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-CreditCrisis/idUSTRE4AC5M020081113 | archivedate = 9 January 2009| deadurl= no}}</ref> although Russian stocks rebounded in 2009 becoming the world’s best performers, with the [[MICEX Index]] having more than doubled in value and regaining half its 2008 losses.<ref>{{Citation | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aR48z1j0bBrU | title = Russian Stocks Cut to ‘Neutral’ at JPMorgan on Commodity Risks | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | accessdate = 16 December 2009}}.</ref>
As the crisis progressed, [[Reuters]] and the [[Financial Times]] speculated that the crisis would be used to increase the Kremlin's control over key strategic assets in a reverse of the "loans for shares" sales of the 1990s, when the state sold off major assets to the [[business oligarch|oligarch]]s in return for loans.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/bondsNews/idUSLA60378720081013 |agency=Reuters |title=Kremlin holds key as crisis threatens oligarchs |date=13 October 2008 |accessdate=29 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218191443/https://www.reuters.com/article/bondsNews/idUSLA60378720081013 |archivedate=18 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In contrast to this earlier speculation, in September 2009 the Russian government announced plans to sell state energy and transport holdings in order to help plug the [[Federal budget of Russia|budget deficit]] and to help improve the nation's aging infrastructure. The state [[Earmark (politics)|earmarked]] about 5,500 enterprises for [[divestment]] and plans to sell shares in companies that are already publicly traded, including [[Rosneft]], the country’s biggest oil producer.<ref>{{Citation | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=agAUNSXARKTk | title = Russia’s Planned State Asset Sales to Outshine Pee | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | accessdate = 16 December 2009}}.</ref>
From July 2008 – January 2009, Russia's [[foreign exchange reserves]] (FXR) fell by $210 billion from their peak to $386 billion as the central bank adopted a policy of gradual devaluation to combat the sharp devaluation of the [[Russian ruble|ruble]]. The ruble weakened 35% against the dollar from the onset of the crisis in August to January 2009.<ref>{{Citation | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aPzxsrEg7GUc | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |title=Ruble Gain Versus Dollar ‘Inevitable,’ Zadornov Says| accessdate = 16 December 2009}}.</ref> As the ruble stabilized in January the reserves began to steadily grow again throughout 2009, reaching a year-long high of $452 billion by year's-end.<ref>[http://www.easybourse.com/bourse-actualite/accor/press-release-fitch-downgrades-russia-to-bbb-FR0000120404-609688 Fitch Downgrades Russia To BBB] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130121204915/http://www.easybourse.com/bourse-actualite/accor/press-release-fitch-downgrades-russia-to-bbb-FR0000120404-609688 |date=21 January 2013 }}, Dow Jones (via Easy Bourse), 4 February 2009.</ref><ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/quote?ticker=RUREFEG:IND Russian foreign reserves] [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref>
Russia's economy emerged from recession in the third quarter of 2009 after two quarters of record negative growth.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aon.9KAC7AMw Russian Economy Exited Recession in Third Quarter ] [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref> GDP contracted by 7.9% for the whole of 2009,<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aG9CimQa7sKc Russia Suffered Record Economic Contraction in 2009] [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] Retrieved on 1 February 2009</ref> slightly less than the economic ministry's prediction of 8.5%.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/business/20091216/157255443.html Russia's economy to reach pre-crisis level by late 2012] [[RIA Novosti]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref> Experts expect Russia's economy will grow modestly in 2010, with estimates ranging from 3.1% by the Russian economic ministry<ref>[http://businessneweurope.eu/story1919/RUSSIA_2010_Slow_build_over_first_half_to_boom_in_2011 RUSSIA 2010: Slow build over first half to boom in 2011] Business News Europe. Retrieved 21 January 2010</ref> to 2.5%, 3.6% and 4.9% by the [[World Bank]], [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF), and [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) respectively.<ref>[http://www.imf.org/external/country/RUS/index.htm Russian Federation and the IMF] [[International Monetary Fund]] Retrieved on 3 February 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.worldbank.org/globaloutlook.html World Bank Economic Outlook] [[World Bank]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.oecd.org/document/18/0,2340,en_2649_33733_20347538_1_1_1_1,00.html OECD Economic Outlook No. 86, November 2009] [[OECD]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref>
==Background== Russia is a major exporter of commodities such as oil and metals, so its economy had been hit hard<ref name=badnews>{{Citation | url = http://www.stratfor.com/memberships/124716/analysis/20081003_global_market_brief_implications_russias_declining_oil_production | title = The Implications of Russia's Declining Oil Production | publisher = [[Stratfor]] | date = 3 October 2008}}.</ref> by the decline in the price of many commodities. The Russian stock market declined significantly. Foreign investors had pulled billions of dollars out of Russia on concerns over escalating geopolitical tensions with the West following the military conflict between Georgia and Russia,<ref>{{Citation | url = http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080817/116091756.html | title = South Ossetia conflict wipes $7bln off Russian market – Kudrin | publisher = [[RIA Novosti]] | place = [[Russia|RU]] | date = 17 August 2008}}.</ref> as well as concerns about state interference in the economy.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://money.cnn.com/2008/09/04/news/international/powell_KGB.fortune/ |publisher=CNN | first=Bill | last=Powell | title=How the KGB (and friends) took over Russia's economy | date=9 September 2008| accessdate= 12 October 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081013184508/http://money.cnn.com/2008/09/04/news/international/powell_KGB.fortune/| archivedate= 13 October 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref> Those concerns were underscored in July by Prime Minister [[Vladimir Putin]]'s criticism of steel company [[Mechel]] collapsing the company's stock.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.russiaprofile.org/page.php?pageid=Business&articleid=a1218030204 | title = No Time to Panic | first = Sergi | last = Balashov | publisher = Russia profile | date = 6 August 2008}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.theotherrussia.org/2008/07/29/putin-and-russias-collapsing-stock-market/ | title = Putin and Russia’s Collapsing Stock Market | first = Yulia | last = Latynina | author-link = Yulia Latynina | publisher = The other Russia | date = 29 July 2008}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = https://www.forbes.com/feeds/afx/2008/09/22/afx5454115.html | title = Russia's Medvedev gives boost to Mechel's owner | newspaper = [[Forbes]] | date = 22 September 2008}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.robertamsterdam.com/2008/07/understanding_the_attack_on_me.htm | title = Understanding the Attack on Mechel | first = Robert | last = Amsterdam | author-link = Robert Amsterdam | date = 29 July 2008}}.</ref> By September 2008, the RTS stock index plunged almost 54%, making it one of the worst performing markets in the world.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/financial-turmoil-accelerates-russia/story.aspx?guid=%7BAD559BFE%2D5E6C%2D4033%2D87C6%2D36EA9D4DFA18%7D | title = Financial turmoil accelerates in Russia | newspaper = MarketWatch | date = 17 September 2008}}.</ref> Russian involvement in the US [[subprime mortgage crisis]] contributed to the volatility in Russia's financial system. The [[Central Bank of Russia|Russian Central Bank]] owned US$100 Billion of [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]] of the two American mortgage giants [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]] that were [[Federal takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac|taken over by the US government]]. This investment appeared to be bound for write-off.<ref>{{cite news |first= Julian |last= Delasantellis |title= Paulson placates China, Russia – for now | url = http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Global_Economy/JI10Dj03.html |work=[[Asia Times Online]] |date= 9 September 2008|accessdate=17 September 2008}}</ref>
Many analysts, including [[Andrei Illarionov]], former economic policy adviser to then-President Vladimir Putin, claim that in Russia the crisis in the stock market was deepened dramatically by internal factors, including concerns over state interference in the economy fueled in June by Putin's criticism of [[Mechel]] and the conflict over [[TNK-BP]], lack of transparency in banking and political risks associated with escalating geopolitical tensions following the [[2008 South Ossetia war]] in August.<ref name ="illarionov">{{Citation | first = Andrei | last = Illarionov | url = http://www.themoscowtimes.com/article/1016/42/371419.htm | title = Fighting Financial Fires With Blini | newspaper = [[The Moscow Times]] | date = 3 October 2008}}.</ref> [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Swedish Foreign minister]] [[Carl Bildt]] said on 17 September that the current Russian financial crisis is "obviously more worrying" than the ongoing [[subprime mortgage crisis]] in view of the political development in Russia.<ref>{{Citation | language = sv | url = http://di.se/Avdelningar/Artikel.aspx?stat=0&ArticleID=2008%5c09%5c17%5c301279&SectionId=Ettan&menusection=Startsidan;Huvudnyheter | title = Carl Bildt bloggar om krisen |trans-title=Carl Bildt blogs about crisis | newspaper = Dagens industri | date = 17 September 2008}}.</ref> Furthermore, Russia's overt reliance on the oil and natural gas sector made it particularly vulnerable.
According to the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' and [[Gazeta.ru]], as the Russian market declined in September, a conspiracy theory circulated within Russian leadership that the U.S. government had incited American investors to withdraw their capital from Russia, in punishment for the war in Georgia.<ref name="white">{{Citation | first = Gregory L | last = White | title = Russian Rescue Package Expands to $120 Billion | newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date = 19 September 2008}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | first = Дмитрий | last = Бутрин | url= http://www.gazeta.ru/column/butrin/2844738.shtml | script-title=ru:Плесень конспирологии | newspaper = [[Gazeta.ru]] | date = 29 September 2008 | language = ru}}.</ref>
==Financial markets== [[Image:RusFinCris.PNG|right|thumb|450px|Major Russian stock market [[RTS Index]] with [[S&P 500]] and Oil Spot Prices. All data are in percentages to 1 May 2008 values. '''A''' – [[Vladimir Putin]] criticises [[Mechel]]; '''B''' – [[2008 South Ossetia war]] starts; '''C''' – [[International recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia|Recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia by Russia]]; '''D''' – [[Alexei Kudrin]] "no systematic crisis" speech; '''E''' – measures to save major banks are adopted by the Russian government; '''F''' – [[Global financial crisis of September–October 2008]]; '''G''' – President [[Dmitri Medvedev]] announced additional bailout financing]]
===Stock markets===
On 24 July 2008, [[Mechel]]'s stock plunged by almost 38 percent after Russia's Prime Minister [[Vladimir Putin]] criticized its CEO [[Igor Zyuzin]], and accused the company of selling resources to Russia at higher prices than those charged to foreign countries. The comments, which raised fears of another attack similar to that made on [[Yukos]] in 2004, contrasted sharply with previous efforts by President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] to improve Russia's reputation as an investor-friendly country.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news | title= Putin’s Criticism Puts a $6 Billion Hole in a Company | url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/26/business/worldbusiness/26steel.html | last= Kramer | first= Andrew E | date= 26 July 2008 |work=New York Times | accessdate=10 August 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090417073428/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/26/business/worldbusiness/26steel.html| archivedate=17 April 2009<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On the following day, Mechel issued a contrite statement promising full cooperation with federal authorities,<ref name=NYT/> while share values rebounded by nearly 15 percent. 28 July presidential aide [[Arkady Dvorkovich]] then sought to restore calm, declaring that all parties would "act in a civilized way," and confirming that Mechel was cooperating with antitrust authorities.<ref>{{cite news | title= Putin blasts steel firm Mechel for tax evasion | url= http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9273QLO0.htm | last= Stewart | first= Catrina | date= 28 July 2008 | publisher=[[BusinessWeek]] | accessdate=10 August 2008 }}</ref> Just hours later, however, Putin announced that Mechel had been avoiding taxes, by using foreign subsidiaries to sell its products internationally. His renewed attack caused share prices to tumble once more—this time by almost 33 percent.<ref>{{cite news | title= Fresh criticism by Putin sends Mechel shares tumbling again | url= http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/fresh-criticism-putin-sends-mechel/story.aspx?guid=%7B8C4B2044-12EA-4F2A-A20B-5E640B836CA2%7D&dist=msr_9 | last= Lesova | first= Polya | date= 28 July 2008 | publisher=[[MarketWatch]] | accessdate=10 August 2008 }}</ref>
On 16 September Russia's most liquid stock exchange [[MICEX]] and the dollar-denominated [[Russian Trading System|RTS]] were suspended trade for one hour after the worst one-day fall in 10 years as Finance Minister [[Alexei Kudrin]] reassured markets there was no "systemic" crisis.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssFinancialServicesAndRealEstateNews/idUSLG65392720080916 |agency=Reuters |title=UPDATE 1-Russian stocks suspended in worst plunge since 1998 |date=16 September 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919162420/https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssFinancialServicesAndRealEstateNews/idUSLG65392720080916 |archivedate=19 September 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Next day, trading was suspended for the second day in succession on Russia's two main stock exchanges (MICEX and RTS) after shares fell dramatically, forcing the [[Federal Financial Markets Service]] to intervene.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/markets/article4772350.ece | location=London | work=The Times | first=Tony | last=Halpin | title=Russian markets suspended again after shares plummet | date=17 September 2008| accessdate= 12 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080923190104/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/markets/article4772350.ece| archivedate= 23 September 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=arNaiuHTXLbs&refer=europe Russian Exchanges Halt Trading for Second Day; VTB Declines], Bloomberg, 17 September 2008.</ref> The [[#Money markets|simultaneous collapse of money markets]] prompted reaction from the government and the Central Bank, while Finance Minister [[Alexey Kudrin]] sought assurances from U.S. Treasury Secretary [[Henry Paulson]] that the U.S. did not play politics with Russia in the crisis.<ref name="white"/>
The crisis continued on 18 September, as trading was suspended for the third day in succession on Russia's two main stock exchanges amidst fear of financial collapse. News agencies are quoting Russia's finance minister [[Alexei Kudrin]] as saying trading on Russian exchanges will not resume until 19 September 2008.<ref>{{cite news|first=Polya |last=Lesova |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/russian-stock-markets-remain-hold/story.aspx?guid={8901F86A-FF6D-4658-BC1C-4D926CA478BF}&dist=msr_5=MarketWatch |title=Russia moves to stem crisis; stock markets closed |location=NEW YORK |publisher=MarketWatch |date=18 September 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2009}}</ref> Officials at [[MICEX]] stock exchange describe conditions in the Russian markets as "extraordinary"<ref name="timesonline1">{{cite news|last=Halpin |first=Tony |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article4780314.ece |title=Russia floods markets with cash in shutdown |work=The Times |location=UK |date=18 September 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2009}}</ref> Deputy [[Finance Minister]] Pyotr Kazakevich asserted that "Russia is facing its worst stock market decline in a decade mainly because of a confidence crisis rather than liquidity problems".<ref>{{cite news|first=Irem |last=Koker |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/english/finance/9930871.asp?scr=1 |title=Russia heightens fears crisis spreading into emerging markets |publisher=Hurriyet DailyNews.com |accessdate=4 January 2009}}</ref>
On 6 October the [[MICEX]] and [[Russian Trading System|RTS]] crashed by 18.6% and 19.1% respectively. The losses forced the [[Federal Financial Markets Service]] to suspend the stocks three times. The decreases in other world markets on that day were considerable, but less dramatic than in Russia.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/business/20081006/117483204.html Panic as Russian stock market falls by almost 20%]. ''[[RIA Novosti]]'', 6 October 2008.</ref> Trading on both exchanges was suspended on the next day; Russian companies have augmented in price at London [[London Stock Exchange|LSE]].<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://top.rbc.ru/economics/07/10/2008/251100.shtml Russian stocks have risen in price at LSE]</ref> On 8 October the MICEX and RTS plunged 14.4% and 11.3% respectively, trading on the markets was halted until 10 October, respectively.<ref>Polya Lesova. [http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/russian-stocks-plunge-again-trading/story.aspx?guid=%7B648BD3E7-9B66-4E79-9413-16530266BC32%7D Russian stocks plunge again, trading suspended]. ''[[Marketwatch]]'', 8 October 2008.</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7658656.stm |work=BBC News | title=Falls force Russian markets close | date=8 October 2008| accessdate= 12 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081011060847/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7658656.stm| archivedate= 11 October 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, on 9 October MICEX trading resumed ahead of schedule, and the stock market rose 14.7%.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://newsru.com/finance/09oct2008/stocks.html Индексы на российских биржах растут. ММВБ дважды приостанавливала торги.]</ref> On the next day the regulator, wary of crises in American and Asian markets, decided not to open trading at all.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://newsru.com/finance/10oct2008/torgi.html]</ref>
===Money markets===
The crisis in [[money market]]s was imminent since spring, when [[Central Bank of Russia]] warned the public of a gradual contraction in bank lending due to unfolding world liquidity crisis. However, the regulator preferred to combat inflation, raising the [[refinancing rate]] and [[Bank reserves|bank reserve contributions]]. 1 September hike in reserve rate alone withdrew nearly 100 billion roubles from the money market.<ref name=RUB>{{cite news | title=Russia’s Banking Crisis | url=http://eng.expert.ru/printissues/expert/2008/38/vtoroe_dno_besplatno/ | author=Maxim Rubchenko | publisher=Expert Online |date=29 September 2008 |accessdate=17 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081201073046/http://eng.expert.ru/printissues/expert/2008/38/vtoroe_dno_besplatno/| archivedate= 1 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The raise coincided with a seasonal peak in tax payments and left the banking system in a worse state of liquidity than that of August 1998.<ref name=RUB/> A subsequent drop in rouble-to-dollar exchange rate and dollar-denominated prices of Russian corporate securities forced investors to [[Crowding out (economics)|crowd out]], worsening the [[positive feedback]] loop. The interbank [[money market]] that traditionally relied on Russian corporate stock as a [[Collateral (finance)|collateral]] for the [[repurchase agreement]]s, immediately imploded in what was called "a crisis of trust" or even "elimination of trust":<ref name=ASP>{{ cite news | title=Russia’s Top Economist Needs to Face Reality | url=http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=27448 | publisher=Saint Peterburg Times|date=24 October 2008 | author=[[Anders Åslund]] |accessdate=17 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081025234421/http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=27448| archivedate= 25 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> when the borrowers defaulted on loans, leaving lenders with impaired collateral, other banks stopped lending as a precaution.<ref name=RUB/>
Money market crunch passed its first lowest mark 15–17 September. 17 September the government lent the country's three biggest banks, [[Sberbank]], [[VTB Bank]] and [[Gazprombank]], 1.13 trillion [[Russian ruble|rubles]] (US$44 billion) for at least three months to boost [[Market liquidity|liquidity]];<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=a1sZsKZ32kvU&refer=europe Russian Exchanges Halt Trading for Second Day; VTB Declines], Bloomberg, 17 September 2008.</ref> the Central Bank lowered the [[reserve requirement]].<ref>[http://www.cbr.ru/pw.aspx?file=/press/if/080917_1833473.htm Press Release of the Central Bank] (in Russian)</ref> This was followed 24 September by Central Bank loans to keep the current accounts afloat and prevent a [[bank run]]. The regulators also raised the cap for [[deposit insurance]] from 400 to 700 thousand roubles (equivalent to 25 thousand dollars).<ref name=R2B>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssBanks/idUSLK1655220081120 | title=Two more Russian banks lose licences |agency=Reuters |date=20 November 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008}}</ref> These actions served their short-term purpose but failed to revitalize the money market: no bank was willing to lend for longer than overnight.<ref name=RUB/>
17 November [[MosPrime]] interbank interest rate on rouble loans reached a record high of 22.67%, indicating another shortage of liquid funds as the bank clients transferred funds overseas or paid taxes due. Rates on six-month US dollar [[forward contract]]s fluctuated at 40–60%, short-term [[currency swap]]s averaged around 80% as the banks anticipated further drop in exchange rates.<ref name=K1811>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1072889 | title= Banki doplachivayut za budushy dollar (Банки доплачивают за будущий доллар)|publisher=[[Kommersant]] |date=18 November 2008|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2008}}</ref>
===Bank failures===
On 15 September the [[KIT Finance]] brokerage failed to pay off its debt, signalling problems in Russia's financial sector.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/marketsNews/idUSLG19029320080916 |agency=Reuters | first=Gleb | last=Bryanski | title=Russian brokerage says fails to meet some obligations | date=16 September 2008| accessdate= 12 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>Polya Lesova. [http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/moodys-cuts-ratings-russian-bank/story.aspx?guid=%7BC4983CCB-5E39-4A71-BB08-80C4009C0D58%7D Moody's cuts the ratings of Russian bank KIT Finance]. ''[[Marketwatch]]'', 17 September 2008.</ref> On 8 October the [[Russian Railways]] and [[Alrosa]] agreed to acquire a 90% stake in KIT Finance.
In the beginning of October [[Sergei Mikhailovich Ignatyev|Sergei Ignatyev]], chairman of the Central Bank, announced imminent bankruptcy of 50 to 70 banks.<ref name=ASP/> Actually, in late August – late November the regulator has shut down only nine banks.<ref name=R2B/> More smaller banks showing signs of distress are allowed to operate, like the [[Moscow Mortgage Bank]] that defaulted on returning individual deposits in November.<ref>{{ cite news | url = http://www.echo.msk.ru/news/554018-echo.html | title=Moskovsky zalogovy bank otkazyvayet klientam (Московский залоговый банк отказывает клиентам в выдаче депозитов) | publisher=[[Echo of Moscow]] |date=18 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=18 November 2008 }}</ref> Regional banks, heavily dependent on individual deposits, were in particular hit. A [[bank run]] registered in [[Bashkortostan]] in November caused local crises. Three of the four worst affected banks were promised rescue by their shareholders or third-party buyers; fate of the fourth one is yet{{when|date=July 2014}} to be decided.<ref name=K2211>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1077346 | title= Bashkirskie banki popali pod sanatsiyu (Башкирские банки попали под санацию)|publisher=[[Kommersant]] |date=22 November 2008|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2008}}</ref>
==Government intervention==
===Refinancing foreign capital=== [[File:Politicians of Russia 18 September 2008-1.jpg|thumb|[[Sergei Mikhailovich Ignatyev|Sergei Ignatyev]] (Chairman of the [[Central Bank of Russia]]), [[German Gref]] (Chairman and CEO of [[Sberbank]]) and [[Andrey Kostin]] (Chairman and CEO of [[Vneshtorgbank]]) at a meeting convened by [[President of Russia]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] dealing with [[Economy of Russia|economic issues in Russia]] on 18 September 2008.]] On 18 September, [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] ordered ministers to inject 500 billion [[Russian rouble|roubles]] of funds from the [[Federal budget of Russia|state budget]] into the markets and pledged that the financial system would receive "all necessary support".<ref name="timesonline1"/> On 7 October, Medvedev announced an additional $36 billion for banks on top of the $150 billion approved in September.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=a16BnNfBwIkw&refer=home|title=Russia Providing $200 Billion for Banks, Builders|publisher=[[Bloomberg LP]]|last=Mauldin|first=William|date=7 October 2008|accessdate=12 October 2008}}</ref>
On 29 September, [[Vladimir Putin]] announced a government policy aimed at refinancing Russian corporations that previously relied on foreign loans. Government authorized [[Vnesheconombank]] as its principal agent in distributing state loans to these corporations, amounting initially up to 50 billion US dollars, or 8% of Russia's foreign currency assets. At the same time Putin recommended the Central Bank to extend [[unsecured loan|unsecured]] stabilization loans to Russian banks,<ref name=K30>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1033709/VEB_nonresident_debt_redemption/| title=VEB to Guarantee Redemption of All Corporate Debt by Year-End | publisher=[[Kommersant]] |date=30 September 2008 | accessdate=17 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081010115919/http://www.kommersant.com/p1033709/VEB_nonresident_debt_redemption/| archivedate= 10 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> which was duly implemented.<ref name=K1811/> The policy was immediately dubbed "soft re-[[nationalisation]]" and criticized for selective picking of "eligible" borrowers.<ref name=ASP/> The 50 billion installment covers only the current portion of 477 billion US dollars owed by Russian corporations to foreign lenders; total assets of the government and the Central Bank combined are estimated at 550 billion US dollars.<ref name=K30/>
On 23 October, [[Standard & Poor's]] changed the long-term outlook on the sovereign credit ratings of Russia from stable to negative, warning of the costs of bailing out troubled banks and a rising risk of a budget deficit in 2009. It also lowered Russia's Transfer and Convertibility (T&C) assessment to [[Bond credit rating|BBB+]] from [[Bond credit rating|A-]]. At the same time, the 'BBB+' long-term foreign currency, the 'A-' long-term local currency ratings and the short-term ratings of [[Bond credit rating|A-2]] were affirmed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lse.co.uk/MacroEconomicNews.asp?ArticleCode=49l823n6gf5uvqg |title=TEXT-S&P release on Russian Federation |agency=Reuters |work=Macroeconomic News |publisher=London South East |date=23 October 2008 |accessdate=4 January 2009}}</ref>
By 13 November, Russian government spending to quench the recession reached 222 billion US dollars, or 13.9% of its GDP;<ref>{{cite news|title=Russia Has Spent $222 Billion on Crisis|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p-13561/world_financial_crisis_intervention/|publisher=Kommersant |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=15 November 2008}}</ref> in November the state was spending its reserves at an average 22 billion dollars a week.<ref name=R21/>
On 8 December 2008, [[Standard & Poor's]] additionally lowered Russia's foreign currency credit ratings to [[Bond credit rating|BBB]] (long term) and [[Bond credit rating|A-3]]. It also lowered Russia's Transfer and Convertibility (T&C) assessment to [[Bond credit rating|BBB]] and the long-term local currency assessment to [[Bond credit rating|BBB+]]. On the other hand, the short-term credit rating in local currency was left intact as A-2. The lowering of credit ratings was caused by the sharp decline of reserves and investment flow.<ref>[http://www.standardandpoors.ru/article.php?pubid=4745&sec=pr Долгосрочный кредитный рейтинг Российской Федерации по обязательствам в иностранной валюте понижен до «ВВВ» вследствие рисков, связанных с оттоком капитала; прогноз – «Негативный»] [[Standard & Poor's]] 8 December 2008 {{ru icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSL88820020081208 | title=Russia gets first rating downgrade in 10 yrs |agency=Reuters , 8 December 2008 | accessdate=9 December 2008 | date=8 December 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090109221004/https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSL88820020081208| archivedate= 9 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Standard & Poor's also launched a downward revision of Russian municipal and corporate bond ratings.<ref>{{ cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1091360 | title=Reiting truba (Рейтинг – труба) | publisher=[[Kommersant]], 9 December 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=8 December 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081210000915/http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1091360| archivedate= 10 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Tax and state budget policy=== {{see also|Federal budget of Russia}} 20 November [[Vladimir Putin]] announced government package of tax reforms. Corporate profit tax rate (24% in 2008) is to be reduced to 20%.<ref name=R20>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-Russia/idUSTRE4AJ57P20081120|title=Crisis will not sink Russian economy: Putin|agency=Reuters |date=20 November 2008 |accessdate=20 November 2008}}</ref> Profit tax base will decrease for companies investing in capital assets as the immediately recoverable depreciation allowance is raised from 10% to 30% of the asset cost. There will be no change in [[value added tax]] rates (maximum 18%) in 2009, but the government considered changing VAT accrual rules in favor of the taxpayers. Minister of finance [[Alexey Kudrin]], who resisted tax breaks until September,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-Russia/idUSLH37815520080918|title=Russia boosts markets support, shares up in London|accessdate=20 November 2008 |agency=Reuters |date=18 September 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081219120216/https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-Russia/idUSLH37815520080918| archivedate= 19 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> concurred with Putin's proposal, estimating that they will save the businesses around 500 billion roubles annually.<ref name=GA20>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/financial/2008/11/20/2889490.shtml|title=Dobro ot krizisa (Добро от кризиса)|publisher=gazeta.ru |date=20 November 2008|language=Russian|accessdate=20 November 2008}}</ref>
Earlier in November, Kudrin announced that the state has accepted the fact of a long-term drop in oil prices and that the existing [[Federal budget of Russia|state budget plans]] will hold unchanged if the oil prices stabilize on 50 dollars per barrel mark.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russia’s Finance Minister Declared Oil Price|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1056193/r_500/Oil_budget_Kudrin/|publisher=Kommersant |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=15 November 2008}}</ref> Even with tax breaks effective, Kudrin estimated that the 2009 state budget will break even or, in worst case, bear no more than 1% deficit.<ref name=R20/><ref name=GA20/> The deficit will be covered by Stabilisation Fund, without resorting to borrowing.<ref name=R20/>
In December the government lifted import tariffs on industrial equipment imported by metallurgy, construction, forestry and textile industry,<ref>{{cite news|title=Gov’t Lifts Industrial Equipment Duties |url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1089030/customs_and_duties/ |publisher=Kommersant, 5 December 2008 |accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref> at the same time enforcing increased tariffs on imported cars.
On 15 April 2009, Finance Minister [[Alexei Kudrin]] said the federal budget will show a deficit of 7.4% of GDP in 2009. In comparison, the US expects a budget deficit of 13.5% of GDP, Britain 9.3%, and France 6.6%. According to Kudrin forecast for the 2010 deficit is 5%. Kudrin warned, that Russia must cut down its budget deficit before 2011. "Our vulnerability to the crisis is higher than that of the countries with more diversified economies. This is why 2009 should be a unique year. We must not have a comparable budget deficit in subsequent years. We must work to reduce it to 3% in 2011," he said.<ref name="budget_deficit">{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20090415/121134126.html |title=Russia reviews forecast for its budget deficit |date=15 April 2009 |publisher=[[RIA Novosti]] |accessdate=25 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hFCtOV0u?url=http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20090415/121134126.html |archivedate=3 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 25 May 2009, President Dmitry Medvedev said the budget deficit in 2009 will be "at least 7%" of GDP.<ref name="deficit_may">{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090525/155082858.html |title=Russia's budget deficit to hit 7% of GDP in 2009 |date=25 May 2009 |publisher=[[RIA Novost]] |accessdate=25 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hFCtlyXn?url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090525/155082858.html |archivedate=3 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Corporate governance=== [[Federal Financial Monitoring Service]] of Russia, the agency in charge of domestic stock markets and [[corporate governance]], pressed the corporations to reveal their true owners and signed an agreement with the government of [[Cyprus]] (20 November) that may enable inter-government disclosure of ownership records. Cyprus is, nominally, the number one investor in Russia; 99% of [[Russian Trading System|RTS]] stock trades are arranged between foreign shareholders.<ref name=K20>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1075465/r_529/offshore_taxation_financial_regulation/| title=Capital Discypriotization | publisher=[[Kommersant]] |date=20 November 2008 | accessdate=20 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081205050211/http://www.kommersant.com/p1075465/r_529/offshore_taxation_financial_regulation/| archivedate= 5 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===International cooperation===
Russia has agreed to co-finance [[International Monetary Fund]] emergency loans to other states, initially contributing one billion US dollar.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kudrin Names the Price of the G20|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1072612/r_528/world_financial_crisis_G20_summit/|publisher=Kommersant |date=18 November 2008 |accessdate=18 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081203014453/http://www.kommersant.com/p1072612/r_528/world_financial_crisis_G20_summit/| archivedate= 3 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Earlier, in October, Russian ambassador to [[Iceland]] announces that Iceland will receive a €4 billion loan from Russia to mitigate the [[2008–2012 Icelandic financial crisis]]. The loan will be given across three or four years, and the interest rates will be 30 to 50 points above [[London Interbank Offered Rate|LIBOR]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Russia Grants Iceland Giant Loan in Euros |publisher=IcelandReview |accessdate=11 October 2008 |url=http://www.icelandreview.com/icelandreview/daily_news/?cat_id=28304&ew_0_a_id=313200}}</ref> Prime minister [[Geir Haarde]] had been investigating the possibility of a loan provided by Russia since the mid-summer.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ísland fær risalán frá Rússlandi |publisher=RÚV |accessdate=11 October 2008 |url=http://ruv.is/heim/frettir/frett/store64/item229999/| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081010123149/http://ruv.is/heim/frettir/frett/store64/item229999/| archivedate= 10 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= yes}}</ref><ref>[http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1869 The Foreign Exchange Reserves of the Central Bank of Iceland bolstered] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429011058/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1869 |date=29 April 2011 }}, [[Central Bank of Iceland]], 7 October 2008.</ref> Iceland's Central bank Governor [[Davíð Oddsson]] later clarified that the loan was still being negotiated.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aV.chNI42D8o&refer=home|title=Iceland Seeks Loan From Russia, Pegs Currency|last=Brogger|first=Tasneem|publisher=[[Bloomberg LP]]|date=7 October 2008|accessdate=12 October 2008}}</ref>
==Russian economic crisis== At the end of November 2008, The Russian economy as a whole was not in a state of recession. The government forecast for 2009 stood at a 6.7% annual growth rate while a November 2008 [[World Bank]] report projected 3% growth for 2009,<ref name=R21>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/reutersEdge/idUSTRE4AK4L620081121 | title=Russia acknowledges financial crisis has hit hard |agency=Reuters |date=21 November 2008 | accessdate=22 November 2008 }}</ref> However, a revised projection issued 30 March 2009 by the World Bank projects a 4.5% decrease for 2009 with unemployment projected to rise to 12% by the end of 2009. The World Bank report expressed concern about the condition of the poor and recommended increases in social support payments such as unemployment payments and child support payments. The report projected a slight rise in the average price of oil during 2010, up to $53 a barrel from the projected average of $45 for 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/31/world/europe/31russia.html | work=The New York Times | first=Ellen | last=Barry | title=World Bank Sees Slump in Russia Worsening | date=31 March 2009| accessdate= 30 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090401225415/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/31/world/europe/31russia.html| archivedate= 1 April 2009| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In the middle of December 2008 Russian officials confirmed that possibility of a recession was inevitable. "Russia is headed for a recession", the country's deputy economy minister, [[Andrei Klepach]], has said. Asked whether Russia would have a recession, he said: "It's started already. I'm afraid it will not be over in the next two quarters. ... A major drop began in October and there will also be drops in November–December," he said, according to official reports. Recessions are normally declared after two quarters of negative growth. He also said that full-year economic growth for 2008 would be lower than the 6.8% previously forecast.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7779132.stm |work=BBC News | title=Russia confirms recession to come | date=12 December 2008| accessdate= 13 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081212181247/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7779132.stm| archivedate= 12 December 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Steel industry===
Russian steel industry is dependent on foreign markets and domestic construction and automobile industries. Crisis in the industry was first publicly reported in the end of September – early October. [[Magnitogorsk Iron and Steel Works]] laid off 3,000 workers (10% of its Urals staff) and reduced output by 15% on 7 October,<ref>{{cite news | title=Iron Industry Reduces Output | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1037442/MMK_production_decline/ | publisher=Kommersant|date=8 October 2008 | accessdate=15 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081017091354/http://www.kommersant.com/p1037442/MMK_production_decline/| archivedate= 17 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=R1310/> another layoff of 1,300 was announced in early November.<ref name=FMSN>{{cite news | language=Russian | url=http://www.newsru.com/finance/06nov2008/magnitka.html | title=Rossiyskie giganty sokraschayut ... (Российские гиганты сокращают сотрудников: магнитогорская "Магнитка" – 1300, ВТБ – 1000) | publisher=newsru.com | accessdate=16 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081210110652/http://www.newsru.com/finance/06nov2008/magnitka.html| archivedate= 10 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Severstal]] reduced domestic production by 25%; its US and Italian production dropped by 30%.<ref name=R1310>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/basicIndustries/idUKLA15036320081013|title=Severstal cuts steel output as crisis hits demand|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=13 October 2008 |accessdate=16 November 2008}}</ref> [[Evraz Group]], employer of 40 thousands workers in [[Kemerovo Oblast]], was reported negotiating layoffs with the unions and regional government since 30 October. The company, specializing in construction-grade rolled steel, was inherently in worse position than other Russian steel mills. 13 November Evraz announced that, instead of layoffs, it will decrease workers' wages by a third. Some of Evraz facilities were converted to a four-day working week; the company reduced output to an estimated 50–60% of its capacity.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sekonomit na zarplate (Сэкономить на зарплате) |url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008/11/14/168972 |publisher=[[Vedomosti]] |date=14 November 2008 |language=Russian |accessdate=15 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226064233/http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008%2F11%2F14%2F168972 |archivedate=26 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 18 November [[Goskomstat]] insider reported an unprecedented drop in industrial prices – minus 6.6% monthly, following a 0.8% drop in September (the agency itself delayed its regular monthly report). Most of the losses concentrate in raw material industries; automobile and tool-making industries dropped only 0.4%.<ref>{{cite news | title=Industrial Deflation Has Little Impact | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1072460/r_528/producer_price_index/ | publisher=Kommersant |date=18 November 2008 | accessdate=18 November 2008}}</ref> In two months, gasoline and diesel oil wholesale prices dropped by 12.8% and 16.5%. The worst price fall hit the steel industry: pig iron and ferric alloys dropped 21.7% in October after an 8.9% drop in September. Prices on aluminum and nickel are down to [[break-even]] point. The decline is sufficient to indicate a [[recession]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazeta.ru/financial/2008/11/17/2886251.shtml | title= Tzeny ukazyvayut na rezessiyu (Цены указывают на рецессию) | publisher=[[gazeta.ru]] |date=18 November 2008|language=Russian|accessdate=18 November 2008}}</ref>
In November the industry relied on government funds distributed through [[Vneshtorgbank]] loans. VTB issued a 10 billion roubles emergency loan to Evraz to finance its current tax payments;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rian.ru/crisis_news/20081113/154990953.html|title=VTB predostavil Evraz Group 10 mlrd... (ВТБ предоставил "Евраз Груп" 10 млрд рублей для текущей деятельности)|language=Russian|publisher=RIA Novosti |date=13 November 2008|accessdate=15 November 2008}}</ref> a similar 5 billion loan was issued to [[OAO TMK]]. [[Magnitogorsk Iron and Steel Works|Magnitka]] was reported "in the line" for VTB financing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008/11/14/168974|title=Zayom na nalogi(Заем на налоги)|publisher=Vedomosti |date=14 November 2008|language=Russian|accessdate=15 November 2008}}</ref> The industry continued to implode, and on 14 and 18 November [[Novolipetsk Steel]] shut down two of its five<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nlmksteel.com/StandardPage____15.aspx | title=Capacity and utilisation of plant, 2007 | publisher=[[Novolipetsk Steel]] | accessdate=16 November 2008}}</ref> [[blast furnace]]s, reducing its [[pig iron]] capacity by 2.5 million metric tons, or 27%.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.londonstockexchange.com/LSECWS/IFSPages/MarketNewsPopup.aspx?id=2021509&source=RNS | archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20081114062009/http://www.londonstockexchange.com/LSECWS/IFSPages/MarketNewsPopup.aspx?id=2021509&source=RNS | dead-url=yes | archive-date=14 November 2008 | title=NLMK idles two blast furnaces | publisher=[[Novolipetsk Steel]] report to [[London Stock Exchange]] | accessdate=16 November 2008}} </ref> On the same day Novolipetsk Steel denied steel shipments to [[GAZ]] due to automobile maker's default on payments.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.echo.msk.ru/news/553417-echo.html | title=Avtokonzern GAZ lishilsya postavok metalla (Автоконцерн ГАЗ лишился поставок металла от Новолипецкого комбината)|publisher=[[Echo of Moscow]]|language=Russian|accessdate=15 November 2008}}</ref>
===Automotive industry=== {{main|Automotive industry in Russia}} In June 2008 [[The Economist]] described "Russia's booming car market" as a place where "you just need someone to count the money".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=11496858 | title=Crisis? What oil crisis? | publisher=The Economist, 5 June 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 | date=5 June 2008}}</ref> In November the market slowed to its lowest since January 2007. [[AC Nielsen]] linked the market drop to a collapse in [[auto loan]] programs and general uncertainty among consumers, and predicted that unless auto loans recover, the market will slide back into the 1990s.<ref>{{cite news | title=Russian auto sales slow as crisis hits car loans | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/marketsNews/idUSLB38301520081111 |agency=Reuters |date=11 November 2007 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> The government supported domestic auto makers by an increase in [[tariff]]s on imports, leading to an expected 7.5–8% price increase for imported cars.<ref name=K11>{{cite news | title=Foreign Car Owners to Have Higher Self-Rating | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1054618/Duty_foreign_car/ | publisher=Kommersant |date=11 November 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref>
[[GAZ]] and [[KAMAZ]] were the first auto makers to declare production cuts in September–October 2008. [[GAZ]] truck production has decreased by 23.4% in September 2008; in October the company announced week-long shutdowns of the main assembly line to meet decrease in demand for its most successful line, the [[GAZelle]] truck.<ref name=K08/> [[KAMAZ]], the target of acquisition by [[Daimler AG]] since July,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ousivMolt/idUSL568815820080725 | title=Daimler in talks to buy stake in Kamaz |agency=Reuters , 25 July 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 | date=25 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p916729/r_500/Russian_auto_industry/ | title=KamAZ Teams Up with Daimler | publisher=Kommersant, 28 July 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> has been reporting financial difficulties since September. In October KAMAZ reduced working hours by a third, from six-day to four-day working week.<ref name=K08>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1037547/VAZ_KamAZ/ | title=Crisis Extended to Automobile Makers | publisher=Kommersant|date=8 October 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> KAMAZ requested a 15 billion rouble state-backed loan and took a private loan from [[Citigroup]] at 9% over [[prime rate]];<ref>{{ cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1045661 | title=Pike gruzovika (Пике грузовика) | publisher=Sekret firmy|date=27 October 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> in December Daimler AG acquired the first 10% in KAMAZ stock, citing "perfect storm" as a good time acquisition.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssConsumerGoodsAndRetailNews/idUSLC23415720081212 | title=Daimler stock falls on $250 mln Kamaz deal |agency=Reuters , 12 December 2008 | accessdate=15 December 2008 | date=12 December 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090110072149/https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssConsumerGoodsAndRetailNews/idUSLC23415720081212| archivedate= 10 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[AvtoVAZ]] disclosed emergency measures on 16 October, when [[Igor Sechin]] held an industry-wide anti-crisis brainstorming session in [[Tolyatti|Togliatti]].<ref name=K17/> [[AvtoVAZ]] reported a stockpile of 100 thousands unsold cars (two months' output). The company requested government assistance of 1 billion US Dollars arranged through a [[Vneshtorgbank]] loan. Unlike other major borrowers who used VTB loans to substitute foreign capital, AvtoVAZ loan was intended solely to pay current expenses.<ref name=K17>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1042092/government_credit_/ | title=AvtoVAZ Asks for a Billion | publisher=Kommersant|date=17 October 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref>
[[Moskvitch#Introduction of the Aleko|AvtoFramos]], Moscow-based manufacturer of [[Renault Logan]], has confirmed that instead of a planned weekly New Year holiday, the plant will stop for a month, 12 December 2008 to 12 January 2009. Trade unions asserted that AvroFramos has practiced short-time stoppages in November; plant administration refuted these statements. According to the unions, unsold stock reached 8 thousand cars, a month's output of the plant.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazeta.ru/auto/2008/11/28_a_2898289.shtml | title=Renault poshel na ostanovku (Renault пошел на остановку) | publisher=gazeta.ru |date=28 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=29 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081203053039/http://www.gazeta.ru/auto/2008/11/28_a_2898289.shtml| archivedate= 3 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Vredestein|Amtel-Vredestein]] has closed two of its [[tire]] plants due to cash flow problems.<ref>{{cite news | title=Krisis v pomosch (Кризис в помощь) | url=http://www.rbcdaily.ru/2008/11/14/industry/390300 | publisher=[[RosBusinessConsulting]] |date=14 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> On 2 December media announced closure of [[Bor Glass Works]], the principal supplier of auto glass,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://vz.ru/news/2008/12/2/234605.html | title=Borsky zavod ostanavlivaet proizvodstvo (Борский стекольный завод останавливает производство) | language=Russian | publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]], 2 December 2008 | accessdate=15 December 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081205101909/http://vz.ru/news/2008/12/2/234605.html| archivedate= 5 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> but the news was soon refuted as false by the plant administration.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/1095070.html | title=Borsky zavod ne ostanovyat (Борский стекольный завод не остановят) | language=Russian | publisher=Regnum, 7 December 2008 | accessdate=15 December 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081207234617/http://www.regnum.ru/news/1095070.html| archivedate= 7 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Construction and real estate===
In the first half of 2008 Russian construction industry, apparently immune of the global financial squeeze, grew by 22% in nominal money compared to 2007.<ref name=PMR>{{ cite news | title=Russian construction hit by global financial crisis | url=http://www.khl.com/magazines/international-construction/detail/item28455/Russian-construction-hit-by-global-financial-crisis/ | publisher=International Construction|date=22 October 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> In September–October [[Mirax Group]], [[Sistema Hals]], [[ST Group]] and other real estate developers announced freezing of future projects and intention to dispose of ongoing projects in early stages, citing an unacceptable increase in interest rates and uncertain demand. According to a Mirax executive, "our clients are panicking, and that is affecting our business",<ref name=WP/> "... bank financing for developers has practically ceased".<ref name=S1008>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/0,1518,582844,00.html |title=The Credit Crisis Hits Russia |author=Jason Bush |work=Der Spiegel |date=8 October 2008 |accessdate=16 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012105428/http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/0%2C1518%2C582844%2C00.html |archivedate=12 October 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Developers and builders of a lesser scale are facing a "struggle to survive",<ref name=WP>{{cite news | title=Crisis Is Putting Brakes on Russia's Construction Boom | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/06/AR2008100602853.html |work=Washington Post |date=6 October 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 | first=Philip P. | last=Pan}}</ref> especially in regional cities. In October 2008 [[Orenburg]] construction executive described regional business prospects as "very bad", notably the fact that "there is no single bank for today which grants [[mortgage loan]]s... Construction industry will not survive under such terms."<ref>{{cite news | title=Financial crisis hits Orenburg construction industry | url=http://www.regnum.ru/english/1068423.html | publisher=regnum.ru|date=13 October 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081019003353/http://www.regnum.ru/english/1068423.html| archivedate= 19 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
27 October Vladimir Putin urged the government agencies to increase state purchases of road and housing construction services, arguing that the state must capitalize on the decrease in prices of raw materials. The state allocated 50 billion roubles to buy ready-to-occupy urban housing from cash-strapped developers. Putin emphasized that the new contracts must be struck on new, decreased, price terms – estimated to be 20–30% cheaper than in spring.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ng.ru/economics/2008-10-28/4_crisis.html |title=V krizise nashli pozitiv (В кризисе нашли позитив) |publisher=[[Nezavisimaya gazeta]] |date=28 October 2008 |language=Russian |accessdate=16 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081031080725/http://www.ng.ru/economics/2008-10-28/4_crisis.html |archivedate=31 October 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Strabag]] executive estimated that in 2009 construction costs will decrease a further 30%.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.rbcdaily.ru/2008/11/14/market/390298 | title=Gorod ostavit zastroyschikov bez marzhi (Город оставит застройщиков без маржи) | publisher=[[RosBusinessConsulting]] |date=14 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> In November Moscow city government has been successfully pressing local developers for a 25% discount against October [[auction]] prices; the only developer who attempted to sue the city for a breach of contract withdrew their lawsuit and accepted the government terms. City government also pulled out of the 118-floor [[Russia Tower]] project,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazeta.ru/business/2008/11/21/2890861.shtml | title= Znak snizhe (Знак сниже) | publisher=gazeta.ru |date=21 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=16 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206161635/http://www.gazeta.ru/business/2008/11/21/2890861.shtml| archivedate= 6 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> which was immediately suspended by its developer, citing "credit crunch".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7742538.stm |title=Moscow super skyscraper halted |publisher=BBC |date=21 November 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081121183718/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7742538.stm| archivedate= 21 November 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Other industries===
In November, the volume of Russian paper exports to China decreased by 30–40%, coupled with a 30% drop in prices. Exports to Western Europe fare marginally better, with an estimated 25–40% drop in production volumes. Russia's largest producer of industrial paper bags, [[Segezh Paper Mill]] (controlled by the [[Bank of Moscow]] and the City of Moscow<ref>{{cite news | url=http://kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?fromsearch=4d9b7ca5-7395-4b3f-86e7-dd3925e20d88&docsid=1010426 | title=Pushkinskuyu ploshchad zavernuli ("Пушкинскую площадь" завернули в бумагу "Инвестлеспрома") | publisher=[[Kommersant]], 12 August 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=26 November 2008 }}</ref>), declared a ten-day shutdown on 24 November.<ref name=BNSK/> [[UPM (company)|UPM-Kymmene Oyj]] anticipates at least a 30–40% decrease in output compared to 2008.<ref name=BNSK>{{cite news | url=http://kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?fromsearch=43368a4c-1352-45f8-9116-2ab9688056bb&docsid=1080659 | title=Bumaga ne sterpela krizis (Бумага не стерпела кризис) | publisher=[[Kommersant]] |date=24 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=26 November 2008 }}</ref> In June 2010, President Dmitry Medvedev visited Silicon Valley in San Jose, California in order to cultivate ideas of how to develop Russia as a major research center. Skolkovo, a mid-sized city near Moscow, is the proposed location for this Russian Silicon Valley, and will have its own tax structure. Yet, Medvedev has been criticized by opposition politicians for deflecting attention away from the struggling economy and corruption.
===Airlines===
In June–August 2008 the fleet of [[KrasAir]], a [[Krasnoyarsk]]-based airline with a controlling state interest, was grounded by the fuel suppliers' refusal to extend credit to the company that defaulted on payments. Other members of [[AiRUnion]] consortium, notably [[Dalavia]], also folded in August. Thousands of passengers were stranded in airports; flight delays and cancellations became a national agenda.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1019797/Russian_airline_industry/ | title=Flight Delays Continue Nationwide | publisher=Kommersant |date=3 September 2008 | accessdate=17 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081222233341/http://www.kommersant.com/p1019797/Russian_airline_industry/| archivedate= 22 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Government action focused on setting the cap on [[jet fuel]] prices and restructuring its assets into a new company managed by [[Rostechnologii]], a newly formed state [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]]. Ministry of Transportation distributed the licenses to fly former KrasAir routes to other companies. KrasAir also defaulted on payments to its staff, and on 27 October a [[strike action]], coupled with fuel suppliers' denial of service, finally ruined the airline. [[Dalavia]] lost its license earlier in October.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://atwonline.com/news/other.html?issueDate=10%2F7%2F2008 | title=Dalavia Far East Airways, based at Khabarovsk, had its traffic rights suspended | publisher=ATW Daily News|date=7 October 2007 | accessdate= 29 November 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The collapse of KrasAir also threatened [[Sky Express]], Russia's first [[low cost carrier]] co-owned by the [[EBRD]] and former manager of KrasAir.<ref>{{cite news | title=Sky Express License in Danger | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1024008/airlines_crisis/ | publisher=Kommersant |date=11 September 2008 | accessdate=17 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081222233351/http://www.kommersant.com/p1024008/airlines_crisis/| archivedate= 22 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> 22 October the assets of bankrupt [[KrasAir]], [[Domodedovo Airlines]], [[Samara Airlines]] and [[Atlant-Soyuz Airlines]] were consolidated in a new company, '''[[Rosavia]]''', co-financed by the City of Moscow and Rostekhnologii.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1045266/Russian_airlines/ | title=Airlines of Russia Takes Off | publisher=Kommersant|date=22 October 2008 | accessdate=17 November 2008 }}</ref> [[Rossiya (airline)|Rossiya]], [[Orenair]], [[Kavminvodyavia]], [[Vladivostok Air]], [[Dalavia]] and [[Saravia]] were originally planned to join this proposed airline holding company, too, which would have made Rosavia the largest Russian airline by fleet size. Following a 20 percent drop of domestic passenger numbers in Russia per month, the [[Government of Russia|federal government]] scrapped all plans concerning the new airline on 5 March 2009<ref>[http://www.russiatoday.com/Business/2009-03-05/Rosavia_plans_held_off_as_doubts_about_smaller_airlines_mount.html ''Rosavia plans held off as doubts about smaller airlines mount'', Russia Today TV, 5 March 2009 ].Accessed: 6 July 2009.</ref>
===Agriculture, food industry and retail===
Russia had a high grain harvest in 2008, but so it was elsewhere in the world, bringing the prices down. To support the trade, [[Dmitry Medvedev]] authorized a state export subsidy of 40 US dollars per [[metric ton]]. This, according to the minister of agriculture, is sufficient to maintain exports at 20–25 million metric tons.<ref>{{cite news | title=Harvester Operators to Be Fed from Budget | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1056449/Subvention_agriculture/ | publisher=Kommersant |date=12 November 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> The food industry is, however, locked between high costs of farm produce and tight price and credit terms dictated by retail chains. Food industry executives anticipate that the chains will eventually lose part of their clients to street markets, as the suppliers are forced to develop this independent sales channel.<ref name=POMI>{{ cite news | url=http://www.expert.ru/articles/2008/11/14/pomidor/ | title= Iz setey na rynok (Из сетей на рынок) | publisher=Expert Online |date=14 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=16 November 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206022955/http://expert.ru/articles/2008/11/14/pomidor/| archivedate= 6 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Domestic retail chains, [[Leverage (finance)|heavily leveraged]],<ref name=RVR/> were experiencing [[liquidity crisis]] at least since April 2008.<ref name=KAPR>{{cite news | title=Chains Drown in Debts | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p879075/top_50_Russian_retailers_rating/ | publisher=Kommersant, 14 April 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> The first chain to go bankrupt in May 2008, [[Grossmart]] (190 stores in Moscow region), had a particularly high debt-to-[[EBITDA]] ratio of 6 to 1.<ref name=KAPR/><ref name=E9>{{cite news | url=http://www.expert.ru/articles/2008/09/01/document430708/ | title=Vremya defoltov (Время дефолтов) | language=Russian | publisher=Expert Online |date=1 September 2008 | accessdate=16 November 2008 }}</ref> [[Arbat Prestige]], subject to government attacks since 2007, defaulted on its bonds in June.<ref name=E9/> In November 2008 nine leading food retail chains (out of nearly 300) received access to government-backed financing.<ref name=POMI/> Nevertheless, retailers are pressing food suppliers for longer credit terms or bigger [[cash discount]]s, demanding up to 50% price cut for cash payment. Suppliers, in a mirror move, raised "regular" credit prices by 20–60%. Rather than submit to the chains' demands, they simply refuse to sell; visible depletion of stocks has affected only a few affected chains.<ref name=RVR/>
==Social impact==
===Unemployment===
A proprietary [[Ernst & Young]] survey of 113 clients that leaked into Russian press in November summarized their losses at 8% of managerial and 6% of low-level jobs by end of October. All companies in the survey practiced some sort of reducing labor costs. One company in four practiced unpaid "vacations"; 8% of clients settled for reduced working hours.<ref name=V2411>{{cite news|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008/11/24/170362 |title=Glavnye uvolnenia vperedi (Главные увольнения впереди) |publisher=[[Vedomosti]] |date=24 November 2008 |accessdate=7 December 2008 |language=Russian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226064243/http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008%2F11%2F24%2F170362 |archivedate=26 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Federal Migratory Service]] announced in November that 1123 Russian companies reported upcoming layoffs of 45 thousand.<ref name=FMSN/>
Most layoffs were reported in metallurgy and financial services: 20% in [[Uralsib]], 1000 in [[Vneshtorgbank]]'s VTB24 retail division.<ref name=FMSN/> 1 December [[Vedomosti]] reported upcoming 40% cuts in [[MDM Bank]] and 80% in [[IFD Kapital]].<ref name=V012>{{cite news|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008/12/01/171534 |title=Finansisty bez raboty (Финансисты без работы) |publisher=[[Vedomosti]], 1 December 2008 |accessdate=7 December 2008 |language=Russian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204091634/http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article.shtml?2008%2F12%2F01%2F171534 |archivedate=4 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Sberbank]] endorsed a long-term program to reduce headcount by 25% in 2014.<ref name=FMSN/> In telecommunications, [[Sitronics]] laid off up to 10% in all business units; in audit services, [[Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu]] reduced number of partners in its Russian division by 17 out of 180.<ref name=V2411/> [[Vedomosti]] has set up a private "layoff newsreel" syndicating independent reports of job cuts, yet as at 7 December 2008, there are no reliable nationwide statistics on white-collar unemployment, which usually escapes official unemployment record.<ref name=VNR>{{ cite news | url=http://career.vedomosti.ru/reductions.shtml | title=Vedomosti layoff newsreel |language=Russian | accessdate=7 December 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081205034453/http://career.vedomosti.ru/reductions.shtml| archivedate= 5 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
By late November, Kremlin First Deputy Chief of Staff, [[Vladislav Surkov]], was warning that the middle classes should be defended from poverty during the crisis. He called for swift measures to protect the middle class from layoffs and to support consumption.<ref name=R2811>{{ cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/afxnewslimited/feeds/afx/2008/11/28/afx5755046.html | title=Kremlin says to defend Russian middle class in crisis | author=Guy Faulconbridge |agency=Reuters |date=28 November 2008 | accessdate=7 December 2008 | work=Forbes}}</ref> "If the 1980s were the times of the intellectuals and the 1990s were the times of the oligarchs then the 00s can be seen as the epoch of the middle classes,' Surkov said in a speech published on the Web site of the ruling United Russia party ... The main task of the state during the slump must become the preservation of the middle class, the defence of the middle class from the waves of poverty and confusion that are coming from the West," he said.<ref name=R2811/>
According to official statements released 9 December, rate of unemployment growth peaked in the middle of November and slowed down in subsequent weeks. In the week ending 3 December overall unemployment grew by 1.6% to 1.315 million people, following a 2.3% increase in the preceding week. The state also reported an increase in unpaid vacations and reduced working week employees to 149.3 thousands. The number increased by 84% in a single week ending 3 December. The trade unions anticipate that official unemployment will peak at around 2 million people in 2009, when hidden forms of unemployment become visible to statisticians.<ref>{{ cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1091372&ThemesID=437 | title=Monitoring Minzdrava (Мониторинг Минздрава) | language=Russian | publisher=[[Kommersant]], 9 December 2008 | accessdate=9 December 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081215132313/http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1091372&ThemesID=437| archivedate= 15 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Yet on 12 December Putin announced completely different unemployment numbers – 4.6 million in October.<ref>{{ cite news | url=http://rg.ru/2008/12/15/putin.html | title=Banki v prioritete (Банки в приоритете) | publisher=Rossiyskaya Gazeta, 15 December 2008 | accessdate=15 December 2008 | language=Russian | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081215075857/http://www.rg.ru/2008/12/15/putin.html| archivedate= 15 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In February 2009 the unemployment rate peaked at a seven-year high of 9.4%, then began to steadily decline, falling to 7.7% as of October.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/quote?ticker=RUREFEG:IND Russian unemployment rates] [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref>
===Consumer price inflation=== Official consumer price inflation in January–August 2008 reached 14.8%.<ref name=RVR>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc-rss.aspx?DocsID=1050454 | title=Raznitsa v roznitse (Разница в рознице) | publisher=Sekret firmy |date=3 November 2008 | language=Russian | accessdate=17 November 2008 }}</ref> By the end of November, food price inflation for an 11-month period reached 15.3%. Overall price inflation, taking into account consumer and industrial prices, reached 12.5% compared to 10.6% for the same period of 2007. Decline in short-term inflation was credited to a reduction in monetary supply.<ref name=K0912>{{cite news | url=http://www.kommersant.com/p1090700/Inflation_statistics/ | title=Inflation Pressure Goes Dn On Future Expectations | publisher=[[Kommersant]], 8 December 2008 | accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref> Inflation slowed through 2009 with a year on year rate of 9.1% as of November, down from 13.8% a year earlier.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/quote?ticker=RUCPIYOY:IND Russian inflation rates] [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] Retrieved on 16 December 2009</ref>
==See also== *[[1998 Russian financial crisis]] *[[Financial crisis of 2007-2008]] *[[Great Recession]] *[[2008-2009 Latvian financial crisis]] *[[2000s commodities boom]] *[[Russian financial crisis (2014–present)]]

[[File:Bluffs100407 (28 of 28).JPG|thumb|300px|Award-winning pumpkin with small child for reference]] The '''Half Moon Bay Art and Pumpkin Festival''' is an annual festival held in the coastside community of [[Half Moon Bay, California]] for one weekend during [[pumpkin]] harvest season. It is one of the oldest and largest local festivals in California. Proceeds go to local civic causes and to the beautification of the downtown area of Half Moon Bay. There is no admission charge for the event. ==Dates== The annual event is held in October. [[Columbus Day]] Monday is the Safeway World Champion Pumpkin Weigh-in contest. The Half Moon Bay Art and Pumpkin Festival is a two-day event held the following Saturday and Sunday each year. Festival hours are from 9 AM to 5 PM both Saturday and Sunday. ==Locations== The festival is located in downtown [[Half Moon Bay, California|Half Moon Bay]] on Main Street between Miramontes and Spruce Streets. The Great Pumpkin Parade is held at Noon on Saturday and runs East along Miramontes, North on Main St, and West on Mill Street. There are two Music Stages, one at the South entrance and one located next to the Food Court in the IDES grounds. A Family Stage is located at 620 Main Street. The associated Safeway World Championship Pumpkin Weigh-In is located on the IDES Grounds at 735 Main Street on Columbus Day, the Monday prior to the festival. ==History== The Half Moon Bay Art and Pumpkin Festival began in 1971 with the formation of the Main Street Beautification Committee. The group was formed to raise funds for the revitalization of Main Street, which was beginning to show signs of decay. With an abundance of pumpkin patches in the area, the committee organized an old-fashioned harvest-style pumpkin festival. The first festival attracted 30,000 people. That year only one non-profit organization offered food for sale. The festival now includes dozens of local non-profit groups operating food and game booths, selling everything from pumpkin pie to linguisa sandwiches. Proceeds go to various civic and local causes and have included the construction of two parks, multiple scholarship funds, the installation of old-fashioned downtown street lights, the underground wiring of Main Street, and the renovation of City Hall. == Traditions== • The Safeway World Championship Pumpkin Weigh-Off attracts growers from around the United States. The weigh-off is held the Monday prior to the festival and the winners are on display during the festival weekend. In 2009, Don Young of Iowa won the event with a 1,659 lb [[Atlantic Giant]] pumpkin taking home $9,948 in prize money.{{cite news|url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/10/13/BA551A4NTG.DTL|title=1658 pound pumpkin is record|date=October 13, 2009|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle}}
• Harvest inspired Arts and Crafts are represented by 250 artist and craftmakers. Original works are available in glass, ceramics, metals, fiber, leather, wood, jewelry and fine art.
• Food is a big item at the festival. Many food offerings include pumpkin such as pie, pancakes, bread, cheesecake, sausages, and ice cream. Local coastal favorites include Brussels sprouts, artichoke hearts, and Portuguese linguisa sandwiches. All food is provided by community non-profit groups.
• The Great Pumpkin Parade features the weigh-off champion pumpkin, marching bands, classic cars, and costumed children of all ages.
• Continuous entertainment is located on three stages throughout the festival. A variety of music is available from Country, to Blues, to Reggae.
• Family entertainment includes a costume contest, pumpkin carving, games, and a pie eating contest.
• Giant pumpkin carving is provided by [[Farmer Mike]], a professional pumpkin carver that turns giant pumpkins (up to a thousand pounds) into faces and reliefs. [[Farmer Mike]] has carved at the event for 25 years.
• Local wine and microbrews offer wine and beer by the glass.
• Other attractions include a Sunday Pumpkin Run/Walk, a talent show, a pancake breakfast, giant pumpkin photos, a poster contest exhibit, and a haunted house. ==Traffic == The popular event attracts more than 200,000 people to this rural community. Major access from the greater [[San Francisco Bay Area]] is from Highway 92 to the east. North/South access from [[San Francisco]] or [[Santa Cruz, Ca|Santa Cruz]] is available using coastal [[California State Route 1|Highway 1]]. The festival, combined with multiple pumpkin patches surrounding the town, generate severe traffic congestion each year.{{cite news|url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1995/10/13/PENINSUL12943.dtl |title=Pumpkin Moon -Get There Early|date=October 13, 1995|first=Al|last=Morch|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle}} Parking is limited to side streets or paid parking in lots sponsored by local organizations. ==References== ==External links== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [http://www.miramarevents.com/pumpkinfest/ Maramar Events -the official HMB Art and Pumpkin Festival web site] * http://www.halfmoonbaychamber.org/visiting_hmb/greatpumpkins.html {{coord|37|27|36|N|122|25|47|W|source:placeopedia|display=title}} [[Category:Art festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Harvest festivals]] [[Category:Half Moon Bay, California]] [[Category:Festivals in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in San Mateo County, California]] [[Category:Pumpkin festivals]]
