{{Infobox song | title = Heaven Watch the Philippines | English_title = | comment = | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | original_artist = [[Irving Berlin]] | recorded_by = | performed_by = | written = 1946 | Released = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | Published = | Length = <!-- {{Duration|m=MM|s=SS}} --> | Writer = [[Irving Berlin]] | Composer = | Lyricist = | Language = | Form = }} '''''Heaven Watch the Philippines''''' is a popular song by [[Irving Berlin]], written in 1946.
It was written as a tribute to [[Philippines|Filipino]] resistance during the [[Japanese occupation of the Philippines|Japanese occupation]] in [[World War II]]. During the war, Japanese troops in the Philippines attempted to popularize self-glorifying songs such as "Chichi Yo Anata Wa Tsuyokatta" ("Father, You Were Brave" in English). Locals resisted these efforts, preferring instead to sing "God Bless the Philippines" to the tune of Berlin's "[[God Bless America]]" as a show of national pride.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/archive/preview/0,10987,797270,00.html Philippine Flop], Time Magazine, published March 12, 1945, accessed May 15, 2006.</ref>
Berlin himself gave the first performance of "Heaven Watch the Philippines" in [[Tolosa, Leyte]] in 1946, in front of an audience that included [[Sergio Osmeña]] and [[Carlos P. Romulo]].<ref>[http://elgu.ncc.gov.ph/ecommunity/tolosa-leyte/index.php?cat1=32&cat2=4 Municipality of Tolosa: Brief Historical Sketch], the official website of the Municipality of Tolosa, posted 2002, accessed May 15, 2006.</ref>
Berlin was touring U.S. military bases with a stage production of ''[[This Is the Army]]'', in 1945.<ref>[http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/199455%7C0/This-Is-the-Army.html THIS IS THE ARMY], [http://www.tcm.com Turner classic movies].</ref> During a stop in the Philippines, he heard children in [[Leyte]] singing the song ''God Bless America'' (which he had written in 1918 and had revised in 1938) with the lyric "God Bless the Philippines". Touched by that and feeling that they might like a song of their own, he composed "Heaven Watch the Philippines", trying to combine the spiritual quality of "God Bless America" with their feeling for America and desire to be free. He taught the song to school children in Leyte and sang the song in the finale of the show when ''This Is the Army'' opened in Leyte. Berlin had donated the "God Bless America" royalties to the [[Boy Scouts of America]], and he presented the rights to "Heaven Watch the Philippines" to the [[Commonwealth of the Philippines]] with the instruction that if they ever sold the song in the Philippines for profit, the proceeds were to be given to the [[Boy Scouts of the Philippines|Boy]] and [[Girl Scouts of the Philippines]].<ref>Benjamin Sears, ''The Irving Berlin Reader'', pp. [{{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=DqZFJQZiiXIC |page=191 }} 191–192], Oxford University Press, 2012. {{ISBN|9780195383744}}.</ref>
In a 1987 interview with [[Playboy]], [[Imelda Marcos]] falsely claimed that Berlin had written "Heaven Watch the Philippines" specifically for her. When asked about her claim, the 99-year-old Berlin denied it outright.<ref>Ellison, Katherine. "Imelda: Steel Butterfly of the Philippines", p. [{{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=Dfl53AtDM0oC |page=22 }} 22]. [[iUniverse]], 2005. {{ISBN|0-595-34922-6}}.</ref>

{{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Jujuy Exodus |Image_Name = Exodo Jujeño.jpg |Imagesize = 250px |Image_Alt = Portrait of the Jujuy Exodus. |Image_Caption = Portrait of the Jujuy Exodus. |Thumb_Time = |AKA = |Participants = Population of San Salvador de Jujuy |Location = From [[San Salvador de Jujuy]] to [[Tucumán Province|Tucumán]] |Date = {{Start date|1812|08|23}} |Result = Attrition of the [[Royalist (Spanish American Revolution)|Royalist]] army led to its defeat at the [[Battle of Salta]]. |URL = }} The '''Jujuy Exodus''' (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]], '''''Éxodo Jujeño''''') was an episode of the [[Argentine War of Independence]]. It was a massive [[forced relocation|forced displacement]] of people from the [[Jujuy Province]], by orders of General [[Manuel Belgrano]], conducted by his [[Patriot (Spanish American Revolution)|patriot]] forces that were battling a [[Royalist (Spanish American Revolution)|Royalist]] army. The population was compelled to leave under the threat of execution.<ref> ''"los desobedientes serian tratados como traidores y pasados por las armas"''. Roca, José Luis (2007). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=JzPOmeeoX_MC&pg=PA315&dq=%22El+%C3%89xodo+Juje%C3%B1o+%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22El%20%C3%89xodo%20Juje%C3%B1o%20%22&f=false Ni con Lima ni con Buenos Aires: la formación de un estado nacional en Charcas]''. Plural Editores, p. 315. {{ISBN|99954-1-076-1}} {{es icon}}</ref>
==Development== During the early 1812 [[Manuel Belgrano]] had created the [[Cockade of Argentina|cockade]] and [[Flag of Argentina]] near the city of [[Rosario]], and then received order to move to the north. He would take command of the [[Army of the North]], based in the city of [[San Salvador de Jujuy]]. The situation was not favourable: a short time before [[Juan José Castelli]] had led the [[First Alto Perú campaign]] and, despite an initial advantage and a brief time ruling the [[Upper Peru]], faced a decisive defeat during the [[Battle of Huaqui]]. The surviving [[Patriot (Spanish American Revolution)|patriots]] and remains of the Army had retreated to the south, to Jujuy. They were lacking men, weapons and money, and had to stop a victorious army, better armed and four times bigger.
The loyalists, led by General Pío Tristán, were advancing south with 3,000 troops from today's [[Bolivia]], into the northwest of Argentina (through [[Humahuaca]]). The revolutionaries were outnumbered 2 to 1, demoralized, badly armed, far from the assistance of the central government, and facing an outbreak of [[malaria]] without medication. In addition, many of the locals, especially of the higher classes, resented the arrival of forces from [[Buenos Aires]] and were ready to [[defector|defect]].
Belgrano, faced with the prospect of total defeat and territorial loss, ordered all people to pack their necessities, including food and furniture, and follow him, in carriages or on foot, together with whatever cattle and beasts of burden could endure the journey. The rest (houses, crops, food stocks, and also any objects made of iron) was to be burned, so as to deprive the loyalists of resources, following a strict [[scorched earth]] policy. On 29 July 1812 Belgrano asked the people of Jujuy to "show their [[hero]]ism" and join the march of the army under his command "if, as you assure, you want to be free". The punishment for ignoring the order was execution and the destruction of the defector's properties. Belgrano labored to win the support of the populace, and later reported that most of the people had willingly followed him without the need of force.
The exodus started on 23 August and gathered people from Jujuy and [[Salta Province|Salta]]; people travelled south about 250 km, finally arriving at the banks of the Pasaje River, in the province of [[Tucumán Province|Tucumán]], on the early hours of 29 August.
The Exodus is commemorated in Jujuy by traditionalist groups with an Evocative March, every 22 August since 1955. The [[Jujuy Province]] is declared honorific capital of Argentina each 23 August since 2002, by national law 25.644.<ref>[http://www3.hcdn.gov.ar/folio-cgi-bin/om_isapi.dll?clientID=898685323&advquery=%5BField%20Ley%3a%2725664%27%5D&headingswithhits=on&hitsperheading=on&infobase=leyes.nfo&record={A41}&softpage=Document42 Ley 25.644]</ref>

[[John McCain]] was the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] candidate for [[United States presidential election, 2008|President of the United States in 2008]]. Rick Davis, his [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|campaign manager]], projected at one point{{when|date=March 2018}} that his staff would eventually increase to about 450. By early July 2008, it had opened 11 regional offices in key states and some 84 offices total across the country in a joint effort with the [[Republican National Committee]].<ref>[http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2008/07/20/obamas_paid_staff_dwarfing_mccains/ Obama's paid staff dwarfing McCain's]</ref>
==National leadership team== Persons listed on the John McCain for President website:<ref>[http://www.johnmccain.com/Informing/fundraisers.htm John McCain 2008 - John McCain for President<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Former [[Secretary of Commerce]] [[Robert Mosbacher]] - Chairman * [[Frederic V. Malek]] - Finance Director * [[Jill Hazelbaker]] - Spokeswoman

==Former members== * Senator [[Phil Gramm]] - General Co-chair, resigned July 18 after remarks calling Americans "whiners"<ref>{{Cite news | first = Lorraine | last = Woellert | title = Gramm Steps Down as McCain Co-Chair After `Whiners' Remark | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aQgyvcWXm2pM&refer=home | publisher = Bloomberg L.P. | date = 2008-07-18 | accessdate = 2008-07-19}}</ref> * [[Robert Zoellick]] * [[Tom Loeffler]]<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/washington/AP-McCain-Lobbying.html | work=The New York Times}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> * [[Susan E. Nelson]], "continued to collect payments from [the Loeffler Group] this year while she was on the McCain-campaign payroll as its fund-raising coordinator"<ref>WSJ, "Democratic Group Tries to Keep Spotlight on McCain's Lobbyist Ties"</ref> The Loeffler Group is a lobbying firm that has "received $990,000 in lobbying fees and another $3,000 in expenses from the Saudi government".<ref>http://www.fara.gov/docs/5432-Supplemental-Statement-20080118-6.pdf</ref><ref>http://realtime.sunlightprojects.org/2008/04/15/contract-but-no-contacts-mccain-campaign-officials-firm-collects-millions-from-saudis-but-no-meetings-with-members-of-congress/</ref> * [[Mark McKinnon]], citing a pledge not to work against an [[Barack Obama|Obama]] candidacy.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/21/us/politics/21consult.html?ref=politics | work=The New York Times | title=Keeping Vow on Obama, McCain Adviser Resigns | first=Jim | last=Rutenberg | date=May 21, 2008 | accessdate=May 8, 2010}}</ref> * [[Doug Davenport]] and Doug Goodyear of the [[DCI Group]] resigned on May 10, 2008, after revelation of DCI's ties to the [[military junta]] in Myanmar. Davenport, the regional campaign manager for the mid-Atlantic states, founded the DCI Group's lobbying practice and oversaw the contract with [[Myanmar]] in 2002. Goodyear was asked to become convention CEO after campaign manager Rick Davis's lobbying firm partner, [[Paul Manafort]], was nixed because of his own close ties to foreign governments and controversial companies<ref>[http://marcambinder.theatlantic.com/archives/2008/05/a_second_mccain_aide_resigns.php A Second McCain Aide Resigns], ''[[The Atlantic]]'', May 11, 2008</ref> * [[Carlos Bonilla]], economic policy adviser. Left in May 2008 after the campaign imposed new rules restricting the involvement of lobbyists. * [[Michael P. Dennehy]], national political director and founder of the political consulting and lobbying firm The Dennehy Group.<ref>''Concord Monitor'': [https://web.archive.org/web/20080304034740/http://www.concordmonitor.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20061231%2FREPOSITORY%2F612310383 Dennehy on the job for McCain.] December 30, 2006.</ref> Left in May 2007 explaining that his family obligations conflicted with his arduous, 24/7 political job in Washington, D.C.<ref>url = http://hotlineblog.nationaljournal.com/archives/2007/05/mccains_politic.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905032430/http://hotlineblog.nationaljournal.com/archives/2007/05/mccains_politic.html |date=2008-09-05 }}</ref>

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/175.157.218.109|175.157.218.109]] to version by Shellwood. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3541059) (Bot)
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=February 2015}} <!-- Where possible, please add a REFERENCE for each entry made on this list. --> The '''list of foods with religious symbolism''' provides details, and links to articles, of foods which are used in religious communities or traditions to symbolise an aspect of the faith, or to commemorate a festival or hero of that faith group. Many such foods are also closely associated with a particular date or season. As with all religious traditions, some such foods have passed into widespread secular use, but all those on this list have a religious origin. The list is arranged alphabetically and by religion.
Many religions have a particular 'cuisine' or tradition of cookery, associated with their culture (see, for example, [[List of Jewish cuisine dishes]]). This list is ''not'' intended for foods which are merely part of the cultural heritage of a religious body, but ''specifically'' those foods that bear religious symbolism in the way they are made, or the way they are eaten, or both.
==Christianity== * Agatha Buns, St Agatha's Breasts, or Minni di Virgini - served on the feast day of [[Agatha of Sicily|St Agatha]] (5 February), the small round fruit buns are iced and topped with a cherry, intended to represent breasts. St Agatha was martyred by having her breasts cut off, for refusing to surrender her chastity and virginity to pagans. Due to this association she has become the patron saint of bakers.<ref>Illustration and details at [http://www.goodfoodstories.com/minni-di-virgini/ Good Food Stories] website.</ref><ref>Reference with picture at [https://yummyniceblog.wordpress.com/2011/02/07/minni-di-santagata-st-agathas-breasts/ Adventures of the Kitchen].</ref> *[[Baklava]] - in Greece, it is supposed to be made with 33 dough layers, referring to the years of Christ's life.<ref>Theodore Kyriakou and Charles Campion, ''The Real Greek at Home'', London 2004</ref> *[[Bread]] - often (though not exclusively) unleavened bread; one of the two elements (with wine) of the Christian [[eucharist]], the bread represents Christ's body.<ref name="EB">[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9033174/Eucharist Encyclopædia Britannica, s.v. Eucharist]</ref> *[[Cattern cake]] - small individual cakes with [[caraway]] seeds, made on [[St. Catherine's Day]] (25 November) to celebrate St [[Catherine of Alexandria]], and originating in Tudor times amongst the lace-makers of [[Nottinghamshire]], England.<ref>History and recipe available [http://www.lavenderandlovage.com/2011/11/st-catherines-day-lace-makers-and.html here].</ref> *[[Tsoureki#Christopsomo: Christmas Bread|Christopsomo]] - a type of [[Tsoureki]] bread served at Christmas in Greece; Christmas symbols, and a cross, are traditionally incorporated into the loaf using dough shapes; it is flavoured with figs.<ref>Referenced at the [http://greekfood.about.com/od/greekbreadspitas/r/christopsomo.htm About Food] website.</ref><ref>See entry at [http://www.thegreekglutton.com/christopsomo-greek-christmas-bread/ The Greek Glutton].</ref> *[[Easter biscuit]] - associated with [[Easter]], particularly in parts of England, often flavoured with oil of cassia as a symbol of the perfumes used in preparing Christ's body for burial.<ref>Discussed at [https://www.theguardian.com/notesandqueries/query/0,5753,-2847,00.html The Guardian] website.</ref> *[[Easter egg]] - associated with Easter, as a symbol of new life.<ref name=Meaning>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mzKVPZthGHUC&pg=PA51&dq=easter+egg+Christian|title= Christianity|publisher= [[Nelson Thornes]]|author= Anne Jordan|quote=Easter eggs are used as a Christian symbol to represent the empty tomb. The outside of the egg looks dead but inside there is new life, which is going to break out. The Easter egg is a reminder that Jesus will rise from His tomb and bring new life. Orthodox Christians dye boiled eggs red to make [[red Easter eggs]] that represent the blood of Christ shed for the sins of the world.|date=5 April 2000|accessdate =7 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=Symbolism>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=hPMVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA119&dq=easter+egg+empty+tomb&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IpWAT_e-EKnh0QHVmI3RBw&ved=0CDsQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=easter%20egg%20empty%20tomb&f=false|title= The Guardian, Volume 29|publisher=H. Harbaugh|quote=Just so, on that first Easter morning, Jesus came to life and walked out of the tomb, and left it, as it were, an empty shell. Just so, too, when the Christian dies, the body is left in the grave, an empty shell, but the soul takes wings and flies away to be with God. Thus you see that though an egg seems to be as dead as a stone, yet it really has life in it; and also it is like Christ's dead body, which was raised to life again. This is the reason we use eggs on Easter. (In days past some used to color the eggs red, so as to show the kind of death by which Christ died,-a ''bloody'' death.)|year=1878|accessdate =7 April 2012}}</ref> *[[Fanesca]] - Soup eaten during [[Holy Week]] in [[Ecuador]]. It contains twelve types of beans representing the Apostles and salt cod representing Jesus Christ.<ref>An account of the soup, and a journey to discover its origins, in published in [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/09/05/speaking-of-soup New Yorker] magazine.</ref> *St George cake - individual [[Cupcake|fairy cakes]] with white icing, and a red icing cross, eaten on [[St George's Day]] (23 April).<ref>One recipe, [https://www.bakingmad.com/st-georges-day-cupcakes-recipe/ with pictures].</ref><ref>St George's Day cakes at [http://www.bakewithstork.com/recipes/cupcakes-for-st.-georges-day/ Stork website].</ref> *[[Hot cross bun]] - traditionally eaten on [[Good Friday]] after the Good Friday Liturgy, to break the fast required of Christians on that day.<ref name="TurnerTaylor1999">{{cite book|last1=Turner|first1=Ina|last2=Taylor|first2=Ina|title=Christianity|year=1999|publisher=Nelson Thornes|isbn=9780748740871|page=50|quote=To mark the end of the Lent fast Christians eat hot cross buns. These have a special meaning. The cross in the middle shows how Jesus died. Spices inside remind Christians of the spices put on the body of Jesus. Sweet fruits in the bun show that Christians no longer have to eat plain foods.}}</ref> *[[Koulourakia]] - pastry dessert served on Easter Day in parts of Greece.<ref>Referenced at [http://www.dianekochilas.com/the-foods-of-greek-easter/ Diane Kochilas, Greek food for life].</ref> *Lammas loaf - ordinary bread, but baked using flour from the first cut of the new harvest, for the [[eucharist]] of [[Lammas]] Festival (1 August).<ref>Referenced at [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2012/aug/01/local-loaves-for-lammas The Guardian].</ref> *[[Lampropsomo]] - a type of [[Tsoureki]] bread, flavoured with ground cherry stones, served at Easter in Greece; the name signifies the light of Christ, and red-painted hard boiled eggs are inserted as a symbol of Christ's blood (often three eggs, symbolic of the Holy Trinity).<ref>See details at [http://www.spiceroots.com/lambropsomo-greek-easter-bread-breadbakers/ Spice Roots] website.</ref> *[[St. Lucia buns|St Lucia buns]] (St Lucy buns) - a saffron bun with raisins, associated with [[St Lucy's Day]] (13 December) celebrations, especially in the countries of Scandinavia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aktivioslo.no/artikkel/lussekatter/ |title=Lussekatter må man ha når man skal feire Luciadagen |publisher=Aktivioslo.no |date=2009-12-01 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kristendom.dk/lucia |title=Luciadag |publisher=kristendom.dk |date= |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref> *[[Michaelmas#Food|St. Michael's Bannock]], Michaelmas Bannock or ''Struan Micheil'' is a [[Hebrides|Hebridean]] bread made from equal parts of barley, oats, and rye without using any metal implements.<ref name=cooks>{{cite web|author=Randal W. Oulton |url=http://www.cooksinfo.com/michaelmas-bannock |title=Michaelmas Bannock |publisher=Cooksinfo.com |date=2007-05-13 |accessdate=2016-03-28}}</ref> *Michaelmas cake or St Michael cake - served at [[Michaelmas]] (29 September) this cake is identical to a [[butterfly cake]], but the 'wings' represent angels rather than butterflies.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} *[[Pancakes]] - traditionally eaten on [[Shrove Tuesday]] to symbolise the end of rich eating before [[Lent]] (which begins the following day).<ref>[http://articles.dailyamerican.com/2011-03-07/news/29155052_1_pancake-dinner-pancake-day-shrove Shrove Tuesday inspires unique church traditions KATIE WALKER] 7 March 2011</ref> *[[Paska (bread)|Paska]] - Polish and Ukrainian sweet bread baked and often blessed with other foods for consumption on Easter Sunday to mark the end of fasting.<ref>Joan Halmo [https://books.google.com/books?id=wOJ4sLwVllEC&pg=PA43&dq=Paska+bread&lr=#PPA43,M1 ''Celebrating the church year with young children''] Liturgical Press, 1988 {{ISBN|978-0-8146-1580-5}}. 159 pages. page 43</ref> *[[Pretzel]] - Southern France monks (610 AD) baked thin strips of dough into the shape of a child's arms folded in prayer. Also associated with [[Lent]] in some places.<ref name="Fakes1994">{{cite book|last=Fakes|first=Dennis R.|title=Exploring Our Lutheran Liturgy|date=1 January 1994|publisher=CSS Publishing|isbn=9781556735967|page=33|quote=Since people often gave up meat during Lent, bread became one of the staples of Lent. Bakers even began making dough pretzels--a knotted length of dough that represented a Christian praying, with arms crossed and hands placed on opposite shoulders.}}</ref> *[[Religieuse]] - a type of [[Éclair (pastry)|éclair]] common in France, made to resemble a nun (which is the meaning of its name).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prettytastycakes.com/2008/08/31/une-religieuse-un-eclair/ |title=une religieuse, un éclair |publisher=Pretty Tasty Cakes |date=2008-08-31 |accessdate=2012-08-26}}</ref> *St Sarkis Aghablit - salty biscuits eaten by Armenian youths (traditionally girls, but also now boys<ref>See [http://www.thedailymeal.com/recipes/st-sarkis-halva-recipe The Daily Meal] website.</ref>) on the eve of [[Saint Sarkis the Warrior|St Sarkis's Day]] to induce dreams of their future [[spouse]], by the saint's blessing.<ref>Story and recipe at the [http://www.thearmeniankitchen.com/2014/02/st-sarkis-day-armenian-version-of.html Armenian Kitchen] website.</ref> *St Sarkis Halva - a sweet pastry stuffed with fruit and nuts eaten in Armenian communities on [[Saint Sarkis the Warrior|St Sarkis's Day]] to symbolise the blessings brought by the saint.<ref>Recipe at [http://www.thedailymeal.com/recipes/st-sarkis-halva-recipe The Daily Meal] website.</ref><ref>Recipe at [http://www.thearmeniankitchen.com/2011/02/st-sarkis-day-armenian-valentines-day.html The Armenian Kitchen] website.</ref> *[[Simnel cake]] - symbolically associated with [[Lent]] & Easter and particularly [[Mothering Sunday]] (the fourth Sunday of Lent).<ref name="BBC Religions: Mothering Sunday">{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/holydays/motheringsunday_1.shtml |title=BBC Religions: Mothering Sunday |accessdate=14 July 2012}}</ref> *[[Stollen]] - a German fruit bread with marzipan, eaten during [[Advent]]; it recalls a special Advent tradition restricted to Germany, granted by the Pope in the so-called "butter letter" (1490).<ref name="Stollen history">[http://www.stollen-online.de/dresdnerstollen/geschichte-eng.htm Stollen history]</ref> *[[Święconka]] - a savoury meal, each element of which is symbolic, blessed in churches on Holy Saturday, and eaten on Easter Day, in Poland.<ref>[http://annhetzelgunkel.com/easter/swiecone.html#swieclinks Swieconka] by Ann Hetzel Gunkel</ref> *[[Vasilopita]] - Saint Basil's or King's cake, traditionally eaten on New Year's Day in Greece. It is baked with a coin inside, and whoever finds the coin in their slice is considered blessed with good luck for the whole year.<ref name="hasluck">[[Margaret Masson Hardie Hasluck|Margaret M. Hasluck]], "The Basil-Cake of the Greek New Year", ''Folklore'' '''38''':2:143 (June 30, 1927) [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1256522 JSTOR]</ref> *[[Wine]] - one of the elements of consecration used in the [[sacrament]] of the [[eucharist]], the wine represents Christ's blood.<ref name="EB" />
==Hinduism== *[[Ghee]] - sacred food of the Devas. Burnt in the ritual of [[Aarti]], offered to gods, and used as libation or anointment ritual. *[[Modak]] - a sweet dumpling with a filling of fresh [[coconut]] and [[jaggery]] made specially during [[Ganesh Chaturthi]]. *[[Ghevar]] - is a [[Rajasthani cuisine|Rajasthani]] sweet traditionally associated with the [[Teej]] Festival.<ref>[http://indiacanteen.tastyfix.com/ghevar-a-delight-of-indian-cuisine/ Festival reference] and recipe.</ref>
==Islam== *[[Baklava]] - associated with the fasting month of [[Ramadan (calendar month)|Ramadan]] and [[Eid ul-Fitr]] by the Balkans and Ottoman Empire. *[[Date (fruit)|Dates]] - traditionally dates are eaten at the [[Iftar]] meal to break the fast of Ramadan, symbolically recalling the tradition that the prophet Muhammad broke his fast by eating three dates.<ref>The health benefits and symbolic purposes explained at [http://www.shiachat.com/forum/topic/234983334-why-do-muslims-break-their-fast-with-dates/ Shia Chat].</ref> *[[Halva]] - on the 7th and 40th days and first anniversary following the death of a Muslim, the semolina or flour helva is offered to visitors by relatives of the deceased; it is known in Turkish as “helva of the dead”. The ritual is also performed in Afghanistan, Turkey, Iran. *[[Ketupat]] - packed rice wrapped in a woven palm leaf. Associated with Eid ul-Fitr among Muslims in Southeast Asia.<ref>Reference from the [http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/08/05/muslims-celebrate-lebaran-ketupat-a-week-after-idul-fitri.html Jakarta Post].</ref> *[[Rendang]] - spicy meat dish of [[Minangkabau people|Minangkabau]]. The ingredients of the food contains symbolism of the Minangkabau culture: the chili symbolizes [[ulama]] and [[sharia]], the meat symbolizes clan leaders, the coconut milk symbolizes teachers, spice mixture symbolizes the rest of Minangkabau society. *[[Tumpeng]] - cone-shaped rice dish of [[Javanese culture|Javanese tradition]], associated with the ''[[slametan]]'' ceremony as well as the [[Mawlid]] ceremony. [[Syncretism|Syncretic]] in nature, also used in ceremonies of the [[Balinese people|Balinese Hindu people]]
==Judaism== *Apples and honey - eaten on [[Rosh Hashanah#Symbolic foods|Rosh Hashanah]], to symbolize a sweet new year; other foods with a symbolic meaning may be served, depending on local custom, such as the head of a fish to symbolize the "head" of the year. *Bread - two loaves of bread (''lechem mishneh''), usually braided [[challah]], the [[Berakhah|blessing]] over which the Sabbath meals commence, symbolic of the double portion of [[manna]] that fell for the Israelites on the day before Sabbath during their 40 years in the desert after [[the Exodus]] from [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. *Cheese [[blintz]]es, cheese [[kreplach]], [[cheesecake]], cheese [[sambusak]], atayef (a cheese-filled pancake), a seven-layer cake called ''siete cielos'' (seven heavens) and other dairy foods are traditionally [[Shavuot#Dairy foods|eaten on Shavuot]], and have various symbolic meanings all connected to the giving of the [[Torah]] on [[Mount Sinai#Religious significance|Mount Sinai]] celebrated on this holiday. *[[Charoset]] - a sweet paste eaten at the [[Passover]] [[Seder]], symbolically representing the mortar made by the Jews in Egyptian slavery. *[[Etrog]] - the yellow [[citron]] or Citrus medica used during the week-long holiday of Sukkot. *[[Hamantash]] - a triangular pastry filled with fruit, nuts, or seeds (especially poppy seeds) and eaten at the festival of [[Purim]], being symbolic of the ears of the defeated enemy. *[[Latkes]] - [[potato pancake]]s, known as ''latkes'' in [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]], especially among [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazi]] families, Sephardi, [[History of Jews in Poland|Polish]] and [[Israeli Jews|Israeli]] families eat jam-filled [[doughnut]]s ([[Pączki|pontshkes]]), [[Buñuelos|bimuelos]] (fritters) and [[sufganiyah|sufganiyot]], all of which are [[Frying|fried]] in oil, eaten on [[Hanukkah#Hanukkah foods|Hanukkah]], to commemorate the miracle of a small flask of oil keeping the flame in the Temple alight for eight days. *[[Maror]] - a bitter herb eaten at the Passover Seder meant to remind of the bitterness of slavery. *[[Matzo]] - a type of unleavened bread eaten at the Passover Seder (and the following week), symbolically recalling the Jews leaving Egypt in too much haste to allow their bread to rise in the ovens. *[[kosher wine|Wine]] - for the recitation of ''[[kiddush]]'' at the beginning of [[Shabbat]] and [[Jewish holidays|Festival]] meals, at the [[Havdalah]] service at the conclusion of the Sabbath, and for the [[Jewish wedding#Seven blessings|Seven Blessings]] of the wedding ceremony.
==Shinto== *[[Tofu]] - the ''abura-age'' (soybean curd) is a favourite food of the foxes associated with the deity [[Inari Ōkami|Inari]] and is offered at shrines.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}}
==Taoism== *[[Dumpling]] - symbolizes wealth because the shape is similar to money-related instruments such as the [[tael]] (Chinese weight measure) or Chinese ingots (especially the [[jau gok]]). They are eaten at midnight of [[Chinese New Year]]. *[[Noodle]] - symbolizes longevity, usually served in the Chinese New Year’s Eve.
==See also== {{portal|Food|Religion}} * [[List of foods]]

{{Drugbox | Verifiedfields = changed | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 408580996 | IUPAC_name = {2-[(2-chloro-6-fluorophenyl)amino]-5-methylphenyl}acetic acid | image = Lumiracoxib2DACS.svg | width = 180px | tradename = Prexige | Drugs.com = {{drugs.com|international|lumiracoxib}} | pregnancy_AU = C | legal_status = ℞-only, withdrawn ([[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Canada]], [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[Germany]], [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Cyprus]], [[Brazil]]) | routes_of_administration = Oral | bioavailability = 74-90% | protein_bound = >98% | metabolism = Predominantly in the liver via [[oxidation]] and [[hydroxylation]] ([[CYP2C9]]) | elimination_half-life = 5-8 hours | excretion = Urine (54%) and faeces (43%) | IUPHAR_ligand = 2897 | CAS_number_Ref = {{cascite|changed|??}} | CAS_number = 220991-20-8 | ATC_prefix = M01 | ATC_suffix = AH06 | PubChem = 151166 | DrugBank_Ref = {{drugbankcite|changed|drugbank}} | DrugBank = DB01283 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 133236 | UNII_Ref = {{fdacite|changed|FDA}} | UNII = V91T9204HU | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|changed|EBI}} | ChEBI = 73044 | KEGG_Ref = {{keggcite|correct|kegg}} | KEGG = D03714 | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 404108 | PDB_ligand = LUR | C=15 | H=13 | Cl=1 | F=1 | N=1 | O=2 | molecular_weight = 293,72 g/mol | SMILES = Clc2cccc(F)c2Nc1ccc(cc1CC(=O)O)C | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C15H13ClFNO2/c1-9-5-6-13(10(7-9)8-14(19)20)18-15-11(16)3-2-4-12(15)17/h2-7,18H,8H2,1H3,(H,19,20) | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = KHPKQFYUPIUARC-UHFFFAOYSA-N }} '''Lumiracoxib''' ([[International Nonproprietary Name|rINN]]) is a [[carboxylic acid]] [[COX-2 selective inhibitor]] [[nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug]], manufactured by [[Novartis]] and still sold in few countries, including [[Mexico]], [[Ecuador]] and the [[Dominican Republic]], under the trade name '''Prexige''' (sometimes misquoted as "Prestige" by the media).{{cite journal|last=Shi|first=S|author2=Klotz, U |title=Clinical use and pharmacological properties of selective COX-2 inhibitors.|journal=European Journal of Clinical Pharmacology|date=March 2008|volume=64|issue=3|pages=233–52|doi=10.1007/s00228-007-0400-7|pmid=17999057}} Lumiracoxib has several distinctive features. Its structure is different from that of other COX-2 inhibitors, such as [[celecoxib]]: lumiracoxib is an [[analog (chemistry)|analogue]] of [[diclofenac]] (one chlorine substituted by fluorine, the phenylacetic acid has another methyl group in meta position), making it a member of the arylalkanoic acid class of NSAIDs; it binds to a different site on the COX-2 enzyme than do other COX-2 inhibitors; it is the only [[acid]]ic coxib and has the highest COX-2 selectivity of any NSAID.{{cite journal |vauthors=Tacconelli S, Capone ML, Patrignani P |title=Clinical pharmacology of novel selective COX-2 inhibitors |journal=Curr Pharm Des |volume=10 |issue=6 |pages=589–601 |year=2004 |pmid=14965322 |doi= 10.2174/1381612043453108|url=https://zenodo.org/record/977695}} Since its original approval, lumiracoxib has been [[list of withdrawn drugs|withdrawn from the market]] in several countries, mostly due to its potential for causing liver failure (sometimes requiring [[liver transplantation]]). It has never been approved for use in the United States. ==History== The TARGET study ('''T'''herapeutic '''A'''rthritis '''R'''esearch and '''G'''astrointestinal '''E'''vent '''T'''rial) was conducted with more than 18,000 patients to test its gastrointestinal and cardiovascular safety against [[naproxen]] and [[ibuprofen]] and also study its efficacy against these two NSAIDs. In November 2006, Prexige received marketing approval for all European Union countries through a common procedure called MRP. However, in August 2007, Prexige was withdrawn from the market in Australia following 8 serious liver adverse events, including 2 deaths and 2 liver transplants.{{Cite web |url=http://www.tga.gov.au/recalls/2007/lumiracoxib.htm |title=Urgent medicine recall - Lumiracoxib (PREXIGE) |access-date=2007-08-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070827160513/http://www.tga.gov.au/recalls/2007/lumiracoxib.htm |archive-date=2007-08-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} On September 27, 2007, the US Food and Drug Administration issued a not approvable letter for lumiracoxib, requiring additional safety data.http://hugin.info/134323/R/1156327/223186.pdf Canada withdrew Prexige (approved at 100 mg dose only) in October 2007.[http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/media/advisories-avis/_2007/2007_141-eng.php Withdrawal of Market Authorization for Prexige] Several European Union countries followed suit in November 2007.[http://www.novartis.com/newsroom/media-releases/en/2007/1169462.shtml Media releases] The FDA rejected '''Prexige''' as a trade name for lumiracoxib in 2003. '''Prexede''' was suggested as an alternative, but the FDA Division of Medication Errors and Technical Support (DMETS) subsequently recommended against it as well.http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/05/briefing/2005-4090B1_33_GG-FDA-Tab-U.pdf ===Withdrawal from market=== On August 11, 2007, Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration ([[Therapeutic Goods Administration|TGA]], the national agency responsible for regulation of pharmaceuticals) cancelled the registration of lumiracoxib in Australia due to concerns that it may cause liver failure.[http://www.tga.gov.au/media/2007/070811-lumiracoxib.htm Medicines Regulator cancels registration of anti inflammatory drug, Lumiracoxib] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603202146/http://www.tga.gov.au/media/2007/070811-lumiracoxib.htm |date=2009-06-03 }}, ''[[Therapeutic Goods Administration]]'', 11 August 2007. Retrieved on 2007-08-11 According to the TGA's Principal Medical Adviser, Dr Rohan Hammett, as of 10 August 2007 the TGA had received 8 reports of serious adverse liver reactions to the drug, including two deaths and two liver transplants.
"The TGA and its expert advisory committee, the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (ADRAC), have urgently investigated these reports. ADRAC has today recommended the cancellation of the registration of Lumiracoxib due to the severity of the reported side effects associated with this drug," Dr Hammett said. "The TGA has taken this advice to cancel the registration of Lumiracoxib in order to prevent further cases of severe liver damage. "It seems that the longer people are on the medicine, the greater the chance of liver injury. The TGA is, therefore, advising people to stop taking the Lumiracoxib immediately and to discuss alternative treatments with their doctor," Dr Hammett said.{{cite web |url=http://www.tga.gov.au/media/2007/070811-lumiracoxib.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603202146/http://www.tga.gov.au/media/2007/070811-lumiracoxib.htm |archivedate=2009-06-03 |df= }}
New Zealand has followed suit with Australia in recalling Prexige.{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/category/story.cfm?c_id=278&objectid=10459030 |title=NZ regulators ban arthritis drug |date=21 August 2007 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}} On October 3, 2007, Health Canada requested sales of Prexige to stop. Novartis has agreed to the request and has taken steps to do so.http://www.novartis.ca/downloads/en/letters/prexige_fact_20071003_e.pdf{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On December 13, 2007, the European Medicines Agency recommended the withdrawal for Prexige from all EU markets.[http://www.emea.europa.eu/pdfs/human/press/pr/PR_Lumiracoxib_57930107en.pdf Press release: European Medicines Agency recommends withdrawal of the marketing authorisations for lumiracoxib-containing medicines, 13 December 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911153940/http://www.emea.europa.eu/pdfs/human/press/pr/PR_Lumiracoxib_57930107en.pdf |date=11 September 2008 }} On January 17, 2008, the [[Philippines]] [[Department of Health]] ordered [[Novartis]] Healthcare Phils. Inc. (Novartis) to remove (recall) all lumiracoxib from local drug stores in 2 weeks due to the harmful effects of the drug (potential serious [[liver]]-related side effects, hepatotoxicity or malfunction of the [[lung]]s).[https://archive.is/20070709212017/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=105842 Abs-Cbn Interactive, DOH recalls lumiracoxib, sets two-week deadline] On July 22, 2008, The [[Brazil]]ian [[National Health Surveillance Agency]] ordered the withdrawal of 100 mg formulations of lumiracoxib and suspended marketing of the 400 mg formulation for 90 days,{{cite news |url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/cotidiano/ult95u425127.shtml |title=Anvisa cancela registro do Prexige; consumidor deve substituir medicamento |date=July 22, 2008 |accessdate=2008-07-22 |work=[[Folha de S. Paulo]] |language=Portuguese}} after a three-year safety review found a marked increase in adverse event reports; 35% of lumiracoxib-associated adverse events reported worldwide between July 2005 and April 2008 were found to have occurred in Brazil.{{cite press release |url=http://www.anvisa.gov.br/divulga/noticias/2008/220708_1.htm |title=Anvisa cancela registro do antiinflamatório Prexige |date=July 22, 2008 |accessdate=2008-07-22 |publisher=[[National Health Surveillance Agency|Anvisa]] |language=Portuguese}} Lumiracoxib was definitively withdrawn from the Brazilian market on October 3, 2008.{{cite news |url=http://noticias.terra.com.br/brasil/interna/0,,OI3230378-EI715,00-Anvisa+suspende+venda+e+uso+de+antiinflamatorios.html |title=Anvisa suspende venda e uso de 2 antiinflamatórios |date=October 3, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-03 |publisher=Terra |language=Portuguese}} On November 12, 2008, INVIMA, the [[Colombia]]n National Institute for Food and Drug Surveillance ordered the withdrawal of all presentations of lumiracoxib (Prexige), due to the international reports on hepatotoxicity. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.drugdevelopment-technology.com/projects/prexige/ Prexige] *[https://www.forbes.com/2002/04/19/0419nvs.html Forbes] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061113214436/http://www.pharma.us.novartis.com/newsroom/pressReleases/releaseDetail.jsp?PRID=1003 FDA request more information September 23, 2003] *[http://www.npsradar.org.au/site.php?page=1&content=/npsradar/content/lumiracoxib.html NPS RADAR] *[http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/AC/05/briefing/2005-4090B2_02_Novartis-Lumiracoxib.pdf FDA - Background Document for Lumiracoxib 1/13/2005] *http://www.nzherald.co.nz/category/story.cfm?c_id=278&objectid=10459030 {{Anti-inflammatory and antirheumatic products}} {{Prostanoidergics}} [[Category:COX-2 inhibitors]] [[Category:Withdrawn drugs]] [[Category:Hepatotoxins]] [[Category:Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs]] [[Category:Chloroarenes]] [[Category:Fluoroarenes]] [[Category:Acetic acids]]

{{lead rewrite|date=May 2018}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Michigan Womyn's Music Festival | image = Michigan Womyn's Music Festival logo.png | caption = | location = [[Hart Township, Michigan|Hart, Michigan]] | years_active = 1976–2015 | founders = | dates = August | genre = [[Women's music]] | website = [http://michfest.com/ michfest.com] }} The '''Michigan Womyn's Music Festival''', often referred to as '''MWMF''' or '''Michfest''', and called the "Original Womyn's Woodstock",Edwalds, Loraine; Stocker, Midge (eds.) ''The Woman-Centered Economy: Ideals, Reality, and the Space in Between'', Third Side Press, 1995. was an international [[Feminism|feminist]] [[music festival]] held every August from 1976 to 2015 in [[Oceana County, Michigan]], USA, near [[Hart Township, Michigan|Hart Township]], in a small wooded area referred to as "The Land" by MichFest organizers and attendees. The event was completely built, staffed, run and attended by women. Attendees described attending the event as a powerful and unique experience for them.{{cite journal|last1=Odahl-Ruan|first1=Charlynn|last2=McConnell|first2=Elizabeth|last3=Shattell|first3=Mona|last4=Kozlowski|first4=Christine|date=June 15, 2015|title=Empowering Women through Alternative Settings: Michigan Womyn’s Music Festival|url=https://www.gjcpp.org/en/article.php?issue=19&article=105|journal=Global Journal of Community Psychology Practice|volume=6|issue=1|issn=2163-8667}}{{cite web|url=http://www.feministcurrent.com/2016/08/05/women-grieve-michfest-look-forward-new-gatherings/|title=Women grieve the loss of Michfest online, look forward to new gatherings|last1=Cox|first1=Susan|date=August 5, 2016|website=Feminist Current|accessdate=25 May 2018}} Lisa Vogel, founder and organizer of MWMF, described the intention of the festival as being for "[[womyn-born womyn]]". Controversy about Michfest's objective to be a space for womyn-born-womyn led to protests by [[trans women]] and the 2014 call by [[LGBT]] civil rights advocacy group [[Equality Michigan]] ("EM") to boycott the Festival,{{cite web|last1=Equality Michigan|title=End Transgender Exclusion from Michfest|url=https://genderidentitywatch.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/take-action-now-_-equality-michigan.pdf|website=Gender Identity Watch|date=July 28, 2014}} which was joined by the [[Human Rights Campaign]],{{cite web|last1=Sherouse|first1=Beth|title=Michigan Womyn’s Music Festival|url=http://www.hrc.org/blog/michigan-womyns-music-festival|website=[[Human Rights Campaign]]|date=July 30, 2014}} the [[GLAAD|Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]],{{cite web|title=GLAAD President/CEO Sarah Kate Ellis and wife pen op-ed supporting trans inclusion at Michfest|url=https://www.glaad.org/blog/glaad-presidentceo-sarah-kate-ellis-and-wife-pen-op-ed-supporting-trans-inclusion-michfest|website=[[GLAAD]]|date=August 8, 2014}} the [[National Center for Lesbian Rights]], and the [[National LGBTQ Task Force]]. The festival held its final event in August 2015.{{cite web|last1=Ring|first1=Trudy|title=This Year's Michigan Womyn's Music Festival Will Be the Last|url=https://www.advocate.com/michfest/2015/04/21/years-michigan-womyns-music-festival-will-be-last|website=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=April 21, 2015|accessdate=June 13, 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|title=Dear Sisters, Amazon, Festival family|url=https://www.facebook.com/michfest/posts/10153186431364831|website=[[Facebook]]|date=April 21, 2015|accessdate=22 February 2018}} ==History== {{Radical feminism sidebar|expanded=Actions and ideas}} ===Background=== America's first "[[women's music]] festivals" began appearing in the early 1970s, starting with day festivals at the [[California State University, Sacramento|Sacramento State]] and [[San Diego State University]] campuses, the Midwest Women's Festival held in Missouri, the Boston Women's Music Festival, and the National Women's Music Festival at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]]. These first regional women-only events exposed audiences to feminist and [[Coming out|openly lesbian]] artists, most of whom operated independently of the mainstream recording industry. Festival gatherings offered an alternative to urban bars, coffeehouses and protest marches, which were some of the few opportunities for lesbians to meet one another in the early 1970s. The [[separatist feminism|feminist separatism]] of the spaces was a direct outgrowth of and solidarity with the activism created by black power and other racial solidarity movements.[[Ariel Levy (journalist)|Levy, Ariel]]. [http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/03/02/090302fa_fact_levy "Lesbian Nation"], ''The New Yorker'', March 2, 2009. In a 2013 "Letter to the Community", Michfest founder and organizer Lisa Vogel explained MWMF's [[womyn-born womyn]] intention as a [[women-only space]]: "The Festival, for a single precious week, is intended for womyn who at birth were deemed female, who were raised as girls, and who identify as womyn. I believe that womyn-born womyn (WBW) is a lived experience that constitutes its own distinct gender identity."{{cite web|last1=Vogel|first1=Lisa|title=Letter to the Community|url=http://michfest.com/letter-to-the-community-4_11_13/|website=Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|date=April 11, 2013}} ===Foundation and early years=== As a private, women-only camping event, the Michigan festival was founded in 1976 by 19-year-old Lisa Vogel, who, with sister Kristie Vogel and friend Mary Kindig, planned an event along the lines of the recent Boston Women's Music Festival and the Midwest Women's Festival.{{cite web|last=Greenfield|first=Beth|title=Intense, Unique No-Man's Lands|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/26/travel/26ahead.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 26, 2006}} ===1980s=== In 1982, the Festival, then in its seventh year, moved to its long-term 650-acre location near Hart, Michigan, attracting the largest audience hitherto (upwards of 8,000 campers). Gradually, it added an acoustic stage (and an August night [[open mic]] stage) in addition to day stage and night stage programming. After much discussion, cement-paved walkways were added to ease access for women with mobility challenges and [[Baby transport|baby strollers]]. Barbara "Boo" Price became Lisa Vogel's business partner after the 1985 festival and was increasingly involved with production until the two parted ways in 1994. The 1980s saw many unique challenges, including the production of a 10th anniversary double album in 1985, the growth of the gathering to five days (with new intensive workshops) by 1986, the extraordinary thunderstorms of the "Harmonic Convergence" year in 1987, and an outbreak of [[shigella]] in 1988 (the swift handling of which was praised by both local and national health inspectors).[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19880820&id=cm8fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=034EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6037,3712374 "Health Agencies In State Warned of Diarrhea Outbreak"], Milwaukee Journal, August 1988{{cite journal | pmid = 2006648 | volume=133 | title=An outbreak of shigellosis at an outdoor music festival | journal=Am J Epidemiol | pages=608–15 | last1 = Lee | first1 = LA | last2 = Ostroff | first2 = SM | last3 = McGee | first3 = HB | last4 = Johnson | first4 = DR | last5 = Downes | first5 = FP | last6 = Cameron | first6 = DN | last7 = Bean | first7 = NH | last8 = Griffin | first8 = PM}} ===1990s=== During the 1990s the Festival updated structurally and musically to expand styles of stage performance for a new generation of performers, adding a runway to the Night Stage, a [[Moshing|mosh pit]], and acts including the [[Indigo Girls]] and [[Tribe 8]].{{cite web|last=Scauzillo|first=Retts|title=Retts Returns to the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|url=http://lesbianlife.about.com/od/lesbiantravels/a/RettsatMichigan.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=February 23, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206020219/http://lesbianlife.about.com/od/lesbiantravels/a/RettsatMichigan.htm|archive-date=February 6, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Writing from a personal perspective for the ''Village Voice'' in fall 1994, artist and Festival kitchen worker Gretchen Phillips said: "I had never seen so many breasts before, so many bare asses, so much damn skin on such a vast terrain. I decided to make that weekend all about studying my body issues" and "I've always used Mich as a place to charge my batteries for the rest of the year, planning my life around being there in August and learning my lessons, both fun and hard."{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Gretchen|authorlink=Gretchen Phillips|title=I Moshed at Mich|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/|accessdate=3 January 2012|newspaper=The Village Voice|date=September 6, 1994}} Playwright [[Carolyn Gage]] later said: "At Michfest, she can experience a degree of safety that is not available to any woman any time anywhere except at the festival. And what does that mean? It means she achieves a level of relaxation, physical, psychic, cellular, that she had never experienced before. She is free, sisters. She is free. Often for the first time in her life."{{cite book|last=Cage|first=Carolyn|title=Hotter Than Hell: The 2011 Lesbian Tent Revival|year=2011|url=http://carolyngage.weebly.com/hotter-than-hell.html|pages=140–41|quote=At Michfest, she can experience a degree of safety that is not available to any woman any time anywhere except at the Festival. And what does that mean? It means she achieves a level of relaxation, physical, psychic, cellular, that she had never experienced before. She is free, sisters. She is free. Often for the first time in her life.}} In 1999, author and feminist scholar [[Bonnie Morris]]{{cite web|url=http://womensstudies.berkeley.edu/about/department-faculty/bonnie-morris/|title=Bonnie Morris|date=2018|website=Gender & Women's Studies|publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley]]|accessdate=21 May 2018}} described it as "An entire city run by and for lesbian feminists. Utopia revealed. And Eden—built by Eves."{{cite book|title=Eden Built By Eves: The Culture of Women's Music Festivals|last=Morris|first=Bonnie J|publisher=[[Alyson Publications]]|year=1999|isbn=1-55583-477-9|edition=1st|page=60}} === Final Festival === MichFest celebrated its 40th anniversary in 2015. On April 21, Lisa Vogel announced via ''[[Facebook]]'' that it would also be the last festival. An opinion published in ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'' by a festivalgoer speculated that the ongoing controversy regarding trans women was to blame.{{cite web|last1=Anderson-Minshal|first1=Diane|title=Op-ed: Michfest's Founder Chose to Shut Down Rather Than Change With the Times|url=https://www.advocate.com/commentary/2015/04/24/op-ed-michfests-founder-chose-shut-down-rather-change-times|website=The Advocate|date=April 24, 2015|accessdate=13 September 2018}} Vogel wrote in her statement:
There have been struggles; there is no doubt about that. This is part of our truth, but it is not--and never has been--our defining story. The Festival has been the crucible for nearly every critical cultural and political issue the lesbian feminist community has grappled with for four decades. Those struggles have been a beautiful part of our collective strength; they have never been a weakness.
==Functioning, activities and services== Attendance at the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival ranged from 3,000 to 10,000.{{cite news|last=Core|first=Lindsay|title=How the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival's Topless Womyn Changed My Lesbian Life Forever|url=http://www.autostraddle.com/how-the-michigan-womyns-music-festivals-topless-womyn-changed-my-lesbian-life-forever/|newspaper=Autostraddle|date=August 30, 2009}} Women build all of the stages, run the lighting and [[sound reinforcement system|sound systems]], make the trash collection rounds, serve as electricians, mechanics, security, medical and psychological support, cook meals for thousands over open fire pits, provide childcare, and facilitate workshops covering various topics of interest to the attendees, who are referred to as "festies". Hundreds of women spent upwards of a month out on the land building the festival from the ground up because it was torn down after each event ended, leaving the land as close to how it was found as possible.{{cite web|last=Messman-Rucker |first=Ariel |url=http://www.curvemag.com/Curve-Magazine/Web-Articles-2008/Welcome-Home-to-the-Michigan-Womyns-Festival/ |title=Welcome Home to the Michigan Womyns Festival |publisher=Curve |date= |accessdate=February 22, 2012}} Community decisions were made through worker community meetings where the youngest members of the community were given as much access to participate as the oldest. Community service support included ASL translation at every performance, mental and physical health care, AA meetings, camping for disabled women, as well as a tent solely for women of color. While men were not allowed at the Festival, male children age 4 and under were allowed within the festival. Childcare for girls and boys aged 5 and under is provided by Sprouts, and for 5 and over girls the main venue is "Gaia Girls". There is also teen circle. Brother Sun Boys Camp was available for boys aged 5 to 10.{{cite web|last=McMahon |first=Becky |url=http://www.gaypeopleschronicle.com/stories05/august/0819051.htm |title=Michigan festival, in its 30th year, is like a reunion |publisher=Gay People's Chronicle |date=August 19, 2005 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}} ==Production and performances== The Festival created a space for performers of all genres to share their music. While many artists had earned mainstream success after their performance at the festival, the Festival supported diverse performances.[http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/A2267197, Goldin-Perschbacher, Shana. “Michigan Womyn’s Music Festival."] The Grove Dictionary of American Music (2014). Oxford Music Online. Web. 21 Feb. 2015. Genres include classical, jazz, folk, hard rock, acoustic, bluegrass and gospel.{{jstor|25794545}}, "Quinn, Liz. “Michigan Womyn’s Music Festival.” Off Our Backs 14.9 (Oct. 1984): 24-25. Print." The Festival created a high-tech production with three stages in a rural outdoor venue.{{cite web|url=http://www.mjaudio.com/index.php?page=about&category=Crew_Bios&display=6,|title=myrna johnston audio|publisher=}} Musicians and artists who performed at the festival represented a range of lesbian and womyn's art and music, from [[Sarah Bettens]], [[Laura Nyro]], [[Hattie Gossett]], [[Sweet Honey in the Rock]], [[Tracy Chapman]], [[Holly Near]], [[Team Dresch]], [[Kathleen Hanna]], [[Tribe 8]], [[Sia Furler|Sia]], [[Staceyann Chin]] and many more. ==Controversy about transgender people== Controversy over the Festival's determination to remain a space for [[cisgender]] [[females]] led to protests by trans women and their allies, and a boycott of the Festival by Equality Michigan in 2014. The boycott was joined by the Human Rights Campaign ("HRC"), the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation ("GLAAD"), the National Center for Lesbian Rights ("NCLR"), and the National LGBTQ Task Force ("The Task Force"). In response to the anti-Festival petition, the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival stated: "MWMF is not just a party. It is a space wherein females—who have been subjected to all manner of degradation from the moment of their first breath—can unpack and put down the oppressions that are directly tied to that experience under patriarchy...Equality Michigan has initiated a petition and call to action against the Festival based on misrepresentations, purposeful omissions, and selective editing of prior Festival statements on this issue."{{cite web|last1=Vogel|first1=Lisa|title=Michfest Response to Equality Michigan’s Call For Boycott|url=http://michfest.com/statement-from-michigan-womyns-music-festival-8_1_4/|website=Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|date=August 1, 2014}} Lisa Vogel referred to the boycott as "[[McCarthyism|McCarthy-era]] blacklist tactics".{{cite web|author=BTL Staff|title=Michfest Responds: We Have a Few Demands Of Our Own|url=http://www.pridesource.com/article.html?article=67561|website=Pride Source|publisher=[[Between the Lines (newspaper)|Between The Lines]]|date=August 18, 2014}} Michfest supporters responded to the shunning with social media posts, letters,{{cite web|last1=Morris|first1=Bonnie J.|title=Letter to GLAAD|url=http://www.michfestmatters.com/letter-to-glaad-by-bonnie-j-morris-ph-d/|dead-url=yes|publisher=Voices From The Land|date=September 12, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022032643/http://www.michfestmatters.com/letter-to-glaad-by-bonnie-j-morris-ph-d/|archivedate=October 22, 2014|df=}} and online media presentations such as "Myths and The Truth About the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival".{{cite web|title=Myths and The Truth About the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|url=http://www.thetruthaboutthemichiganfestival.com|website=thetruthaboutthemichiganfestival.com|date=September 2014}} NCLR and The Task Force withdrew their support of the boycott,{{cite web|url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/lgbt/NCLRs-Kate-Kendell-removes-Michfest-boycott-signature/51126.html|title=NCLR and Task Force remove names from Michfest petition|last1=Toce|first1=Sarah|date=April 9, 2015|website=[[Windy City Times]]}} and Equality Michigan's executive director resigned from the organization.{{cite web|url=https://gendertrender.wordpress.com/2015/04/14/creator-of-michfest-boycott-emily-dievendorf-resigns-as-executive-director-of-equality-michigan/|title=Creator of Michfest Boycott Emily Dievendorf Resigns as Executive Director of Equality Michigan|last1=GallusMag|date=April 14, 2015|website=GenderTrender}} The womyn-born-womyn intention first came to attention in 1991 after a [[transsexual]] festival-goer, Nancy Burkholder, was asked to leave the festival when several women recognized her as a trans woman and expressed discomfort with her presence in the space.{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Cristan|title=Michigan Womyn’s Music Festival|url=http://transadvocate.com/michigan-womyns-music-festival_n_8943.htm|website=The TransAdvocate|date=April 9, 2013}} In August 2014, Lisa Vogel apologized for this incident, stating: {{quote|Over 20 years ago, we asked Nancy Burkholder, a trans womon, to leave the Land. That was wrong, and for that, we are sorry. We, alongside the rest of the LGBTQ community, have learned and changed a great deal over our 39‐year history. We speak to you now in 2014 after two decades of evolution; an evolution grown from our willingness to stay in hard conversations, just as we do every year around issues of race, ability, class and gender. Since that single incident, Festival organizers have never asked a trans womon to leave the Festival.{{cite web|title=We Have a Few Demands of our Own: Michfest Response to NCLR and HRC endorsing EQM petition to boycott|url=http://michfest.com/we-have-a-few-demands-of-our-own-michfest-response-to-nclr-and-hrc-endorsing-eqm-petition-to-boycott-‐-81814/|website=Michfest (Michigan Womyn's Music Festival)|date=August 18, 2014}}}} In a 2005 interview with [[Amy Ray]], Vogel discussed the intention within its informing political framework and stated: "I feel very strongly that having a space for women, who are born women, to come together for a week, is a healthy, whole, loving space to provide for women who have that experience. To label that as [[transphobia|transphobic]] is, to me, as misplaced as saying the women-of-color tent is racist, or to say that a transsexual-only space, a gathering of folks of women who are born men is misogynist. I have always in my heart believed in the politics and the culture of separate time and space."{{cite web|title=Correspondence: 2005-06-13: Amy - Michigan Womyn's Fest Interviews: Interview #3|url=http://www.indigogirls.com/correspondence/2005/2005-06-13-a/interview03.html|website=Indigo Girls|date=June 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319145443/http://www.indigogirls.com/correspondence/2005/2005-06-13-a/interview03.html|archivedate=March 19, 2006}} After the Burkholder incident, a protest movement against the womyn-born-womyn intention was organized. Opponents contended that it constituted [[discrimination]] against transsexual and [[transgender]] people, many of whom identified as women and were legally female. In 1994, a protest camp was created across the road from the Festival called [[Camp Trans]]{{cite web|last1=Press Release|title=Michigan Womyn's Music Festival Sets the Record "Straight"|url=http://eminism.org/michigan/20060822-mwmf.txt|website=Eminism.org|date=August 22, 2006}} (and later, "Son of Camp Trans"). In 2006, a trans woman and Camp Trans organizer named Lorraine was sold a ticket at the box office.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Supporters of trans women inclusion then issued a press release declaring, incorrectly, that the womyn-born-womyn objective was no longer in effect.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} In response, Lisa Vogel reiterated the Festival's adherence to the intention, and also confronted the distribution of misinformation and accusations of [[transphobia]] by Camp Trans, in an August 2006 press release: {{Quote|"From its inception the Festival has been home to womyn who could be considered gender outlaws, either because of their sexual orientation (lesbian, bisexual, polyamorous, etc.) or their gender presentation (butch, bearded, androgynous, femme - and everything in between). Many womyn producing and attending the Michigan Festival are gender variant womyn...We strongly assert there is nothing transphobic with choosing to spend one week with womyn who were born as, and have lived their lives as, womyn...Supporting womyn-born womyn space is no more inherently transphobic than supporting womyn of color space is racist."}} The Michigan Womyn's Music Festival staunchly defended its raison d'être, described by Vogel as "a predominantly lesbian community...defined by lesbian culture" with "a focus on the experience of those born female, who've lived their lives subjected to oppression based on the sole fact of their being female." In her statement, Vogel added that "it is not the inclusion of trans women at Festival that we resist; it is the erasure of the specificity of female experience." The protests against womyn-born womyn spaces resulted in some artists who had been invited to and/or performed at the Festival losing contracts or forced to cancel appearances because of their support, or their appearance of support, for the festival's intention.{{cite web|last1=Hill-Meyer|first1=Tobi|title=Bitch Pulled From Festival Lineup|url=http://bilerico.lgbtqnation.com/2010/05/bitch_pulled_from_festival_lineup.php|website=The Bilerico Project|publisher=LGBTQ Nation|date=May 21, 2010}} Other performers were physically threatened by pro-inclusion supporters, faced verbal harassment and bomb threats.{{cite web|title=Response to the violence against the Butchies and Le Tigre|url=http://eminism.org/michigan/20011007-carns.txt|website=Eminism.org|date=October 7, 2001|accessdate=January 6, 2014}} In October 2013, filmmaker Sara St. Martin Lynne was asked to resign from the board of the Bay Area Girls Rock Camp for attending the festival (the organization's Festival-related team had raised funds for BAGRC).{{cite web|last1=St. Martin Lynne|first1=Sara|title=Letter of Resignation from the Board of Bay Area Girls Rock Camp|url=http://fishwithoutabicycle.com/2013/10/16/letter-of-resignation-from-the-board-of-bay-area-girls-rock-camp|website=Fish Without a Bicycle|date=October 16, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024010809/http://fishwithoutabicycle.com/2013/10/16/letter-of-resignation-from-the-board-of-bay-area-girls-rock-camp|archivedate=October 24, 2013}} In response to an April 2013 [[Change.org]] petition by trans activist Red Durkin asking performers to boycott MWMF until trans women were included,{{cite web|title=Heated debate follows Michigan Fest boycott petition|url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/lgbt/Heated-debate-follows-Michigan-Fest-boycott-petition/42349.html|website=[[Windy City Times]]|date=April 12, 2013|accessdate=April 27, 2013}} Lisa Vogel released a statement reaffirming the Festival's viewpoint: {{Quote|"I reject the assertion that creating a time and place for WBW to gather is inherently transphobic. This is a false dichotomy and one that prevents progress and understanding. I believe in the integrity of autonomous space used to gather and celebrate for any group, whether that autonomous space is defined by age, race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, ability, gender, class or any other identity. Whatever spaces we carve out in our community to encourage healing and rejuvenation should be accepted, and we should support each other in this endeavor. Nobody should be asked to erase the need for autonomous spaces to demonstrate that they are sisters in struggle."{{cite web|last1=Vogel|first1=Lisa|title=Letter to the Community|url=http://www.curvemag.com/Curve-Magazine/Web-Articles-2013/Letter-to-the-Community/|website=[[Curve (magazine)|Curve]]|date=April 11, 2013|accessdate=April 27, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130924233052/http://www.curvemag.com/Curve-Magazine/Web-Articles-2013/Letter-to-the-Community/|archivedate=September 24, 2013}}}} However, several trans women attended the festival openly and volunteered to work on crew.{{cite web|last1=Kelly|first1=Bryn|title=XOJane It Happened To Me: I WAS A TRANS WOMAN WHO WENT TO MICHFEST|url=http://brynkelly.tumblr.com/post/93890798746/xojane-it-happened-to-me-i-was-a-trans-woman-who|website=brynkelly.tumblr.com|publisher=[[Tumblr]]|date=August 5, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Kalafarski|first1=Alice|title=Just Another Woman at Michfest|url=http://www.prettyqueer.com/2011/09/01/just-another-woman-at-michfest/|website=Pretty Queer Magazine|date=September 1, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118202139/http://www.prettyqueer.com/2011/09/01/just-another-woman-at-michfest/#more-1915|archivedate=January 18, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Hill-Meyer|first=Tobi|title=A Trans Woman at Michigan Women's Music Festival|url=http://www.bilerico.com/2008/08/another_trans_woman_at_mich_fest.php|website=The Bilerico Project|publisher=LGBTQ Nation|date=August 15, 2008|accessdate=April 27, 2013}} The presence of transgender women at MichFest was known to many attendees.{{cite web|last1=Cogswell|first1=Kelly|title=Dyke-Baiting, Trans-Hating, and the MichFest Debacle|url=http://gaycitynews.nyc/dyke-baiting-trans-hating-michfest-debacle/|website=[[Gay City News]]|date=April 29, 2015|accessdate=22 February 2018}} ==Photography== Photographer Angela Jimenez spent five years, from 2003 to 2008, documenting the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival, specifically focusing on the workers who create the festival each year. Several artists, including Desdemona Burgin and Sara St. Martin Lynne have created videos and other art celebrating the freeing experience of the "Land." These productions specifically detail the experiences of liberation that females feel in escaping male dominated culture and spaces for the Festival.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YgaV_dEKwUs|title=Brooklyn Rolls Hard to Michfest 2009 (Part 2)|first=|last=upeoplethemovie|date=21 August 2009|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ut3X6Xdrbuk|title=Michigan Womyn's Music Festival - MICHFEST|first=|last=BUNTYB007|date=20 May 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hdPEFXkQfmg|title=Love from the Land - A love letter from the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|first=|last=Fish Without A Bicycle|date=23 April 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7QLpDnIG18s|title=Because I Came to Michigan - A video about the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|first=|last=Fish Without A Bicycle|date=3 April 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}} In 2014, a new website was created, compiling stories from women who have attended the festival, about what the festival means to them.{{cite web |url=http://www.michfestmatters.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141105050514/http://www.michfestmatters.com/ |archivedate=2014-11-05 |df= }} Michfest Matters: Voices from the Land == Michfest Half-Way Soirée== For years, women created small gatherings outside of the festival and August in their own local communities, consisting mostly of small house parties and potlucks. After attending a festival in August 2004 and a pre-fest potluck, festie and entrepreneur, Lisa A. Snyder, was inspired to take the gatherings to the next level by creating a party that highlighted pieces of the festival in the middle of New York City. In 2005, she created the very first "Michfest Half-Way Soirée", a party that supported the local Michigan Womyn's Music Festival community, female musicians, and women-owned businesses. The worker community and festie community were encouraged to co-mingle and introduce new "festie virgins" to feel a slice of the festival energy, halfway to August. The benefit, the first of its kind (started by Snyder in [[New York City]]) also created buzz about the festival, appearing several times in ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]'' New York {{cite web|last=London|first=Syd|title=We were there: Michigan Womyn's Music Festival Benefit|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/things-to-do/own-this-city-blog/86336/we-were-there-michigan-womyns-music-festival-benefit|publisher=Time Out New York|accessdate=10 January 2012}} and most recently in the February 2011 issue of ''[[GO (American magazine)|GO]]'' in "The Very Best of New York City Music" section.{{cite journal|last=Schroeder|first=Stephanie|title=The Very Best of NYC Music|journal=Go Magazine|date=February 2011|issue=February 2011 Issue|url=http://www.gomag.com/article/the_very_best_of_nyc_musi20/|accessdate=10 January 2012}} In the 2010s, additional locations for the Half-Way to Michfest Parties (sometimes also called Mid-Way Parties or Michfest Half-Way Parties) have begun to pop up across the United States. Known locations include [[Chicago]]; [[San Francisco Bay Area]]; [[Portland, Oregon]]; [[Boston]]; [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]]; [[Santa Cruz, California]]; [[Syracuse, New York]]; [[Long Beach, California]]; [[Western Massachusetts]]; [[Tampa, Florida]]; [[Yellow Springs, Ohio]] and [[Bellingham, Washington]].{{cite web|last=V|first=Kingsley|title=Half Way to Michfest Parties|url=http://www.alotoflife.com/Vs_Version_Blog/Entries/2009/1/26_Half_Way_to_Michfest_Parties.html|accessdate=10 January 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226163352/http://www.alotoflife.com/Vs_Version_Blog/Entries/2009/1/26_Half_Way_to_Michfest_Parties.html|archive-date=26 December
