{{Infobox Musical | name =Mrs Henderson Presents | subtitle = | image =Mrs Henderson Presents musical.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption =Theatre Royal, Bath promotional artwork | music =[[George Fenton]]
Simon Chamberlain | lyrics =[[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]] | book =[[Terry Johnson (dramatist)|Terry Johnson]] | basis =2005 film ''[[Mrs Henderson Presents]]'' | setting =1937 to 1940 [[London]] | premiere_date ={{Start date|df=yes|2015|08|26}} | premiere_location =[[Theatre Royal, Bath]] | productions = 2015 [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]
2016 [[West End theatre|West End]]
2017 [[Toronto]] | awards }} '''''Mrs Henderson Presents''''' is a musical comedy with music by [[George Fenton]] and Simon Chamberlain, with lyrics by [[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]] and a book by [[Terry Johnson (dramatist)|Terry Johnson]]. Based on the 2005 film ''[[Mrs Henderson Presents]]'', the musical received its world premiere at the [[Theatre Royal, Bath]] in 2015 and transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End's]] [[Noel Coward Theatre]] in February 2016. The film was based on the true story of [[Laura Henderson]] and [[London]]'s [[Windmill Theatre]]. ==Background== The musical is based on the 2005 film ''[[Mrs Henderson Presents]]''.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/stage-version-of-mrs.-henderson-presents-will-premiere-in-summer-2015-333463 | title=Stage Version of Mrs. Henderson Presents Will Premiere in Summer 2015 | publisher=[[Playbill]] | website=playbill.com | date=17 October 2014 | accessdate=8 September 2015}} The film was based on the true story of [[London]]'s [[Windmill Theatre]]{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-news/10890395/Mrs-Henderson-Presents-heads-for-the-West-End.html | title=Mrs Henderson Presents heads for the West End | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | website=telegraph.co.uk | date=11 June 2014 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} and its owner [[Laura Henderson]], who transformed the theatre and produced [[Revudeville]] shows featuring static naked tableaux girls, exploiting a loophole in the [[Lord Chamberlain]]'s [[Lord Cromer]] censorship laws.{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/reviews/mrs-henderson-presents-theatre-royal-bath-review-lavish-furs-and-acidic-put-downs-10509947.html | title=Lavish furs and acidic put-downs | publisher=[[The Independent]] | website=independent.co.uk | date=20 September 2015 | accessdate=24 January 2016}}{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3648187/Windmill-always-nude-but-never-rude.html | title=Windmill: always nude but never rude | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | website=telegraph.co.uk | date=24 November 2005 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} In June 2014, it was first revealed by producer John Reid that an adaption was in the works,{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/06-2014/mrs-henderson-presents-west-end_34712.html | title=Mrs Henderson Presents next in line for screen-to-stage treatment? | publisher=Whats On Stage |website=whatsonstage.com | date=11 June 2014 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} with a workshop taking place the same year.{{cite web | url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2014/terry-johnson-direct-stage-premiere-mrs-henderson-presents/ | title=Terry Johnson to direct premiere of Mrs Henderson Presents musical | publisher=[[The Stage]] |website=thestage.co.uk | date=16 October 2014 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} On 16 October 2014, the musical was officially confirmed and it was announced that the show would receive its world premiere in summer 2015, with a view to a [[West End theatre|West End]] transfer.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/stage-version-of-mrs.-henderson-presents-will-premiere-in-summer-2015-333463 | title=Stage Version of Mrs. Henderson Presents Will Premiere in Summer 2015 | publisher=[[Playbill]] |website=playbill.com | date=17 October 2014 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} The musical is directed by{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3213373/Mrs-Henderson-Presents-review-Witty-gags-risque-girls-make-fun-night-frolics-writes-QUENTIN-LETTS.html | title=Phwoarsome! Witty gags and very risque girls make for a fun night of frolics at Mrs Henderson Presents | publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |website=dailymail.co.uk | date=27 August 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} and has a book by [[Terry Johnson (dramatist)|Terry Johnson]],{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/bath-theatre/news/mrs-henderson-presents-royal-bath_36153.html | title=Mrs Henderson Presents musical confirms Bath premiere | publisher=Whats On Stage |website=whatsonstage.com | date=17 October 2014 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} based on an original screenplay by [[Martin Sherman]],{{cite web | url=http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/2015/10/09/mrs-henderson-presents-to-transfer-to-the-west-end-114156/ | title=Mrs. Henderson Presents to transfer to the West End | publisher=The Hollywood News | website=thehollywoodnews.com | date=9 October 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} with choreography by Andrew Wright,{{cite web | url=http://theatreroyal.org.uk/page/3028/Mrs-Henderson-Presents/972#Cast | title=Mrs Henderson Presents Cast and Creative | publisher=[[Theatre Royal, Bath]] | website=theatreroyal.org.uk | accessdate=23 January 2016}} set design by Tim Shortall, costume design by Paul Wills, lighting by Ben Ormerod and [[magic (illusion)|magic]] consultancy by [[Scott Penrose]].{{cite journal |journal=Theatre Royal, Bath programme |title=Mrs Henderson Presents |date=August 2015}} ==Production history== The show's premiere production began previews at the [[Theatre Royal, Bath|Theatre Royal]] in Bath, on 15 August 2015, with its official opening night coming on 26 August, for a limited run until 25 September 2015.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/mrs.-hendersons-presents-musical-based-on-film-gets-world-premiere-tonight-at-u.ks-theatre-royal-bath-357614 | title=Mrs. Henderson's Presents, Musical Based on Film, Gets World Premiere Tonight | publisher=[[Playbill]] | website=playbill.com | date=14 August 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} Rehearsals began on 7 July 2015.{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/bath-theatre/news/tracie-bennett-mrs-henderson-presents-bath_38225.html | title=Tracie Bennett replaces Janie Dee in Mrs Henderson Presents | publisher=Whats On Stage | website=whatsonstage.com | date=7 July 2015 | accessdate=21 January 2016}} On 6 March 2015, initial casting was announced with the news that [[Janie Dee]] would play the role of [[Laura Henderson]] with [[Emma Williams (actress)|Emma Williams]] playing Maureen.{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/bath-theatre/news/janie-dee-mrs-henderson-presents_37313.html | title=Casting announced for Mrs Henderson Presents musical | publisher=Whats On Stage | website=whatsonstage.com | date=6 March 2015 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} Further notable casting included [[Ian Bartholomew]] as [[Vivian Van Damm]] and [[Mark Hadfield]] as Arthur.{{cite web | url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/uk-regional/article/Full-Cast-Announced-for-MRS-HENDERSON-PRESENTS-at-Theatre-Royal-Bath-20150706 | title=Full Cast Announced for MRS HENDERSON PRESENTS at Theatre Royal Bath | publisher=Broadway World | website=broadwayworld.com | date=6 July 2015 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} On 7 July 2015, it was revealed that Janie Dee had withdrawn from the production prior to rehearsals due to personal reasons and that [[Tracie Bennett]] would replace her in the role of Laura Henderson.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/tracie-bennett-replaces-janie-dee-in-world-premiere-of-mrs.-hendersons-presents-352733 | title=Tracie Bennett Replaces Janie Dee in World Premiere of Mrs. Henderson's Presents | publisher=[[Playbill]] | website=playbill.com | date=7 July 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} Following completion of the musicals tryout in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], it was announced that the show would transfer to the [[Noel Coward Theatre]] in London's [[West End theatre|West End]],{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/west-end-transfer-mrs-henderson-presents_38910.html | title=Mrs Henderson Presents transfers to the West End | publisher=Whats On Stage | website=whatsonstage.com | date=9 October 2015 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} with an official opening night of 16 February 2016, following previews from 9 February.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/tracie-bennett-to-star-in-new-british-musical-based-on-mrs.-hendersons-presents-366459 | title=Tracie Bennett To Star in New British Musical Based on "Mrs. Henderson's Presents" | publisher=[[Playbill]] | website=playbill.com | date=9 October 2015 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} The majority of the cast reprised their roles with the exceptions of [[Mark Hadfield]], who was replaced in the role of Arthur by former [[EastEnders]] actor [[Jamie Foreman]],{{cite web | url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/westend/article/Full-Cast-Announced-for-MRS-HENDERSON-PRESENTS-Jamie-Foreman-Robert-Hands-and-More-Join-Tracie-Bennett-and-Ian-Bartholomew-Feb-16-20160107 | title=Full Cast Announced for MRS. HENDERSON PRESENTS | publisher=Broadway World | website=broadwayworld.com | date=7 January 2016 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} Graham Hoadly who (owing to a prior contractual commitment) was replaced in the role of [[Lord Cromer]] by [[Robert Hands]] and Jane Milligan who was replaced in the role of Lady Conway by Liz Ewing.{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/casting-mrs-henderson-presents-west-end_39455.html | title=Full casting announced for West End transfer of Mrs Henderson Presents | publisher=Whats On Stage | website=whatsonstage.com | date=7 January 2016 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} The West End show garnered mixed reviews and closed after its initial four month run. No official reason was given for the close although it is not believed to have been a financial success. In her 2 star review for the [[Evening Standard]], Fiona Mountford stated that the musical "shares with the film a desperate lack of momentum", and of the songs, "none are memorable".{{cite web | title=Mrs Henderson Presents: Windmill girls story leaves nasty taste | website=Evening Standard | date=February 17, 2016 | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/mrs-henderson-presents-theatre-review-windmill-girls-licked-hitler-but-their-story-leaves-a-nasty-a3182551.html | accessdate=April 5, 2017}} In his 4 star review for [[The Stage]], [[Mark Shenton]] stated that the show "doesn't shy from occasional hard edges. Instead, by concentrating on the backstage lives of the dancers and management of the Windmill, there's more of a jaunty, frequently patriotic, flavour to it – that both sings and occasionally stings.{{cite web | title=Mrs Henderson Presents review at Noel Coward Theatre | website=The Stage | date=February 17, 2016 | url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2016/mrs-henderson-presents-review-at-the-noel-coward-theatre-london/ | accessdate=April 5, 2017}} Prior to its opening in London it was announced that the production would transfer to Toronto in early 2017 and the production opened on March 15, 2017 at the Royal Alexandra Theatre in Toronto, Canada where it played a limited engagement until April 23, 2017. The show was essentially recast although [[Tracie Bennett]] reprised the role of Mrs Henderson, with the cast also including [[Peter Polycarpou]] and [[Evelyn Hoskins]] as Maureen,{{Cite news|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/toronto/article/The-Canadian-Premiere-of-the-West-End-Hit-Musical-MRS-HENDERSON-PRESENTS-Begins-315-20170308|title=The Canadian Premiere of the West End Hit Musical MRS HENDERSON PRESENTS Begins 3/15|last=Desk|first=BWW News|work=BroadwayWorld.com|access-date=2017-03-15|language=en}} The show is now listed as a "Past Production" by Michael Harrison Entertainment. ==Music== The musical features an original score composed by [[George Fenton]] and Simon Chamberlain,{{cite web | url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/stage/theatre/article4538791.ece | title=Mrs Henderson Presents at Theatre Royal, Bath | publisher=[[The Times]] | website=thetimes.co.uk | date=27 August 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} with lyrics by [[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]],{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/mrs-henderson-presents-theater-review-818021 | title=‘Mrs. Henderson Presents’: Theater Review | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=26 August 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/leisure/theatreandarts/13630890.Review__Mrs_Henderson_Presents__Theatre_Royal_Bath/ | title=Review: Mrs Henderson Presents, Theatre Royal Bath | publisher=[[Wiltshire Gazette and Herald]] | website=gazetteandherald.co.uk | accessdate=23 January 2016}} orchestrations by [[Larry Blank]],{{cite web | url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/182381/tracie-bennett-ian-bartholomew-emma-williams-set-for-west-ends-mrs-henderson-presents/ | title=Tracie Bennett, Ian Bartholomew & Emma Williams Set for West End's Mrs. Henderson Presents | publisher=Broadway Dot Com | website=broadway.com | date=9 October 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} sound design by [[Gareth Owen (sound designer)|Gareth Owen]]{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/bath-theatre/shows/mrs-henderson-presents_48776/cast/ | title=Mrs Henderson Presents Cast and Creatives | publisher=Whats On Stage | website=whatsonstage.com | accessdate=23 January 2016}} and musical direction by Mike Dixon.{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/aug/26/mrs-henderson-presents-review-a-shot-in-the-arm-for-the-british-musical | title=Mrs Henderson Presents review: a shot in the arm for the British musical | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | website=theguardian.com | date=26 August 2015 | accessdate=23 January 2016}} ===Musical numbers=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act I{{cite journal |journal=Noel Coward Theatre programme |title=Mrs Henderson Presents |date=February 2016}} * "Everybody Loves the Windmill" - Arthur & the Company * "Mrs Henderson Presents" - Laura Henderson, Vivian Van Damm & the Company * "Whatever Time I Have" - Laura * "Lord Chamberlain's Song" - Lord Cormer, Laure & the Secretary * "What a Waste of a Moon" - Eddie * "Rubens and Renoir" - Vivian, Doris, Vera & Peggy * "Ordinary Girl" - Maureen & Laura * "It Starts With a Dream" - Bertie, Maureen, Doris, Vera, Peggy & the Windmill Girls * "Perfect Dream" - Maureen, Doris, Vera, Peggy, Laura, Lord Cromer, Lady Conway & the Windmill Girls * "Living in a Dream World" - Vivian * "He's Got Another Think Coming" - Bertie, Arthur, Maureen, & the Windmill Girls {{col-break}} ;Act II * "'Women at War' Medley" - The (Reprise)" - Maureen & Eddie * "Now is Not the Time (Reprise)" - Vivian * "Innocent Soldier" - The Company * "If Mountains Were Easy to Climb" - Maureen & Laura * "We Never Close (Reprise)" - The Company * "Walkdown" - The Windmill Orchestra {{col-end}} ===Orchestra=== The musical uses an eight-member orchestra consisting of [[Keyboard instrument|Keyboard]], [[Woodwind]], [[Trumpet]], '''Nacht van de Wansmaak''' (Translation: "Night of Repulsion") is a Flemish-Dutch film festival dedicated to [[cult film]]s, [[exploitation film]]s and other bizarre B-films.
==Concept== The festival is organized by Belgian film director [[Jan Verheyen (film director)|Jan Verheyen]] (under the alias of "[[Mad Max|Max Rockatansky]]") and Dutch film director and journalist [[Jan Doense]] (under the alias of "Mr. Horror"). They provide the live introduction to each movie and [[film trailer]] shown at the festival. The event tours throughout the [[Netherlands]] and [[Flanders]] during all the important film theaters in [[Rotterdam]], [[Utrecht]], [[Groningen]], [[Enschede]], [[Amsterdam]], [[Vlissingen]], [[Ghent]], [[Hasselt]], [[Antwerp]], [[Kortrijk]], [[Biddinghuizen]], [[Vlieland]], [[Arnhem]], [[Breda]], [[Koersel]]-[[Beringen, Belgium|Beringen]], [[Eindhoven]], [[Leiden]], [[Amersfoort]], [[Nijmegen]], [[Roeselare]], [[Deventer]], [[Zwolle]] and [[Brussels]].<ref>http://www.nachtvandewansmaak.nl/</ref>
In 1986 Verheyen organized a "Nacht van de Rariteiten" ("Night of the Oddities") film festival in ''De Vooruit'' in Ghent. Despite having a low attendance of only 12 people the idea was reorganized into a full-blown film festival on 28 April 1990 in Rotterdam, which had more success.<ref>http://www.gorehoundinc.com/nachtvandewansmaak/achtergrond.html</ref> Under the new name "Nacht van de Wansmaak" the festival became a recurring event in 1997, 2001, 2003, 2004-2006 and again in 2014.<ref>http://www.gorehoundinc.com/nachtvandewansmaak/achtergrond.html</ref>
During the late 1990s and early 2000s Verheyen also presented a TV show on the Flemish network Kanaal 2 (nowadays [[2BE (TV channel)|2BE]]) under the title "Nacht van de Wansmaak".
In 2003 two DVD's with trailers of obscure B-movies were released.,<ref>http://www.despil.be/e1881/nacht-van-de-wansmaak</ref><ref>http://www.filmsalon.be/wansmaak.html</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = London's New Year's Eve | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = | image =New Years 2014 Fireworks - London Eye.jpg | caption = Fireworks over London Eye as part of the multi-senory New Year's 2013–2014 display | genre = [[New Year's Eve]] event | date = 31 December/1 January | begins = 20:30 ([[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]]) | ends = 00:30 ([[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]]) | frequency = Annually | location = [[Victoria Embankment]], [[South Bank]] and [[River Thames]] | years_active = | first = 2000 | founder_name = | last = | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = 107,000 (2015–16) | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = <!--"organized=" also works--> | people = | member = | website = | footnotes = }} '''New Year's Eve in London''', a [[New Year's Eve]] firework display, is celebrated along the [[Victoria Embankment]] and [[South Bank]] areas of the [[River Thames]] where the [[London Eye]] and [[Big Ben]] are situated. The countdown is accompanied by the chimes of Big Ben, and a digital countdown timer projected onto the [[Shell Centre]], until 2017. The fireworks are launched off the London Eye at midnight. A company, Titanium Fireworks are responsible for the pyrotechnics.
==History==
===2000–05=== The first major [[New Year's Eve]] fireworks display in London was planned in December 1999 to celebrate the year 2000. It was estimated by the BBC that about 3 million people turned up around the Thames to watch the fireworks display. A "river of fire" was planned to accompany the fireworks display, but failed to make an impact. A fireworks display was planned during 2000 to celebrate 2001, but was cancelled in November due to a dispute between then-[[Mayor of London]] [[Ken Livingstone]] and the [[London Underground]].<ref name=NYE2000>{{cite news|title=London New Year's party cancelled|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1032426.stm|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=BBC News Online|date=20 November 2000|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030811102442/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1032426.stm|archivedate=11 August 2003|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Similar disputes also occurred, causing displays to be cancelled for both the 2001–02 and 2002–03 celebrations,<ref>{{cite web|title=Culture, Sport and Tourism Committee|url=http://legacy.london.gov.uk/assembly/past_ctees/cst/2002/cstnov20/cstnov20mins.pdf|publisher=London Assembly|accessdate=30 May 2014|date=20 November 2002|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817161912/http://legacy.london.gov.uk/assembly/past_ctees/cst/2002/cstnov20/cstnov20mins.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> although approximately 80,000 revellers gathered around [[Trafalgar Square]] to celebrate the New Year.<ref>{{cite web|title=A damp squib: the Mayor's plans for New Year's Eve|url=http://legacy.london.gov.uk/assembly/reports/culture/nye2002_report.pdf|publisher=London Assembly|accessdate=30 May 2014|date=1 December 2002|quote=Report of the Culture, Sport and Tourism Committee – December 2002|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005002514/http://legacy.london.gov.uk/assembly/reports/culture/nye2002_report.pdf|archivedate=5 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
After a short three-year hiatus, for the 2003–04 event, there were fireworks though only for three minutes. For the 2004–05 event, in the run-up to midnight, an image of candles was projected onto the Shell Centre as a tribute to the victims of the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rubenfeld|first=Vik|title=Happy New Year!|url=http://www.bigpicweblog.com/exp/index.php/weblog/monthly_archives/C21/P30/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=[[Big Picture (magazine)|The Big Picture]]|date=1 January 2005|quote=New Year's Eve, London—An Image of Candles is Projected onto the Shell Building (left) as a Tribute to the Victims of the Asian Tsunami (REUTERS/Matt Dunham)|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531124545/http://www.bigpicweblog.com/exp/index.php/weblog/monthly_archives/C21/P30/|archivedate=31 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Also, at midnight, fireworks were launched from the wheel itself for the first time.
===2011–12=== For the 2011–12 extravaganza, fireworks were fired in a one-off event from Elizabeth Tower, launching from the top of the building outwards above the many spectators and well wishers below, welcoming in the year in which London went on to host the [[2012 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]].<ref name="NYE2011">{{cite news|title=London gets ready for New Year's Eve's firework display|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16363248|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]|date=30 December 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209122612/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16363248|archivedate=9 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Fireworks were launched in the shape and colour of the [[Olympic flag]], in a display that lasted approximately eleven minutes compared to being reduced to eight minutes in 2010.<ref name="NYE2011" />
===2012–13=== The 2012–13 display was based on both the diamond jubilee and the Olympics. The [[Queen's Christmas speech]] was used in the firework display for the first time.<ref name="NYE2012">{{cite news|title=London enjoys new year fireworks display|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-20874115|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=BBC News Online|date=1 January 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212114103/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-20874115|archivedate=12 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===2013–14=== The theme of the 2013–14 fireworks was 'Firsts' a projection prior to the fireworks featured Mayor of London [[Boris Johnson]] talking about the many 'firsts' that have come from the United Kingdom and London itself.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vodafone joins forces with Mayor for world's first multi-sensory fireworks display|url=http://www.london.gov.uk/media/mayor-press-releases/2013/12/vodafone-joins-forces-with-mayor-for-worlds-first-multi-sensory|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=[[Greater London Authority]]|date=9 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528183811/http://www.london.gov.uk/media/mayor-press-releases/2013/12/vodafone-joins-forces-with-mayor-for-worlds-first-multi-sensory|archivedate=28 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He then went on to explain the 2013–14 fireworks would the "world first" multi-sensory fireworks display with fruit flavoured sweets and [[radio controlled]] [[LED]] bracelets which had previously been used during [[Coldplay]]'s [[Mylo Xyloto Tour]] and the [[2012 Summer Paralympics closing ceremony|London 2012 Paralympics Closing Ceremony]] being handed out to revellers when entering the viewing areas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vodafone Announces 'Vodafone Firsts' New Global Own-Brand Engagement Strategy|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/media/vodafone-group-releases/2013/vodafone-announces-vodafone-firsts-new-global-brand-engagement.html|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=Vodafone UK|date=9 December 2013}}</ref> These sweets were as stated in the information leaflet to be eaten prior to the display to "prepare" spectators with the flavours that they were going to experience during the evening. Scented mists and edible flavoured foam were also sprayed throughout the performance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Multisensory Fireworks|url=http://bompasandparr.com/projects/view/flavour-fireworks|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=Bompas & Parr|date=19 December 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104082308/http://bompasandparr.com/projects/view/flavour-fireworks|archivedate=4 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Revellers usher in 2014 with fireworks and fruit mist|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/01/01/uk-usa-new-years-idUKBRE9BU0LH20140101|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=Reuters|date=1 January 2014|author=Victoria Cavaliere|author2=Eric M. Johnson|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104000142/http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/01/01/uk-usa-new-years-idUKBRE9BU0LH20140101|archivedate=4 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===2014–15=== For the 2014–15 display, the designer of the display stated that the fireworks would focus on London being a world-class city and how it can continue its repetition on being one. It was also focused on how the New Year's event in London was special to the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.designweek.co.uk/news/designing-londons-new-years-eve-fireworks/3039586.article|title=Designing London's New Year's Eve fireworks – Design Week|author=|date=19 December 2014|work=DesignWeek.co.uk|access-date=5 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141231175812/http://www.designweek.co.uk/news/designing-londons-new-years-eve-fireworks/3039586.article|archivedate=31 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The 2014–15 display was the subject of controversy as a £10 charge was introduced by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, for tickets to the official viewing areas.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Year's Eve revellers without tickets warned away from London fireworks|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/dec/31/new-years-eve-london-fireworks|publisher=The Guardian|access-date=1 January 2015|date=31 December 2014|author=Ben Quinn|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101030802/http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/dec/31/new-years-eve-london-fireworks|archivedate=1 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===2015–16=== For the 2015–16 display, the Mayor of London announced a partnership with [[UNICEF]] to raise money for the charity from the profits made during the evening. The [[Elizabeth Tower]] clock face, London Eye and the surrounding areas were lit in blue to support the cause.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.london.gov.uk/press-releases/mayoral/london-new-years-eve-with-unicef |title=Mayor's New Year's Eve fireworks display with Unicef |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229033531/https://www.london.gov.uk/press-releases/mayoral/london-new-years-eve-with-unicef |archivedate=29 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===2016–17=== New Mayor of London [[Sadiq Khan]] stated the 2016–17 display will be the "most exciting New Year fireworks yet for the city". {{citation needed|date=December 2016}} Khan announced a partnership with the BBC to film the fireworks in 360 degrees. The fireworks display paid homage to [[Prince (singer)|Prince]], [[David Bowie]] and [[Ronnie Corbett]] who died in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.london.gov.uk/events/2016-12-31/london-new-years-eve-fireworks-2016 |title=London New Year's Eve Fireworks 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229032254/https://www.london.gov.uk/events/2016-12-31/london-new-years-eve-fireworks-2016 |archivedate=29 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===2017–18=== The 2017–18 firework display featured a soundtrack dominated by female artists such as [[Ariana Grande]], [[Little Mix]], [[Annie Lennox]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Dua Lipa]] and [[Florence Welch]] which was played to mark the [[Representation of the People Act 1918|centenary of women being allowed to vote]]. Big Ben also chimed at midnight amid ongoing repairs. For the first time, the 60 second countdown was only projected from 15 seconds instead of the full 60 seconds due to Big Ben's accuracy being different due to the repair work being carried out on the tower and the bell. In addition, the London Eye's capsules also marked the countdown with each of them lighting down from 10 seconds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://home.bt.com/news/uk-news/girl-power-to-rock-the-show-at-londons-new-years-eve-firework-display-11364239541698|title=Girl power to rock the show at London's New Year's Eve firework display|work=BT.com|access-date=28 December 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229052401/http://home.bt.com/news/uk-news/girl-power-to-rock-the-show-at-londons-new-years-eve-firework-display-11364239541698|archivedate=29 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/story/security-for-new-years-eve-celebrations-reviewed-met-police-says-11187374 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-12-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228162720/https://news.sky.com/story/security-for-new-years-eve-celebrations-reviewed-met-police-says-11187374 |archivedate=28 December 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Ariana Grande's [[One Last Time (Ariana Grande song)|One Last Time]] was played as part of the soundtrack to the firework display with 22 red fireworks to pay tribute to the 22 people who died in the [[Manchester Arena bombing|Manchester Arena attack]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/ariana-grande-leads-london-new-years-eve-fireworks-soundtrack-2201143|title=Ariana Grande leads the London New Year's Eve fireworks soundtrack|date=2018-01-01|work=NME|access-date=2018-01-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5225529/Poignant-moment-London-saw-2018-Ariana-Grande-song.html|title=Poignant moment London saw in 2018 with Ariana Grande song|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/898655/new-years-eve-fireworks-london-eye-nye-pictures-latest-2018-celebrations|title=Happy New Year! Stunning London Eye fireworks welcome Britain into 2018|last=Stinson|first=Nicole|date=2018-01-01|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=2018-01-21|language=en}}</ref>
===2018-19=== It is unknown if Big Ben will be able to chime due to repair works on the tower which last until 2021, but however Big Ben’s clock hands were taken off in April, so for the first time ever the next event could all be digitally timed. It is known that lots of people will show up.
==Music== Since 2010–11, musical soundtracks have been played during the fireworks. In 2010–11, 2011–12 and 2014–15, [[BBC Radio 1]] provided the soundtrack to the firework displays.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Year 2011 fireworks at London Eye to have musical soundtrack|url=http://www.london-se1.co.uk/news/view/4957|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=London SE1|date=23 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230231904/http://www.london-se1.co.uk/news/view/4957|archivedate=30 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2012–13, 2013–14, 2015–16, 2016–17, 2017–18, and 2018-19, Bounce, a music editing company based in London, provided the soundtrack to the displays.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisbounce.com/clients|title=Clients|website=thisisbounce.com|access-date=10 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170112182508/http://www.thisisbounce.com/clients|archivedate=12 January 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

==Broadcast== The fireworks are broadcast on [[BBC One]] on a show entitled [[New Year Live|''New Year's Eve Fireworks'']].<ref>{{Cite episode|title=New Year Live|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00gtn49|accessdate=4 February 2014|series=New Year Live|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC One]]|location=[[London]]|date=31 December 2008 – 31 December 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130107171107/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00gtn49|archivedate=7 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite episode|title=New Year Live|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03nns31|accessdate=4 February 2014|series=New Year Live|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC One]]|location=[[London]]|date=31 December 2013 – 31 December 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105193713/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03nns31|archivedate=5 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In addition, the network's ''[[2000 Today]]'' broadcast the display for the very first time. [[Sky News]], [[ITV News]] and [[CNN]] also provide coverage on the fireworks and still cover as of 2017. {{citation needed|date=December 2016}}

[[File:Jeu de Paume de Béquet (Bel-Air) - View - VJohnson 2008 p101.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|View of the Salle du Bel-Air from the city ramparts overlooking the moat]] [[File:Jeu de paume de Béquet (Bel-Air) - Map - Nuitter 1886 after p130.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Jeu de Paume de Béquet on a 1615 enlargement of a section of the 1609 [[François Quesnel|Quesnel]] map of Paris<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=xLgxAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA130-IA2 Nuitter & Thoinan 1886, after p. 130].</ref>]]
The '''Salle du Bel-Air'''<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=90YqAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA21 La Salle 1875, pp. 21–24].</ref> or '''Salle du Jeu de Paume de Béquet''' (Hall of the Béquet Tennis Court) was a 1672 [[Theater (structure)|theatre]] located in Paris, France. Originally an indoor tennis court (''[[jeu de paume]]'') it was converted by the Italian designer [[Carlo Vigarani]] into a theatre which was used by [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]]'s [[Paris Opera]] from 15 November 1672 to 1 February 1673.<ref>Wild 1989, p. 299; Harris-Warrick 1992, p. 856.</ref> It was located in the [[Rue de Vaugirard]], just west of the city moat (''fossé'') and the Rue des Fossés Monsieur-le-Prince (now the [[Rue Monsieur-le-Prince]]). Today the site of the former theatre extends into the Rue de Médicis, just south of no. 15 (or 13 bis) Rue de Vaugirard.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=xLgxAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA284-IA1 Nuitter & Thoinan 1886, after p. 284].</ref>
==History== Lully's ''Les fêtes de l'Amour et de Bacchus'' opened at the Salle du Bel-Air in November 1672. This was followed by his first ''[[tragédie lyrique]]'', ''[[Cadmus et Hermione]]'', on 27 April 1673. The theatre was equipped with stage machinery, but Lully regarded it as temporary. After [[Molière]] died on 17 February 1673, Lully convinced [[King Louis XIV]] to allow him to use Molière's [[Théâtre du Palais-Royal (rue Saint-Honoré)|theatre at the Palais-Royal]] free of charge.<ref>Harris-Warrick 1992, p. 856.</ref>

Copies [https://books.google.com/books?id=mTwQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PR5 1] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=xLgxAAAAMAAJ&pg=PR5 2] at [[Google Books]]. * Wild, Nicole ([1989]). ''Dictionnaire des théâtres parisiens au XIXe siècle: les théâtres et la musique''. Paris: Aux Amateurs de livres. {{ISBN|9780828825863}}. {{ISBN|9782905053800}} (paperback). {{Infobox song | Name = So Cruel | Type = [[Song]] | Artist = [[U2]] | Album = [[Achtung Baby]] | Released = 19 November 1991 | track_no = 6 | Recorded = February 1991 – September 1991 | Studio = Elsinore in [[Dublin]], and [[Windmill Lane Studios]] in Dublin | Genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | Length = 5:49 | Writer = U2 ([[composer|music]]), [[Bono]] ([[lyricist|lyrics]]) | Label = [[Island Records]] | Producer = [[Daniel Lanois]] | prev = "[[Who's Gonna Ride Your Wild Horses]]" | prev_no = 5 | next = "[[The Fly (song)|The Fly]]" | next_no = 7 | Misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|MBq3CgBWlx8|"So Cruel" from ''From the Sky Down''}}|Type=song}} }}
"'''So Cruel'''" is a song by [[rock music|rock]] band [[U2]]. It is the sixth track on their 1991 album ''[[Achtung Baby]]'', concluding side one of the album. The song was written at Elsinore in [[Dalkey]]. While audio engineer [[Flood (producer)|Flood]] changed reels to listen to a demo of another song, lead singer [[Bono]] began to improvise a song on guitar. The rest of the band quickly joined in, creating the first take of the song. It was developed as an acoustic track, with Flood adding overdubs and additional elements later. Bassist [[Adam Clayton]] and Flood noted that the technology in the studio was crucial in transforming the acoustic song into the final mix.
During the recording sessions for ''Achtung Baby'', guitarist [[the Edge]] separated from his wife, Aislinn O'Sullivan. The separation had a major effect on the development of the song, as Bono channelled their pain into the lyrics. Bono said "there were lots of other things going on internally within the band and outside it, and I was working through all of that", noting that the Edge's separation from Aislinn was just one component of that. Thematically the song is about unrequited love, jealousy, obsession, and possessiveness.
U2 have performed "So Cruel" live just four times, all of which were on the [[Zoo TV Tour]] in 1992. The track was favourably received by critics.
==Writing and inspiration== "So Cruel" was developed by lead singer [[Bono]]. Following the recording sessions at [[Hansa Studios]] in [[West Berlin]] in 1990, U2 resumed the album's sessions in February 1991 at the seaside manor Elsinore in [[Dalkey]], renting the house for ₤10,000 per month.<ref name="adams">{{cite journal |url=http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/1994_articles/mar94/u2robbieadams.html |title=ROBBIE ADAMS: U2's Achtung Baby & Zooropa |journal=[[Sound on Sound]] |first=Paul |last=Tingen |date=March 1994 |accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref><ref>McGee (2008), pp. 134–135</ref> Producer [[Daniel Lanois]]' strategy was to record in houses, mansions, or castles, as he believed it brought atmosphere to the recordings.<ref name="adams" /> During the recording at Elsinore, while working on another song, [[Audio engineering|audio engineer]] [[Flood (producer)|Flood]] changed the [[reel]] to listen to an earlier take. Bono picked up a guitar and began to sing. The rest of the band quickly joined in. Flood said, "All of a sudden, almost in the time it had taken for me to wind off the reel and wind the next reel on, it was quite obvious that there was a song about to pop out, and if I wasn't suddenly taking the reel off and getting a new piece of tape on, and changing from monitoring a backing track downstairs to everybody's in the control room wanting to record now, it would never have happened."<ref>Beyda (2000), p. 6</ref>
"So Cruel" was developed acoustically, with guitarist [[the Edge]] playing an acoustic guitar, bassist [[Adam Clayton]] playing an [[Acoustic bass guitar|acoustic bass]], and drummer [[Larry Mullen, Jr.]] using a [[bodhrán]].<ref name="U2228" /> Author John D. Luerssen interpreted the song as beginning "with the same kind of basic approach to songcraft that gave wings to '[[She's a Mystery to Me]]'".<ref>Luerssen (2010), pp. 258-259</ref> Bono said that "People thought it was too traditional, one more attempt at writing a song for [[Roy Orbison]]".<ref name="U2228">McCormick (2006), p. 228</ref> Lyrically, it was also inspired by [[Scott Walker (singer)|Scott Walker]]. Bono said, "His is a very delicate mode of expression on the outside, though too often it is laced underneath with a lot of pain and rage."<ref name="Stokes" />
According to Clayton, Flood "did a couple of treatments to the track that utterly transformed it." He [[Dynamic range compression#Side-chaining|keyed]] Clayton's bass with the bodhrán, which "gave it a much more bubbly, off-beat feel".<ref name="U2228" /><ref name="g45">Graham (2004), p. 45</ref> This was followed by some [[overdub]]bing and the laying down of a full drum track. Flood said, "I think the way we shifted around the rhythm was very important... The bass is played, but in the studio we doctored it to change the emphasis of where the bass line lay. That turned it into something that had a more unique feel about it, meshed against the song."<ref name="Stokes" /> Duchess Nell Catchpole was brought in to play [[violin]] and [[viola]] for the song. The strings were arranged by the Edge and producer [[Brian Eno]].<ref name="ABnotes" /> Clayton explained that while the original acoustic version "wasn't something one could imagine being on the record", it "was lifted up by studio trickery."<ref name="U2228" /> Flood believes that the use of technology was crucial in making the final mix.<ref name="Stokes" /> An early version of the track was later released on some versions of the 20th anniversary reissue of ''Achtung Baby''.
==Themes== [[File:The edge u2 at brasilia 2011.jpg|thumb|right|upright|alt=|The Edge (pictured in 2011) separated from his wife during the recording of ''Achtung Baby''. Their painful emotions were channelled in the lyrics.]]
During the recording sessions for ''Achtung Baby'', the Edge separated from his wife, Aislinn O'Sullivan. Reflecting on the impact it had on U2, Bono said, "We're a really tight community. This is not like somebody's, you know, girlfriend's left. We've grown up with these people, this our family, our community. This was really hard for us... It was like the first cracks on the beautiful porcelain jug with those beautiful flowers in it that was our music and our community, starting to go 'crack'."<ref name="FTSD">{{cite AV media |people=U2, [[Davis Guggenheim]] (Director) |title=[[From the Sky Down]] |medium=film |publisher=[[BBC Worldwide|BBC Worldwide Canada]] |date=2011}}</ref> The Edge explained that travelling to Berlin to write and record provided him with an escape from his failing marriage: "I was disappearing into the music for a different reason. It was a refuge in a way. That approach didn't completely work. You know, I wasn't really... in a good positive headspace. I was running away, I suppose."<ref name="FTSD" /> ''[[Hot Press]]'' editor [[Niall Stokes]] noted that in the lyrics, "Bono is clearly drawing on the experiences of those close to him, and particularly on the emotional turmoil that the Edge and Aislinn had been going through."<ref name="Stokes">Stokes (2005), p. 101</ref> Bono said "that's in there, but it's unfair to lump it all on the Edge and Aislinn splitting up. That was one of the saddest things... But that was only one part of it. There were lots of other things going on internally within the band and outside it, and I was working through all of that. People are desperately trying to hold onto each other in a time when that's very difficult. Looking around, you see how unprepared for it all people are, and the deals they make."<ref name="Stokes" />
Thematically, "So Cruel" also deals with unrequited love, jealousy, obsession, and possessiveness.<ref name="Stokes" /><ref name="g49">Graham (2004), p. 49</ref> Stokes described it as "the desolate complaint of a lover who has been spurned but who remains in love with his tormentor."<ref name="Stokes" /> ''Uncut'' contributor Gavin Martin said "the lyrics of the song reinforce the idea of ''Achtung Baby'' as a kind of romantic masque, where images of love, debased or abandoned, abound."<ref name="Martin" /> Elizabeth Wurtzel of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' noted "with its lovely string arrangements, winding keyboards, and frothy, hypnotic melodies, is reminiscent of [[Tommy James and the Shondells|Tommy James]]'s "[[Crimson and Clover]]", except that every lovingly sweet line is contrasted with a bitterly ironic counter line", citing the lyric "I disappeared in you / You disappeared from me / I gave you everything you wanted / It wasn't what you wanted" as an example.<ref>Wurtzel (2003), p. 97</ref> Hubert Dreyfuss, a Professor of Philosophy at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and Mark Wrathall, a Humanities Professor at [[Brigham Young University]] believed that the song was an exploration into philosophical [[Dualistic cosmology|dualism]]. Quoting the lyric "Head of heaven, fingers in the mire", they said "if we are essentially dual in this way, then any attempt to overcome one side in favour of the other inevitably ends in despair", comparing the underlying philosophy to [[Blaise Pascal]]'s ''[[Pensées]]''.<ref>Dreyfuss (2006), p. 18</ref>
Author Višnja Cogan wrote "Women... never get treated badly in U2 songs... Women are put on a pedestal by Bono, his mother's untimely death being undoubtedly one of the reasons. If anything, in some of the songs on ''Achtung Baby'', it is the man who gets the raw deal. On 'So Cruel', it is the man who is the victim of a woman. It is the reverse of the classical torch song".<ref name="Cogan">Cogan (2008), p. 85</ref> Quoting the lyric "Her skin is pale like God's only dove / Screams like an angel for your love / Then she makes you watch her from above / And you need her like a drug", he added "The man is manipulated by the woman's sexual power. He is incapable of pulling himself out of this relationship and despite his best efforts, he comes back to her."<ref name="Cogan" /> He noted that the woman is portrayed as "cruel, unreliable and unfaithful. She can only betray him and the duality between love and lust is well depicted in the song." Cogan concluded by saying "unlike the classical torch song, this one ends with the man seemingly deciding to leave the woman... The only thing we don't know in the end is whether he actually acts on his promise or not."<ref name="Cogan" />
Conversely, author Deane Galbraith believed the song was told from the woman's viewpoint, saying "a woman is unable to receive love without also hating those who love her. She acts simultaneously as tender lover and cruel sadist. The lyrics that describe her 'like an angel' are immediately juxtaposed with a more sordid description that pictures her love as an addictive and manipulative drug. Instead of the subtle and vivifying transcendence of a heavenly angel, when she offers to take her lover higher, he is forced to watch her while she controls him 'from above'. For this is a fallen angel, not purely good or evil, but a lover whose best intentions are insidiously corrupt".<ref>Galbraith (2011), p. 180</ref>
==Reception== "So Cruel" was favourably received by critics. ''Hot Press'' editor Niall Stokes called it "dark, bitter, intense and masochistic", believing the lyrics to be the aspect that made the song memorable. He added, "As a statement about marital infidelity, the sense of betrayal that accompanies it and the rage that almost inevitably follows, it would be hard to surpass."<ref name="Stokes" /> ''Uncut'' contributor Gavin Martin rated the song four stars, calling it "lustful and lustrous". He said that "the Edge's looped five-note piano motif is encircled by a sabre-rattling guitar and a fine synthesized string part; lushly multi-dimensional, pregnant with poise and feeling" and that the theme of "marital disharmony and emotional desolation" underpinning ''Achtung Baby'' was especially evident on the song.<ref name="Martin">{{cite journal |last=Martin |first=Gavin |date=April 2009 |title=Achtung Baby |journal=The Ultimate Music Guide |issue=U2 |pages=74–77 |publisher=''Uncut''}}</ref> Greg Potter of ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]'' wrote that it was "riddled with images of self-doubt and uncertainty".<ref>{{cite news |title=Achtung Baby: faith and flesh with a kick |newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |first=Greg |last=Potter |page=6 |date=21 November 1991 |quote=While songs such as One, Until the End of the World, So Cruel and the dour closer Love is Blindness are riddled with images of self-doubt and uncertainty, they are countered by the uplifting cadences of Even Better than the Real Thing, Mysterious Ways and Acrobat.}}</ref> Elysa Gardner of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' said, "Bono sounds humbler and more vulnerable than in the past", noting that he "[acknowledges] his own potential for hypocrisy and inadequacy, and addressing basic human weaknesses rather than the failings of society at large".<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/achtung-baby-19920109 |title=U2's 'Achtung Baby': Bring the Noise |journal=[[Rolling Stone]] |first=Elysa |last=Gardner |date=9 January 1992 |issue=621 |accessdate=15 October 2011 |page=51}}</ref>
Steve Morse of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' called it an "embittered love [song]" with "a minimalist drum sound from Larry Mullen and an even more minimalist vocal from Bono."<ref>{{cite news |title=U2 Bounces Back |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |first=Steve |last=Morse |page=53 |date=15 November 1991}}</ref> [[Jon Pareles]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that "[love is] a state of desperation or a bitter memory... The marchlike 'So Cruel' [ricochets] from fond reminiscence to vindictiveness to accusations, some of them directed at the narrator himself".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/arts/recordings-view-u2-takes-a-turn-from-the-universal-to-the-domestic.html?pagewanted=3&src=pm |title=U2 Takes a Turn From the Universal To the Domestic (Page 3) |date=17 November 1991 |first=Jon |last=Pareles |authorlink=Jon Pareles |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=15 October 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/620LqE2Ht |archivedate=27 September 2011}}</ref> Writing for the ''[[Boston Herald]]'', Julie Romandetta called "So Cruel" a "broken-hearted [lament]" that was "lushly orchestrated".<ref>{{cite news |title=Band returns to its roots with 'Achtung Baby' |newspaper=[[Boston Herald]] |first=Julie |last=Romandetta |page=31 |date=18 November 1991 |quote=Songs about romantic hardship fill more than half of ''Achtung Baby''. Bono's broken-hearted laments are most poignant on the lushly orchestrated 'So Cruel' and the gentle, subdued 'Love is Blindness'.}}</ref> Robert Hillburn of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' believed that it was one of U2's best tracks, describing it as "pulsating and accusatory".<ref>{{cite news |title=Achtung Baby - U2 (Island) |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |first=Robert |last=Hillburn |page=4G |date=22 November 1991 |quote=Yet some tracks - including the pulsating and accusatory "So Cruel" and the anxious "Until the End of the World" - clearly rank with the finest moments in U2's body of work.}}</ref> Brian Eno described the song as "epic and intimate, passionate and chill".<ref>{{cite news |title=The Making of U2's New Recording |first=Brian |last=Eno |authorlink=Brian Eno |newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |page=3F |date=17 November 1991}}</ref>
==Live performances== U2 have only performed "So Cruel" four times live, all of which were on the [[Zoo TV Tour]]. The first appearance was on 22 May 1992 in Milan, Italy, on the second leg of the tour when, at the end of "[[Bad (U2 song)|Bad]]", Bono sang a few lines of "So Cruel" in place of "[[All I Want Is You (U2 song)|All I Want Is You]]".<ref>de la Parra (2003), p. 147</ref> In August 1992, a few days prior to the commencement of the third leg of the tour, U2 rehearsed the song in Hershey, Pennsylvania.<ref>de la Parra (2003), p. 151</ref> The second performance in concert was on 22 August 1992 in Foxboro, Massachusetts. Bono performed the song acoustically. Concert historian Pimm Jal de la Parra said that it "[chilled] the crowd."<ref>de la Parra (2003), p. 153</ref> The final performances occurred on 9 and 15 September 1992 in Pontiac, Michigan, and Chicago, Illinois respectively. On both occasions it was played in place of "All I Want Is You". Abbreviated performances, recorded at Hansa studios, appear in the 2011 documentary ''[[From the Sky Down]]''.<ref name="FTSD" />
==Covers== [[Depeche Mode]] reworked the song for the 2011 tribute album ''[[AHK-toong BAY-bi Covered]]''. "We first heard ''Achtung Baby'' working on ''[[Songs of Faith and Devotion]]'' with [[Flood (producer)|Flood]]," remarked [[Martin Gore]]. "It was the closest our bands ever got: U2 had become more [[Electronic music|electronic]], while Depeche Mode were working on a new rock vision. But there was never a rivalry. Bono used reverse psychology in his email ''(requesting the band's participation in the tribute album)'', saying he totally understood why we'd say no. We just thought, 'Why not?' 'So Cruel' is Bono at his best, words-wise. And we couldn't tackle '[[One (U2 song)|One]]' – that would be almost [[Sacrilege|sacrilegious]]."<ref>{{cite journal|title=What's On Your Free CD?|journal=[[Q (magazine)|Q]]|date=December 2011|pages=6–7}}</ref>

'''Sopot Hit Festival''' - is international song contest, bringing contestants and guests who are stars with world recognition. It has been transmitted annually by the [[TVP2|Polish Television]] in the coastal resort of [[Sopot]], [[Poland]]. Together with [[National Festival of Polish Song in Opole]] and [[Sopot International Song Festival|Sopot Festival]] it the biggest Polish music festival.

{{Other uses}} [[File:Splinter.jpg|thumb|Splinter]]
A '''splinter''' is a fragment of a larger object (especially [[Timber|wood]]), or a [[foreign body]] that penetrates or is purposely injected into a body. The foreign body must be lodged inside tissue to be considered a splinter. Splinters may cause initial pain through ripping of flesh and muscle, infection through bacteria on the foreign object, and severe internal damage through migration to vital organs or bone over time.
Splinters commonly consist of [[wood]], but there are many other types. According to the [[American Academy of Family Physicians]] (AAFP), common types of splinters are glass, plastic, metal, and spines of animals.<ref>Capellan O, Hollander, JE. "Management of lacerations in the emergency department". ''Emerg Med Clin North Am.'' 2003;21:205–31.</ref>
Splinters can necessitate amputation; if it is in the finger for more than one 2–3 days, advice should be sought from a doctor.
==Contracting a splinter== Generally, a splinter causes an initial feeling of pain as the sharp object makes its initial penetration through the body. Through this penetration, the object cuts through the [[cutaneous]] layer of the skin, and settles in the [[Subcutaneous tissue|subcutaneous]] layer of the skin, and can even penetrate further down, breaking the sub-cutaneous layer, settling in muscle tissue, or even the bone. Some splinters will remain in place, but most will continue to migrate through the body, further damaging their surroundings.
==Types== [[File:Sea Urchins enjoying sunbathing.jpg|thumb|Sea urchins may cause splinters]] According to the AAFP, the most common foreign bodies contracted by people fall into two official classes: biological splinters, and nonbiological splinters.<ref>American College of Emergency Physicians: clinical policy for the initial approach to patients presenting with penetrating extremity trauma. Ann Emerg Med. 1999;33:612–36.</ref> In the biological class, splinters include bone, fish spines, teeth, and wood. In the nonbiological class, common splinters contracted are glass, metal, aluminum, fishhooks, pencil graphite, and plastic.
Rarely, people may become infected with splinters from more unusual sources. Common cases of exotic foreign bodies include sea urchins, insect stings, stingray spines, and even grenade shrapnel.
==Specific details of some splinters== * Wood: this type of splinter is contracted from lumber or other vegetative materials. Wood splinters must be removed from wounds because they are associated with inflammation and risk of infection. Larger or deeper splinters can result in difficult removal, or localization of the foreign body. * Fishhooks: fishhooks that become lodged in the skin are problematic because of the barbs found on the ends of most fishhooks. These barbs are designed to make removal difficult, and if care is not taken, the victim can experience tearing of not only the flesh, but the muscle as well. The most common injuries caused by fishhooks occur in the hand, face, scalp, foot, and eye. * Glass: one study found that patients were more likely to feel sensations from glass present in their skin than from any other kind of splinter. Though glass is generally detectable by radiography and is radiopaque, there is limited ability for radiography to detect glass fragments smaller than 2mm. Most glass splinters are inert, and generally lack the ability to migrate to other regions of the body{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}. * Other: Pencil lead and other graphite foreign bodies, once lodged in the cutaneous layer of the skin, can cause permanent pigment tattooing if not removed immediately. Metallic bodies range from [[BB gun|BB]] pellets to grenade shrapnel. Smaller objects can be removed without much difficulty if the depth of the wound remains superficial, but if the wound does not protrude past the subcutaneous layers of the skin, and remains inert, the object can actually remain in place. In larger objects, fragments that remain superficial in one’s body may be removed without much trouble, but if wounds protrude past the subcutaneous layers of the skin and even into the muscular area or near vital organs, such objects must be left alone and immediate medical attention must be sought. * {{anchor|Hair splinter}}Hair: Short lengths of hair, especially stiff hair such as trimmed [[beard]] hair or pet hair, can work its way under the skin of the feet or hands. So-called "hair splinters" are commonly experienced by [[hairdresser]]s and [[dog groomer]]s.<ref>https://www.healthline.com/health/hair-splinter</ref> This is distinct from an [[ingrown hair]], where a hair still attached to its [[hair follicle|follicle]] grows back under (or fails to emerge from) the skin.
==Detection== [[File:Anatomy The Skin - NCI Visuals Online.jpg|thumb|Anatomy The Skin - NCI Visuals Online]] Splinters are often first detected by the person with the splinter in their body. There are many signs that a splinter has entered one’s body.
===Signs of a hidden foreign body=== * Puncture wound * Blood-stained injury track of a fresh wound * Sharp pain with deep palpation over a puncture wound * Discoloration beneath the epidermis * Wound that elicits pain with movement * Wound that fails to heal * [[Abscess]] (with sterile culture) * Pain associated with a mass * Mass under the [[epidermis (skin)|epidermis]] * Chronically draining purulent wound * [[Cyst]] * Granuloma formation * Sterile monoarticular [[arthritis]] * Periosteal reactions * [[Osteomyelitis]] * Pseudo tumors of bone * Delayed tendon or nerve injury
Many times, if the presence in a body is not known, but only effects are felt, modern technologies will be employed. Depending on the type of foreign body the patient is infected with modern detectors can range from Computed Tomography, Radiography, and Ultrasonography. If manual detection and localization fail, such modern technologies may be utilized accordingly:<ref name=tibbles>Tibbles CD, Porcaro W. Procedural applications of ultrasound. Emerg Med Clin North Am. 2004;22:797–815.</ref>
* [[Tomography]] - reserved for failed exploration of infection * [[Radiography]] - used to locate bone, fish spines, glass, gravel-stone, metal, aluminum, pencil graphite, some plastics, teeth, and some wood (e.g., spines, cactus, thorns) * [[Ultrasonography]] - used to locate glass, metal, pencil graphite, some plastics, stone, and some types of wood.<ref name=tibbles />
==Removal== There are many medical techniques to remove splinters safely. Common medical techniques include the Elliptical Technique and the String Technique.<ref name=Blankstein>Blankstein A, Cohen I, Heiman Z, Salai M, Diamant L, Heim M, et al. Ultrasonography as a diagnostic modality and therapeutic adjuvant in the management of soft tissue foreign bodies in the lower extremities. Isr Med Assoc J. 2001;3:411–3.</ref> In the elliptical technique the surrounding area of the splinter is sliced in an elliptical formation. From there the flesh in the elliptical area is cut (in the shape of an upside-down cone) and the whole chunk of flesh containing the splinter is removed. The Needle Cover Technique is limited to fishhook removal. A string is looped around the base of the hook, and as the hook is pressed further into the skin, the string is pulled, allowing the barbs to be unhooked from muscle and follow the path of the rest of the hook out of the body without snagging any additional flesh.<ref name=Blankstein />
==Infection== Infection is usually determined by the duration of time that the foreign object remains lodged in the human body. Objects that have included poison, deep penetration, dirt, or bite injuries generally result in a shorter time until infection is notable. According to the AAFP patients that are older, or have diabetes, or have wounds that are longer, wider, more jagged or deeper, have a much higher risk of infection. Simply the easiest way to avoid infection is to completely remove the splinters or foreign body as soon as possible. Though infection is generally the largest complication encountered with splinters, ranging from 1.1 to 12 percent presence, the use of antibiotics in non-bite cases is generally deemed unnecessary by the medical community.<ref>Broder KR, Cortese MM, Iskander JK, Kretsinger K, Slade BA, Brown KH, et al., for the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). Preventing tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis among adolescents: use of tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid and acellular pertussis vaccines recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR Recomm Rep. 2006;55RR-31–34.</ref> Though cases are rare, infection of foreign body wounds can result in cases of tetanus.
One case of tetanus contraction through a splinter was seen in Ohio, 1993. An 80-year-old woman was presented to an ED with dysphagia and a stiff jaw. Not long after a preliminary checkup, a wood splinter was found to have been lodged in her chin for approximately 1 week; the area was erythematous with active purulent drainage. The woman was diagnosed with tetanus, admitted to the hospital, and begun on a regimen of 3,000 units of tetanus immune globulin, tetanus toxoid, and intravenous clindamycin. Despite aggressive treatment, including assisted mechanical ventilation, the patient succumbed to the effects of her primary infection and died 15 days later. The woman had no history of previous tetanus vaccinations despite previous care for a wound and on-going medical attention for hypertension.<ref>Buttaravoli PM, Stair TO. Minor emergencies: splinters to fractures. St. Louis: Mosby, 2000;471–7.</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{more footnotes|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox rail accident | title = Summit Tunnel fire | image = Entrance to Summit Tunnel. - geograph.org.uk - 424169.jpg | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = South portal, Summit Tunnel | map_type = England | map = | AlternativeMap = | map_alt = | map_overlay = | map_dot_label = | map_size = | map_caption = | date = 20 December 1984 | time = | location = [[Summit Tunnel]], [[Lancashire]]/[[West Yorkshire]] border | coordinates = {{coord|53.6751|N|2.088261|W|type:event|display=inline}} | country = United Kingdom | line = [[Manchester and Leeds Railway]] | operator = [[British Rail]] | type = Derailment and fire | cause = Defective bearing | location-dist = | location-dir = | location-city = | location-dist-mi = | trains = 1 | pax = | crew = 3 | deaths = | injuries = | damage = | map_state = | map_name = | footnotes = }} On 20 December 1984 a [[dangerous goods]] [[train]] passing through the [[Summit Tunnel]] on the [[Greater Manchester]]/[[West Yorkshire]] border, caught fire on the rail line between [[Littleborough, Greater Manchester|Littleborough]] and [[Todmorden]], England.
==History== {{main|Summit Tunnel}} The tunnel, which is {{convert|2885|yd|m}} in length, was built in 1840-41. Twelve of the fourteen construction shafts,<ref name = "RA" /> at intervals of approximately {{convert|220|yd|m}},{{cn|date=March 2016}} were left open to help vent smoke and steam from the [[steam locomotive|locomotives]] that passed through it.<ref name = "RA" />
The incident was one of a series of railway accidents during 1984, coming only days after the fatal collision between an express passenger train and a train of fuel oil tankers at [[Eccles rail crash (1984)|Eccles]], Greater Manchester on 4 December. One day earlier on 3 December a train guard had been killed after a collision between a diesel multiple unit and parcels vans at Longsight also in Manchester. This third serious railway accident in the North West of England in less than 3 weeks led the [[Littleborough and Saddleworth (UK Parliament constituency)|Littleborough and Saddleworth]] MP [[Geoffrey Dickens]] to call for an inquiry into railway safety, in particular with respect to the conveyance of dangerous chemicals such as those involved in the accidents at Eccles and Summit Tunnel.<ref name="Granada News">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n4fVhmSacr0 |title=Granada News report on Summit Tunnel Disaster |publisher=LittleboroughLocal |date=27 April 2015 |access-date=20 November 2015}}</ref>
==Fire== The train involved was the 01:40 freight train from [[Haverton Hill]], [[Teesside]] to {{rws|Glazebrook}} oil distribution terminal in [[Merseyside]]. It was formed by [[British Rail Class 47|class 47]] [[diesel locomotive]] 47 125 and thirteen [[tank car|tankers]].<ref name = "RA">{{cite web |url=http://www.railwaysarchive.co.uk/documents/DoT_Summit1984.pdf |periodical=Railway accident |title=Report on the derailment and fire that occurred on 20th December 1984 at Summit Tunnel in the London Midland Region of British Railways |location=London |author=[[Department of Transport]] |date=4 June 1986 |format=PDF, 5.7 MB |publisher=[[Her Majesty's Stationery Office]]}}</ref>
At 05:50 on 20 December 1984, the train, carrying more than {{convert|1000000|L|impgal USgal}} ({{convert|835|t|LT ST|disp=or}}) of four-star [[petrol]] in thirteen [[tank car|tankers]], entered the tunnel on the Yorkshire (north) side travelling at {{convert|40|mph|km/h}}. One-third of the way through the tunnel, a defective [[axle]] [[Bearing (mechanical)|bearing]] ([[journal bearing]]) derailed the fourth tanker, which caused the derailment of those behind. Only the locomotive and the first three tankers remained on the rails. One of the derailed tankers fell on its side and began to leak petrol into the tunnel. Vapour from the leaking petrol was probably ignited by the [[hot box|damaged axle box]].<ref name = "RA" />
The three train crew members could see fire spreading through the [[Track ballast|ballast]] beneath the other track in the tunnel, so they left the train and ran the remaining mile to the south portal (where they knew there was a direct [[telephone]] connection to the signaller) to raise the alarm.<ref name = "RA" />
Crews from [[Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service|Greater Manchester Fire Brigade]] and [[West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service|West Yorkshire Fire Brigade]] quickly attended the scene. Co-ordination between the brigades appears to have worked well, perhaps because they had both participated in an emergency exercise in the tunnel a month before.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report on the Derailment and the fire that occurred on 20th December 1984 at Summit Tunnel|url=http://www.railwaysarchive.co.uk/documents/DoT_Summit1984.pdf|website=railwaysarchive.co.uk|publisher=Department of Transport|accessdate=20 April 2017|page=12|format=PDF|date=4 June 1986}}</ref>
The train crew were persuaded to return to the train, where they uncoupled the three tankers still on the rails and used the locomotive to drive them out.<ref name = "RA" /> Greater Manchester fire brigade then loaded firefighting equipment onto track trolleys and sent a crew with [[SCBA|breathing apparatus]] (BA) in to begin their firefighting operation at the south end of the train. They also lowered hoselines down one of the [[ventilation shaft]]s to provide a water supply. At the same time, crews from West Yorkshire fire brigade entered the tunnel and began fighting fires in the ballast at the north end of the train.
However, at 9.40 a.m., the pressure in one of the heated tankers rose high enough to open its pressure relief valves. The vented vapour caught fire and blew flames onto the tunnel wall. The wall deflected the flames both ways along the tunnel, and the bricks in the tunnel wall began to [[spall]] and melt in the flames.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/local-news/gallery/remembering-summit-tunnel-fire-30-8315438|title=Remembering the Summit tunnel fire 30 years on|first=Damon|last=Wilkinson|date=19 December 2014|publisher=}}</ref> The BA crews from both brigades decided to evacuate.<ref name=Times211284/> They managed to leave just before the first explosion rocked the tunnel.
Left to itself, the fire burned as hot as it could. As the walls warmed up and the air temperature in the tunnel rose, all 10 tankers discharged petrol vapour from their pressure relief valves. Two tankers melted (at approximately {{convert|1530|C|disp=or}}) and discharged their remaining loads.
The fuel supply to the fire was so rich that some of the combustibles were unable to find oxygen inside the tunnel with which to burn; they were instead ejected from vent shafts 8 and 9 as fuel-rich gases that burst into flame when they encountered oxygen in the air outside. At the height of the fire, pillars of flame approximately {{convert|45|m|ft}} high rose from the shaft outlets on the hillside above.
The gases are estimated to have flowed up these shafts at {{convert|50|m/s|mph}}. Air at this speed is capable of blowing around heavy items: hot projectiles made from tunnel lining (rather like [[volcanic bombs|lava bombs]] from a [[volcano]]) were cast out over the hillside. These set much of the vegetation on fire,{{sfn|Stephen|2016|p=103}} and caused the closure of the [[A6033 road]].<ref name=Times211284/> In the cleanup operation afterwards, small globules of metal were found on the ground surrounding shaft 9; these had been melted from the tanker walls, swept up with the exhaust gases, and dropped out onto the grass around the top of the shaft.
Unable to get close enough to safely fight the fire directly,{{sfn|Stephen|2016|p=102}} the fire brigades forced high-expansion foam into ventilation shafts far from the fire.<ref name=Times211284/> This created blockages that starved the fire of oxygen. By mid-afternoon the next day, the inferno was no longer burning, though the fire was by no means knocked down. Petrol continued to leak from the derailed wagons through the tunnel drainage and ballast and the vapour sporadically reignited when it came into contact with the hot tunnel lining. Two hundred people were evacuated from their homes and workplaces in [[Walsden]] in response.<ref name = "RA" /><ref name=Times211284>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Homes evacuated as train explodes |first=David |last=Nicholson-Lord |day_of_week=Friday |date=21 December 1984 |page_number=28 |issue=62018 |column=A-E }}</ref> They were allowed back home the next day.<ref name=Times221284/>
The brigades continued to fight the fire for another two days, until West Yorkshire Fire Brigade issued the stop message just after 6:30 p.m. on Christmas Eve. Fire crews remained at the site until 7 January 1985.{{sfn|Stephen|2016|p=103}}
==Aftermath== [[File:Summit Tunnel, North Portal - geograph.org.uk - 60363.jpg|thumb|People walking through Summit Tunnel in August 1985, before the line was reopened to traffic]] Due to the fire, the line between {{rws|Rochdale}} and {{rws|Todmorden}} was closed. Passenger trains between two stations were replaced by buses.<ref name=Times221284>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Rail disruption for weeks after tunnel fire |day_of_week=Saturday |date=22 December 1884 |page_number=2 |issue=62019 |column= }}</ref> Of the {{convert|1100000|L|impgal USgal}} of [[petrol]] carried by the train, {{convert|275000|L|impgal USgal}} were rescued by the train crew when they drove the locomotive and the first three tankers to safety. A further {{convert|16000|L|impgal USgal}} of petrol were recovered after the fire was extinguished, and {{convert|900000|L|impgal USgal}} ({{convert|670|t|LT ST|disp=or}}) burnt.
The damage done by the fire was minimal. Approximately half a mile of track had to be replaced, as did all the electrical services and signalling. The biggest surprise was how well the brick lining had stood up to the fire.<ref name = "RA" /> Although some bricks in the tunnel and in the blast relief shafts had become so hot that they vitrified and ran like molten glass, most of the brickwork lining of the tunnel was scorched but still serviceable. One of the photographs taken in the aftermath shows a rail tanker directly beneath shaft 9: it is crowned with a mass of vitrified slag from bricks in the shaft that had melted and dripped down.
The last of the wagons was removed from the tunnel on 1 March 1985.<ref name = "RA" /> Once British Rail had replaced the track and electrical services, shored up the bases of vent shafts 8 and 9 and filled the two shafts with inert foam (all this took eight months), locals were allowed a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to walk through the tunnel before train services resumed on 19 August 1985.<ref name = "RA" />
The Summit Tunnel fire is probably one of the biggest underground fires in transportation history, certainly bigger than the [[1996 Channel Tunnel fire]] (a relatively meagre 350 [[watt|megawatts]]) and probably bigger than the ill-defined [[Salang tunnel fire]] in [[Afghanistan]]. Only the Crozet tunnel accident (France, 20 March 1971) may have been bigger.<ref>http://www.tunnels-ferroviaires.org/tu42/42078.1.pdf</ref> The BR train crew who returned to the site to rescue a locomotive and three tankers left the fire site shortly before one of the other petrol tankers filled the tunnel with flames. The firefighters in BA sets who were in the tunnel when it filled with flames were saved because blast relief shafts 8 and 9 acted as flame vents (a function their designer never envisaged).
At the Masons Arms [[public house]] in Todmorden, there is a small collection of photographs noting the fire, along with the statistics of the construction,{{cn|date=March 2016}} and a quotation by [[George Stephenson]], the tunnel's builder, who said, "I stake my reputation and my head that the tunnel will never fail so as to injure any human life".<ref name=Times010391>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename= |day_of_week=On track to hail Pennine navvies |first=Peter |last=Davenport |date=1 March 1991 |page_number=11 |issue=63954 |column=C-F }}</ref>
==Investigation== A [[public enquiry]] was held into the accident. The hearing was held in [[Manchester]].<ref name=Times090285>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Tanker train crew ran for their lives |day_of_week=Saturday |date=9 February 1985 |page_number=3 |issue=62058 |column=B-C }}</ref> A report was published on 4 June 1985.<ref name = "RA"/>

[[File:Re-Repeat by Iman Al Sayed.jpg|thumb|Re-Repeat By [[Iman Al Sayed]] - The Big Picture Art Exhibition 2014]]A non-profit art organization consists of an annual art exhibition as well as an expanded program of talks and collateral events in [[The United Arab Emirates]]. participating artists and curators for the juried exhibition are selected via an open call announced every December.<ref>{{cite web|last1=alborghetti|first1=roberto|title="THE BIG PICTURE" IN DUBAI : DEMOLISHING BOUNDARIES AND FREEING ARTISTS "FROM ART POLITICS, GALLERIES’ PROFITABLE GUIDELINES AND FAME-DRIVEN MARKET"|url=https://robertoalborghetti.wordpress.com/2013/06/11/the-big-picture-in-dubai-demolishing-boundaries-and-freeing-artists-from-art-politics-galleries-profitable-guidelines-and-fame-driven-market/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BREAKING BOUNDARIES|url=http://wilesmag.com/2013/arts-entertainment-breaking-boundaries/}}</ref>
== Annual Exhibition== * '''2015:''' Hosted in Pro Art Gallery and Street Art Gallery Dubai in the month of May and curated by Xenia Gazi.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nikoliovich|first1=Nichole|title=Who’s behind the Big Picture?|url=http://middleeastliving.com/whos-behind-the-big-picture/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Selected to Present Photos in Dubai|url = http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/kerala/Selected-to-Present-Photos-in-Dubai/2015/04/17/article2767966.ece|accessdate = 2015-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Photo artist selected for international show|url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/kozhikode/photo-artist-selected-for-international-show/article7120912.ece|newspaper = The Hindu|date = April 20, 2015|access-date = 2015-06-13|issn = 0971-751X|language = en|first = Jabir|last = Mushthari}}</ref> * '''2014:''' Hosted in Pro Art Gallery Dubai<ref>{{cite web|last1=McGinley|first1=Shane|title=Dubai showcase to include works by Warhol, Picasso, Dali and Banksy|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/dubai-showcase-include-works-by-warhol-picasso-dali-banksy-536810.html}}</ref> and which included original works artists such as [[Picasso]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Salvador Dali]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]], [[Jean-Michel Basquiat]] and [[Banksy]] curated along 40 emerging artists from the UAE curated by Ram Nath.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Seaman|first1=Anna|title=Big Picture exhibition in Dubai has works by local artists hanging next to famous pieces by Warhol, Banksy|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/big-picture-exhibition-in-dubai-has-works-by-local-artists-hanging-next-to-famous-pieces-by-warhol-banksy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Churchill|first1=Neil|title=Local Dubai Artists Share Space With Banksy|url=http://edgardaily.com/local-dubai-artists-share-space-with-banksy/}}</ref> * '''2013:''' Hosted in June 2013 at Dubai Community Theatre and Arts Centre.
