Television]] * [[CBS Television Studios]] }} | distributor = [[CBS Television Distribution]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|4|17}} | last_aired = {{End date|2015|7|24}} | website = http://cwtv.com/shows/the-messengers/ | website_title = Official website | production_website = }} '''''The Messengers''''' is an American television series that aired on [[The CW]] during the 2014–15 season. The series was officially picked up on May 8, 2014,{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2014/05/08/the-cw-new-series-fall-2014-the-flash/|title=The CW New Series For Fall 2014 – 'The Flash' and 'iZombie'|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|date=May 8, 2014|publisher=TVLine|accessdate=May 12, 2014}} and premiered on April 17, 2015. The series was cancelled by the CW on May 7, 2015, but aired all of its episodes, and concluded on July 24, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/upfront-central/upfronts-2015-cw-cancels-hart-dixie-messengers/140663|title=Upfronts 2015: CW Cancels 'Hart of Dixie', 'The Messengers'|last=Baysinger|first=Tim|work=Broadcasting & Cable|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} ==Plot== A mysterious object plummets to Earth, sending out a shock wave that causes five strangers to die, only to miraculously come back to life moments later. The members of the group are Vera (Shantel VanSanten), a struggling radio-astronomer living in New Mexico who is searching for her missing son; Erin (Sofia Black-D'Elia), a young mother in Tucson, Arizona who is desperate to protect her seven-year-old daughter Amy from her abusive policeman ex-husband; Peter (Joel Courtney), a troubled high school student and orphan in Little Rock, Arkansas; Raul (J.D. Pardo), a federal agent in Mexico who is looking to escape his dangerous and violent undercover assignment; and Joshua (Jon Fletcher), a charismatic second-generation televangelist in Houston, Texas. Most mysterious of all is the figure known only as The Man (Diogo Morgado), who offers Vera the location of her abducted son if she will help him with one morally complicated task which puts her on a collision course with Rose ([[Anna Diop]]), a nurse in Houston who has been in a coma for seven years after being shot by an unknown hitman. Drawn together by fate and biblical prophecy, "The Messengers" soon learn they now have supernatural gifts that might be the only hope for preventing the impending [[Rapture]]. ==Cast and characters== ===The Messengers=== The main characters of the series are the Messengers (real term: "Angels of the Apocalypse"), a group of ordinary humans chosen by [[God]] to determine if humanity is worth saving. They are hit by an energy wave from the meteorite that brought The Man to earth, which causes them to die for a few minutes. Then they awaken with strange supernatural abilities denominated as "gifts". However, their gifts have side-effects on their bodies unless the seven ''true'' Messengers are united. *[[Shantel VanSanten]] as Vera Buckley{{cite web|url=http://www.cwtvpr.com/the-cw/shows/the-messengers/about|title=CWTVPR Press Release|publisher=CWTVPR|accessdate=December 13, 2014}} :An emotionally and financially struggling radio-astronomer who is searching for her missing son, Michael, who was kidnapped seven years earlier. After finding out her ex-boyfriend (and Michael's father), Leo Travers, carries a genetic disease, which was the reason he broke up with her, Vera decides to tell him about their kidnapped son's existence, rekindling their relationship. :Gift: spirit-walking; side-effect: If her spirit doesn't return to her body in a short time, her body dies. *[[J. D. Pardo]] as Raul Garcia :A former drug courier who became a US Federal agent to bring down the Mexican drug cartel he worked for. It is soon revealed that the detective who arrested him was the one who betrayed him to the same drug cartel. After failing to save his brother, Raul is trying to make amends with his niece, Nadia; both are unaware that they are biological father and daughter. :Gift: mind-reading and telepathy; side-effect: headaches. *[[Joel Courtney]] as Peter Moore :A troubled high school student and orphan with previous [[suicidal ideation|suicidal tendencies]]. After developing his ability, he kills one of his tormentors in [[self-defense]] and ends up on the run. When he meets the other Messengers, Peter learns the meaning of having a family and wants to make amends with his last foster parents, David and Melissa Cooper. He also develops an interest in Raul's niece, Nadia. :Gift: super strength; side-effect: unknown. *Jon Fletcher as Joshua Silburn Jr. :A second-generation televangelist preacher and recovered addict who struggles to find his place in the world. After he realized that his wife cheated on him with his own father (Silburn, Snr.) which makes him the possible father of her baby, Joshua leaves in anger and meets the rest of the Messengers by the way. By the end, he is the only one aware of Erin's daughter, Amy and her true self as the Antichrist. :Gift: Having psychic visions of the future; side-effect: seizures. *[[Sofia Black-D'Elia]] as Erin Calder :A young woman trying to make a new life for herself and daughter after fleeing from her abusive and controlling husband, who is a policeman, but what she doesn't know is that her own daughter is in fact the new Antichrist, the Devil's daughter. She develops an interest in Raul. :Gift: physical healing; side-effect: [[Degeneration|deterioration in her body]]. *[[Jessika Van]] as Koa Lin{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/09/adam-campbell-joins-unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-sam-littlefield-the-messengers-840257/|title=Deadline Sam Littlefield In The Messengers|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=December 13, 2014}} :An orphaned grifter from Hong Kong who learned everything from her father, who was murdered when she was young. She joins the team during the time they are facing the Abaddon hacker so she can regain her lost money. :Gift: [[shape-shifting]]; side-effect: [[Memory loss|losing her own memories]] in turn. *[[Winston Duke]] as Zahir Zakaria{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/12/ashley-hinshaw-cast-true-detective-winston-duke-the-messengers-1201321091/|title=Winston Duke In The Messengers|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=December 13, 2014}} :A journalist from [[Mali]] who is determined to seek justice after the Plowman brothers' agricultural experiment goes wrong in a [[West African]] village. :Gift: electricity manipulation; side-effect: unknown. ====The Messengers' allies==== *Craig Frank as Alan Harris{{cite web|url=http://www.cwtvpr.com/the-cw/shows/the-messengers/releases|title=Craig Frank Upped To Regular On The Messengers|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=December 13, 2014}} :Vera's assistant astronomer who was oblivious to Vera's powers and of the other Messengers as well, but is convinced that a government conspiracy is behind the recent events. However, after learning the truth from Vera, Alan became a trusted ally for the team. He has a crush on Vera. *Jennifer Griffin as Eliza Shepard :A former Messenger from a previous generation. She has been watching over the new team's activities, and she has her suspicions about Rose's activity and intentions (by deducing she is a Horseman). It is confirmed to the viewers when the Devil eyes the Messengers from a distance and addresses Amy as his daughter. |LineColor = 005AA4 }} }} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== ''The Messengers'' has received mixed reviews from critics. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the show a rating of 47% based on 17 reviews with an average rating of 5.6 out of 10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-messengers/s01/|title=The Messengers: Season 1|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} The site's consensus reads: "''The Messengers'' flashes bursts of potential, but ultimately sags beneath derivative, muddled storytelling". [[Metacritic]] gave the show a score of 56 out of 100, based on 15 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-messengers-2015|title=The Messengers: Season 1|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} ==Release== ''The Messengers'' was scheduled to premiere on April 10, 2015,{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2014/05/15/the-cw-fall-tv-lineup-2014-flash-tuesdays-timeslot/|title=The CW Fall Schedule Revealed: The Originals on the Move, Flash Paired With Supernatural|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|publisher=TVLine|date=May 15, 2014|accessdate=May 18, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2015/01/11/cw-show-renewals/21595759/|title=CW renews eight dramas for new seasons|last=Levin|first=Gary|work=[[USA Today]]|date=January 11, 2015|accessdate=January 11, 2015}} but was moved back a week to April 17, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/listings/20150325cw11/|title=Episode Title: (#101) "Awakening"|work=[[The Futon Critic]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015}} In [[Australia]], the series premiered on [[FOX8]] on June 3, 2015. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://cwtv.com/shows/the-messengers/}} * {{IMDb title|3513704|The Messengers}} {{The CW programming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Messengers (TV series), The}} [[Category:2010s American drama television series]] [[Category:2015 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2015 American television series endings]] [[Category:Apocalyptic television series]] [[Category:Christian fiction]] [[Category:The CW shows]] [[Category:The Devil in fiction]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Fictional depictions of the Antichrist]] [[Category:Historical fiction]] [[Category:Religion in popular culture]] [[Category:Serial drama television series]] [[Category:Television series by CBS Television Studios]] [[Category:Television series by Warner Bros. ''This article is about the discussion group active in Britain from 1938 to 1947. For the Moot in Games Workshop's Warhammer Fantasy fictional universe, see [[The Empire (Warhammer)]].'' '''The Moot''' was a discussion group concerned with education, social reconstruction, and the role of culture in society. It was convened by [[J. H. Oldham]], editor of the [[Christian Newsletter]], and its participants were mainly Christian intellectuals. [[Karl Mannheim]] was a central figure in the group. Others who attended included [[T. S. Eliot]], [[John Middleton Murry]], [[Frederick Clarke (educator)|Sir Fred Clarke]], [[Michael Polanyi]], [[Reinhold Niebuhr]], [[Paul Tillich]], [[Walter Hamilton Moberly|Sir Walter Moberly]], [[John Baillie (theologian)|Professor John Baillie]], Sir Hector Herrington, [[Geoffrey Vickers]], [[Alec Vidler|A.R. Vidler]], [[H. A. Hodges]] and [[Adolph Lowe]]. Catholic historian and independent scholar [[Christopher Dawson]] also contributed numerous written submissions, although he was able to attend only two meetings.{{cite book|last=Clements|first=Keith|title=The Moot Papers: Faith, Freedom and Society 1938-1944|publisher=T & T Clark|page=11}} The discussion group grew out of a Conference on Church, Community and State held at Oxford in 1937.
"More than anything else, the discussions of the Moot revolved around the topic of order and, more particularly, around the problem of how order might be restored in British society and culture in the context of a ‘world turned upside down’." (Mullins and Jacobs, 2006)
The discussions influenced T.S. Eliot's works of [[cultural criticism]] ''The Idea of a Christian society'' and ''Notes towards the definition of culture''. == References == * ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'' * Clary, Betsy Jane ''Rethinking the Future: The Correspondence Between Geoffrey Vickers and Adolph Lowe'' Journal of Economic Issues, March, 1994 * ''The Moot Papers: Faith, Freedom and Society 1938-1944'', ed Keith Clements (London: T & T Clark, 2010) [http://www.continuumbooks.com/books/detail.aspx?BookId=131497] * Kojecky, Roger, ''T.S. Eliot's Social Criticism'', 1971, revised edn. 2014. Ch 9 'A Christian Elite' gives an extended account of The Moot. * Mullins, Phil and Jacobs, Struan 2006 ''T.S. Eliot’s Idea of the Clerisy, and its Discussion by Karl Mannheim and Michael Polanyi in the Context of J.H. Oldham’s Moot'' Journal of Classical Sociology July 2006 6 pp147–156 [http://jcs.sagepub.com/content/6/2/147.abstract] * Mullins, Phil and Jacobs, Struan 2005 ''Michael Polanyi and Karl Mannheim, Tradition and discovery'' the Polanyi society periodical, vol. 32, no. 1, pp. 20–43. [http://www.deakin.edu.au/dro/view/DU:30013191] * Schuchard, Margret, ‘T.S. Eliot and Adolph Lowe in Dialogue The Oxford Ecumenical Conference and After - New Letters and More about the Moot’, ''AAA: Arbeiten aus Anglistik und Amerikanistik'', Bd. 31, H. 1 (2006), pp. 3–24. * A.R. Vidler, ''Scenes from a Clerical Life'', 1977, includes reminiscences by a core member of The Moot. ==External links== * Archival Material at {{wikidata|qualifier|property|P485|Q24568958|P856|format=\[%q %p\]}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moot, The}} [[Category:1938 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1947 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Philosophy events]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1947]] {{UK-org-stub}}

'''Website correlation''', or '''website matching''', is a process used to identify websites that are similar or related. Websites are inherently easy to duplicate.<ref name="replication">Search: [http://www.google.com/search?q=website+replication "website replication"], Google</ref><ref name="clone">Search: [http://www.google.com/search?q=website+clone+script "website clone script"], Google</ref><!--the preceding references demonstrate that cloning is common and well-documented --> This led to proliferation of identical websites<ref name="proliferation">Fetterly, D., Manasse, M., Najork, M., "[http://www.cwr.cl/la-web/2003/stamped/05_fetterly_d.pdf On the Evolution of Clusters of Near Duplicate Web Pages]", ''Proceedings of the First Conference on Latin American Web Congress'', pp. 37,2003</ref> or very similar websites for purposes ranging from [[translation]] to [[Internet marketing]] (especially [[affiliate marketing]])<ref name="market_book_sample">''I've Got a Domain Name--Now What???: A Practical Guide to Building a Website and Web Presence'', {{ISBN|1-60005-109-X}}, 2008</ref><!-- Included this book as an example of a book that explicitly suggests creating multiple websites --> to [[Internet crime]]<ref name="Internet_crime_example">Shane McGlaun, [http://www.dailytech.com/Microsoft+Granted+Permanent+Ownership+of+276+Botnet+Domains/article19579.htm "Microsoft Granted Permanent Ownership of 276 Botnet Domains"], ''Daily Tech'',2010/9/9</ref><!-- example news reference to multiple domains used for crime --> Locating similar websites is inherently problematic because they may be in different languages, on different servers, in different countries (different [[top-level domains]]).
==Uses== Website correlation is used in: *Internet Investigations<ref name="ncjrs_manual">Investigations Involving the Internet and Computer Networks [http://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/210798.pdf], ''National Institute of Justice (U.S.)'',2007</ref> to determine the overall scope of an investigation *[[market research]] to locate competitors or determine the market reach of competing companies or for [[cluster sampling]] *[[Web filtering]]<ref name="literature_survey">J Prasanna Kumar,P Govindarajulu,"Duplicate and Near Duplicate Documents Detection: A Review",''European Journal of Scientific Research'',{{ISSN|1450-216X}} Vol.32 No.4 (2009), pp.514-527</ref><!--survey of duplicate detection literature, especially as it relates to web filtering--> systems to ensure that all websites of a specific type are blocked from view *[[Data mining]] systems to maximize input or output data *[[risk management]] programs to ensure websites are being monitored for problems that introduce fiscal risk *Compliance monitoring as part of a [[compliance and ethics program]] or policy to ensure websites follow established guidelines
==Correlation types== There are several known types of correlation, each demonstrating different strengths and weaknesses. A practical website correlation process may require combining two or more of these methods.
===Similar structure=== To save time and effort, website owners duplicate major portions of website code across many [[Domain name|domain]]s. Similarity of code structure can provide enough information for correlation. Organizations known to have a publicly search-able databases for this kind of correlation include: *http://www.delineal.com
note: Websites can sometimes utilize the same structure but have no relationship to each other (as when websites coincidentally utilize the same [[content management system]]).
===Same server or subnet=== Also known as correlated [[Reverse DNS lookup]]. Websites may be served from the same [[Server (computing)|server]], on one or more [[ip address]], on one or more [[subnet]]. Several organizations retain archives of ip address data and correlate the data. Examples include: * http://www.domaintools.com note: Correlation via this method may be misleading because websites frequently exist on the same server (aka [[shared hosting]]) but have no relationship to each other.
===Same owner=== Websites may be authored by the same person or organization. Website owners are required to provide contact information to a [[Domain name registrar|registrar]] to obtain a [[domain name]]. Domain ownership can be determined via the [[WHOIS]] protocol which provides no mechanism for searching or correlating ownership. Several organizations retain archives of WHOIS information and provide searching and correlation services. Examples include: *http://whoisology.com *http://www.domaintools.com
note: Website ownership information can be ''falsified'', ''outdated'', or ''hidden from public view''. Website Correlation via this method can be accurate, misleading, or impossible depending on the information contained in WHOIS records.
===Similar content=== Search engines provide search-able databases of indexed website content. Search engine results lists are correlated by content similarity.
====Google==== * on [[Google.com]] type 'related:website_name_here.com' to find websites related by name or phrases * find a unique-sounding phrase on the website then use search engine(s) to locate the phrase literally on other websites **In the search box, place quotes around the phrase to do a literal phrase search **instead of copyright 2010 xyzcompany use "copyright 2010 xyzcompany" note: This method of correlation is ''inherently slow'' because one must guess which phrases to search for. Also, related websites may not contain literally similar content (as when a site is translated into another language).
===Same category===
Websites are frequently categorized or tagged similarly via automated or manual means. Examples of publicly accessible website categorization databases include: * http://www.similarsitesearch.com/ * http://similarsites.com * http://similarsites.de * http://www.similarsitecheck.com * http://www.similarto.us * [[DMOZ]]
note: Manual [[Categorization]] and [[tag (metadata)]] methods are inherently subjective.<ref name="subjective_tagging">Bruce & Wiebe, "[https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/natural-language-engineering/article/recognizing-subjectivity-a-case-study-in-manual-tagging/131A4DC84D785E612DDC1AB3A823BD76 Recognizing subjectivity: a case study in manual tagging]", ''Natural Language Engineering'', 1999</ref> Automated categorization and tagging methods are inherently subject to the varying weaknesses and strengths of underlying categorization algorithms.<ref name="automated_tagging">Fabrizio Sebastiani. [https://arxiv.org/pdf/cs.ir/0110053 Machine learning in automated text categorization]. ACM Computing Surveys, 34(1):1–47, 2002.</ref>
===Same tracking ID===
Tracking IDs, used for [[analytics]] or affiliate identification are frequently embedded in website code. These ids can be used for correlation because they imply common management of websites. Publicly available websites for correlating by tracking id include: * http://ewhois.com
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''X-Ray Imaging and Spectroscopy Mission''' ('''XRISM'''), formerly named the X-ray Astronomy Recovery Mission (XARM, pronounced "charm"),<ref group="Note">According to Paul Hertz, director of NASA's astrophysics division, this is because the project "does need some luck"</ref> is an [[X-ray astronomy]] satellite of the [[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]] (JAXA) to provide breakthroughs in the study of structure formation of the universe, outflows from galaxy nuclei, and [[dark matter]].<ref name=Hertz201706>{{cite web |url=https://www.nsf.gov/attachments/190966/public/HertzAAAC2017Jun22FINAL2.pdf |title=Astrophysics |last1=Hertz |first1=Paul |format=PDF |publisher=[[NASA]] |date=22 June 2017 |access-date=2017-07-01}}</ref><ref name="HEAPA2017">{{cite web |url=https://repository.exst.jaxa.jp/dspace/bitstream/a-is/609732/1/SA6000060006.pdf |title=ASTRO-Hに対する高エネルギーコミュニティの総括と今後の方向性について |last1=Fujimoto |first1=Ryuichi |last2=Tashiro |first2=Makoto |format=PDF |publisher=[[JAXA]] |date=5 January 2017 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref> As the only international X-ray observatory project of its period, XRISM will function as a next generation space telescope in the X-ray astronomy field, similar to how the [[James Webb Space Telescope]], [[Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope|Fermi Space Telescope]], and the [[Atacama Large Millimeter Array|ALMA]] Observatory are placed in their respective fields.<ref name="ASTRO-H Successor"/><ref name="mext20160929">{{cite web |url=http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/shingi/gijyutu/gijyutu2/059/shiryo/__icsFiles/afieldfile/2016/10/06/1377887_7.pdf |title=Ｘ線天文衛星代替機の検討状況について |format=PDF |publisher=[[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|MEXT]] |date=29 September 2016 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref> The mission will crosslink X-ray telescopes of the present ([[Chandra X-ray Observatory|Chandra]], [[XMM-Newton]]) with that of the future ([[Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics|ATHENA]], [[List of proposed space observatories#Design studies|Lynx]]/X-Ray Surveyor), thus preventing the formation of a blank period in X-ray astronomy in the early 2020s resulting from the loss of [[Hitomi (satellite)|''Hitomi'']].<ref name="ASTRO-H Successor"/><ref name="mext20160929"/> During its formulation, XRISM/XARM was also known as the "ASTRO-H Successor", "ASTRO-H2".
==Overview== [[File:Astro-H schema (en).png|thumbnail|The XRISM project will be based on the [[Astro-H|ASTRO-H]] mission]] With the retirement of [[Suzaku (satellite)|''Suzaku'']] in August 2015, and the detectors onboard [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]] and [[XMM-Newton]] operating for more than 15 years and gradually aging, the failure of ''Hitomi'' meant that X-ray astronomers will have a 12-year blank period in soft X-ray observation, until the launch of ATHENA (which according to [[Institute of Space and Astronautical Science|ISAS]] director general Saku Tsuneta is a "super ASTRO-H"<ref name="Foust20160613">{{cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=June 13, 2016 |title=NASA and JAXA begin discussions on aftermath of Hitomi failure |url=http://spacenews.com/nasa-and-jaxa-begin-discussions-on-aftermath-of-hitomi-failure/ |newspaper=[[SpaceNews]] |accessdate=2017-06-28}}</ref>) in 2028.<ref name="ASTRO-H Successor"/><ref name="mext20160929"/><ref name="ISASnews430">{{cite web |url=http://www.isas.jaxa.jp/outreach/isas_news/files/ISASnews430.pdf |title=ISASニュース 2017.1 No.430 |publisher=[[Institute of Space and Astronautical Science]] |format=PDF |date=22 January 2017 |access-date=2016-03-23 |language=Japanese}}</ref> This may result in a major setback for the international community,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www8.cao.go.jp/space/comittee/dai52/siryou2-1.pdf |title=Ｘ線天文衛星「ひとみ」の異常事象への対応と代替機の開発について |format=PDF |publisher=Committee on National Space Policy of Japan |date=18 August 2016 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref> as there will be no telescope to cover the most important part of X-ray astronomy, when in other wavelengths the operation of large scale observatories, such as the James Webb Space Telescope and the [[Thirty Meter Telescope]] will commence.<ref name="ASTRO-H Successor"/><ref name="mext20160929"/> A lack of missions could also deprive young astronomers a chance to gain hands-on experience from participating in a project.<ref name="ASTRO-H Successor"/><ref name="mext20160929"/> For these reasons, as well as to recover the science that was to be gained from ''Hitomi'', the XRISM project began. The XRISM mission has been recommended by ISAS's Advisory Council for Research and Management, the High Energy AstroPhysics Association in Japan, NASA Astrophysics Subcommittee, NASA Science Committee, NASA Advisory Council.<ref name="mext20160929"/><ref name="pcos"/> With a planned launch in March 2021,<ref name="pcos"/> XRISM will recover the science that was lost with ''Hitomi'', such as the structure formation of the universe, feedback from galaxies/active galaxy nuclei, and the history of material circulation from stars to galaxy clusters.<ref name="HEAPA2017"/> The space telescope will also serve as a technology demonstrator for the European [[Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics|ATHENA]] (Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics) telescope.<ref name="ISASnews430"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isas.jaxa.jp/topics/files/20151202_1.pdf#page=14 |title=X線天文衛星 ASTRO-Hの衛星概要 |last1=Takahashi |first1=Tadayuki |format=PDF |publisher=[[JAXA]] |date=27 November 2015 |access-date=2017-07-13 |language=Japanese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2011.mpe.mpg.de/athena/workshop_mpe_2011/talks/Athena_Dotani_2011June15.pdf#page=9 |title=The 1st Athena Science Workshop JAXA Contribution |last1=Dotani |first1=Tadayasu |format=PDF |publisher=[[Institute of Space and Astronautical Science|ISAS]] |date=15 June 2011 |access-date=2017-06-24}}</ref> Multiple space agencies, including NASA and the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA)<ref name="ESAcv0620">{{cite web |url=http://sci.esa.int/cosmic-vision/59243-gravitational-wave-mission-selected-planet-hunting-mission-moves-forward/ |title=GRAVITATIONAL WAVE MISSION SELECTED, PLANET-HUNTING MISSION MOVES FORWARD |publisher=[[ESA]] |date=20 June 2017 |access-date=2017-06-24}}</ref> are participating in the mission. In Japan, the project is led by JAXA's [[Institute of Space and Astronautical Science]] (ISAS) division, and the U.S. participation is led by NASA's [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] (GSFC). The U.S. contribution is expected to cost around $80 million, which is about the same amount as the contribution to ''Hitomi''.<ref name="Foust20160721">{{cite news |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=July 21, 2016 |title=NASA may build replacement instrument for Japanese astronomy mission |url=http://spacenews.com/nasa-may-build-replacement-instrument-for-japanese-astronomy-mission/ |newspaper=[[SpaceNews]] |accessdate=2017-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www8.cao.go.jp/space/comittee/27-kiban/kiban-dai26/siryou2.pdf |title=第９回 宇宙科学・探査小委員会 議事要旨 |format=PDF |publisher=Committee on National Space Policy of Japan |date=1 November 2016 |access-date=2017-06-30 |language=Japanese}}</ref>
A team of astronomers from GSFC suggests pairing the XARM satellite with a source satellite containing radioactive sources. XRISM will observe the source sat to conduct absolute calibration of its telescopes, thus functioning as a in-orbit X-ray "standard candle". With its broad effective area, the telescope could potentially establish several standard candles in the sky by observing constant celestial sources. If this concept proves successful, later missions such as ATHENA and Lynx may have their own source sats.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/iachec/meetings/2017/presentations/IACHEC2017_Markevitch_session12.pdf |title=Cal X-1: an in-orbit X-ray standard candle |last1=Markevitch |first1=M |last2=Jahoda |first2=K |last3=Hill |first3=J |format=PDF |publisher=[[MIT]] |date=29 March 2017 |access-date=2017-06-30}}</ref>
===Changes from ''Hitomi''=== The X-ray Imaging and Spectroscopy Mission will be one of the first projects for ISAS to place a separate Project Manager (PM) and a Primary Investigator (PI). This measure was taken as part of ISAS's reform in project management to prevent the recurrence of the ''Hitomi'' accident.<ref name="mext20160929"/> In traditional ISAS missions, the PM was also responsible for tasks that would typically be allocated to PI's in a NASA mission.
While ''Hitomi'' had an array of instruments spanning from soft X-ray to soft gamma ray, XRISM will focus around the Resolve instrument (equivalent to ''Hitomi''{{'s}} SXS),<ref name="x-rayuniverse2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.cosmos.esa.int/documents/332006/1402684/MTashiro_t.pdf |title=X‐ray Astronomy Recovery Mission XARM |last1=Tashiro |first1=Makoto |last2=Kelley |first2=Richard |format=PDF |publisher=[[ESA]] |date=8 June 2017 |access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref> as well as Xtend (SXI), which has a high affinity to Resolve.<ref name="mext30">{{cite web |url=http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/shingi/gijyutu/gijyutu2/059/gijiroku/1379220.htm |title=宇宙開発利用部会（第30回） 議事録 |publisher=[[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|MEXT]] |date=29 September 2016 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref> The elimination of a hard X-ray telescope is based on the launch of NASA's [[NuSTAR]] satellite, a development that wasn't put to consideration when the [[Hitomi (satellite)|NeXT]] proposal was initially formulated.<ref name="mext29">{{cite web |url=http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/shingi/gijyutu/gijyutu2/059/gijiroku/1376305.htm |title=宇宙開発利用部会（第29回） 議事録 |publisher=[[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|MEXT]] |date=14 July 2016 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref> NuSTAR's spatial and energy resolution is analogous to ''Hitomi''{{'s}} hard X-ray instruments.<ref name="mext29"/> Once the operation of XRISM starts, collaborative observations with NuSTAR will likely be essential.<ref name="HEAPA2017"/> Meanwhile, the scientific value of the soft and hard X-ray band width boundary has been noted; therefor the option of upgrading XRISM's instruments to be partially capable of hard X-ray observation is under consideration.<ref name="mext30"/><ref name="mext29"/> Furthermore, a hard X-ray telescope proposal with abilities surpassing ''Hitomi'' has also been proposed.<ref name="FORCE2017">{{cite web |url=https://repository.exst.jaxa.jp/dspace/bitstream/a-is/609717/1/SA6000060036.pdf |title=軟Ｘ線から硬Ｘ線の広帯域を高感度で撮像分光する小型衛星計画 FORCE - Focusing On Relativistic universe and Cosmic Evolution - |last1=Nakazawa |first1=Kazuhiro |last2=Mori |first2=Koji |format=PDF |publisher=[[JAXA]] |date=6 January 2017 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref> The ''FORCE'' (Focusing On Relativistic universe and Cosmic Evolution) space telescope is a candidate for the next ISAS competitive medium class mission. If selected, FORCE is to be launched after the mid 2020s, with an eye towards conducting simultaneous observations with ATHENA.<ref name="FORCE2017"/><ref name="HEAPA2017"/>
==History== Following the premature termination of the ''Hitomi'' mission, on 14 June 2016 JAXA announced their proposal to rebuild the satellite.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://smd-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/science-red/s3fs-public/atoms/files/APD_ImpPlan_2016-12-15_0.pdf#page=16 |title=Astrophysics Implementation Plan: 2016 Update |format=PDF |publisher=[[NASA]] |date=15 December 2017 |access-date=2017-07-01}}</ref> The XARM pre-project preparation team was formed in October 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isas.jaxa.jp/outreach/isas_news/files/ISASnews435.pdf#page=6 |title=ISASニュース 2017.6 No.435 |publisher=[[Institute of Space and Astronautical Science]] |format=PDF |date=23 June 2017 |access-date=2017-07-04 |language=Japanese}}</ref> In the U.S. side, formulation is to begin in the summer of 2017.<ref name="Hertz201706"/> In June 2017, ESA announced that they will participate in XRISM as a mission of opportunity.<ref name="ESAcv0620"/>
==Instruments== XRISM will carry two instruments for studying the soft X-ray energy range, Resolve and Xtend. The satellite will have telescopes for each of the instruments, SXT-I (Soft X-ray Telescope for Imager) and SXT-S (Soft X-ray Telescope for Spectrometer).<ref name="mext20160929"/> The pair of telescopes will have a focal length of {{convert|5.6|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="ASTRO-H Successor"/>
===Resolve=== Resolve is a X-ray micro calorimeter. The instrument will likely not be a complete remanufacture of ''Hitomi''{{'s}} SXS, as there are some space-qualified hardware left from developing SXS, and these spare parts may be utilized to build Resolve.<ref name="Foust20160613"/>
===Xtend=== Xtend is a X-ray [[Charge-coupled device|CCD]] camera. Unlike Resolve, which will be a "built-to-print" version of its predecessor, Xtend differs in that its energy resolution will be improved from ''Hitomi''{{'s}} SXI.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/shingi/gijyutu/gijyutu2/059/shiryo/__icsFiles/afieldfile/2017/06/20/1386893_1.pdf |title=X線天文衛星ASTRO-Hのプロジェクト終了について |format=PDF |publisher=[[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|MEXT]] |date=30 May 2017 |access-date=2017-07-01 |language=Japanese}}</ref>
